story:
MATA1001 

by Maritdatter & Pain Solution

MATA1001 is short for "Me and This Army 1001" and is an art performance that will take place at Cafeteateret in Oslo on August 16th 2014. The piece consists of a fabric wall, my body holding 1001 needles like a pin cushion, and a box of 1001 internationally collected reasons to exist, in physical formats such as notes, pictures etc. The duration of the performance is the time it takes me to pull a reason from the box, a needle from my body and pin it to the wall, until all the reasons are attached by all the needles. The reasons will be recorded in advance and this is the soundscape for the performance. 

Life is hard, unfair, brutal and painful. Life is also awesome, gorgeous, wonderful and delirious. So what is your nr 1 reason to exist? Mine is family and friends. The gratitude I feel for their unconditional love. Coffee and cake in bed. Sunshine. Pancakes. Love again.

With this project I hope, and very humbly so, to inspire you to count your blessings. Let me know that you have by telling me your favorite in either of these ways: 

by post: 

MATA1001, St.Halvardsgate 1c, 0192 Oslo, Norway, 

by email: meandthisarmy1001@gmail.com

or on Mata's page on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Mata1001/519440994828853

The reasons will be collected from 16th of june until 16th of july.

Maritdatter 

I am Maritdatter; a performing artist with a bachelor in pain tolerance, seamstress and creator of MATA1001! 

I've performed all over the world with Pain Solution for the last seven years. Through these years I've gained a lot of experience making costumes and sewn props. I've taken several sewing and pattern work courses and I'm currently doing private studies towards my exam in costume making.

Pain Solution

MATA1001 is created in collaboration with Pain Solution.

Pain Solution was founded by the fakir Håvve Fjell in 1993 and is a power packed rollercoaster of breathtaking entertainment, taking the audience on a ride trough beautiful and bizarre sideshow acts. Pain Solution performes all over the world including everything from childrens birthday parties and weddings to tattoo conventions and fetish events. 

www.painsolution.net

Helene Fjell

MATA1001 will be photographed by Helene Fjell.

Helene Fjell is a freelance photographer and artist living in Olso. She has her background from among other the Pressphotography School and she has studied with a number of well known photographers. 

In 2011 her career made a break through as a debutant at Nordic light International Festival of Photography in Kristiansund.

Helene has followed Pain Solution for two decades, a collaboration that has led to several books and exhibitions.

www.helenefjell.no

www.fakirsideshow.blogspot.no


MATA1001 need you support!

For this project I have worked hard with applications for funding with no positive results in the projects favor. This is why I'm reaching out to you for financial support!

MATA1001 needs help to cover the venue, light and sound technicians, photography, studio recording, live streaming, needles, fabric for the wall and the floor, materials for gathering and making notes for the wall, flyers and posters, humble salaries for my assistants/piercers and catering to feed the crew and volunteers on performance day. 

The total budget for the mentioned above is 10720 euro. 


    Perks! Perks! Perks!

    The perks of this project bases themselves on the materials used in the performance. Not all that into too bloody stuff you say? Don't worry - there are some bloodless perks to choose from too! Check out the full selection on your right! 

    A few of those to choose from:






    Worlwide shipping is included for all perks in need of it. 

    Perks will be shipped in august/september

    Workshops will be scheduled in august. 


    How to help MATA1001!

    Choose your perk and pledge!

    Submit your number one reason to exist!

    Spread the word!

    Love, laugh, live!!!

story:
Hey there,
We're Time to Clear the Air - Inviting youth to mobilize through art! 
We are a group of 7 students from the College of Sustainability at Dalhousie University. We are a working group of The ENRICH Project (Environment Noxiousness, Racial Inequities and Community Health) spearheaded by Dr. Ingrid Waldron (Dalhousie School of Nursing) and a team comprised of Mi'kmaw and African Nova Scotian community members and activists, non-profit organizations, volunteer students and faculty/researchers. 
We are currently in the process of organizing an art project, which will feature art contributed by Mi'kmaw and African Nova Scotian youth from around the province of Nova Scotia. The theme of the art project will depict the effects of Environmental Racism within their respective communities.
Environmental Racism is the the inequitable and disproportionate placement of toxic facilities and other environmental hazards near communities of colour and the working poor. Environmental racism also refers to the lack of democratic engagement of these communities in decision making about where these facilities are located.
If we are able to reach our goal of $500.00 it would assist the youth to purchase art supplies. Funds will also help pay for expenses incurred from ongoing outreach efforts to run this project.

Funds will be allocated for the purchase of arts supplies by youth who participate in this project. Funds will also be used for costs associated with travel to and outreach in Mi'kmaw and African Nova Scotian communities. Lastly, some of the funds will be used to rent space to house art displays submitted by youth for the Time to Clear the Air project.

Art supplies: $200.00

Transportation: $100.00

Renting Space for Final Shows: $200.00


The Impact

Oppression which is systemically experienced by Mi'kmaw and African Nova Scotian communities is not an isolated issue, it occurs throughout Canada and the rest of the world. Environmental racism is one example of systematic oppression. Time to Clear the Air and the ENRICH project are hoping to help those who have been silenced by environmental and toxic hazards in their community. Art has no barriers and helps communicate significant messages across language, education and cultural barriers and this is why we hope to receive help in facilitating art projects across marginalized communities in Nova Scotia.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If donations are not within your scope of helping with this project we will also be excepting any donations of art supplies!  Feel free to send any questions or comments to timetocleartheair@gmail.com

story:
*UPDATE*
Thanks to incredible support and enthusiasm from the textile community, we met our pre-sale goal in just under 9 days! We were blown away with the positive response! But, this is only part of the larger puzzle. We still need to sell more subscriptions, so keep spreading the word.  
The $10,000 we raised through IndieGoGo is only part of the funds needed to get the magazine off the ground.  The subscriptions we've pre-sold only represent 10% of the subscriptions we hope to sell for the first issue.  So, it's clear why your support is critical and appreciated!


What if everything you loved about belonging to a textile community came together in one place?

And you could hold it?
Learn from it?
Be inspired by it?

Introducing TAC.

The magazine of Textile Arts Center. 

After five years of witnessing and influencing contemporary textile trends, we decided it was time to gather our resources, industry lessons, and passion, and put them in one place. There are many textile and fiber focused magazines in the world, but we're motivated to make one that highlights the contemporary state of the industry and sheds light on innovative work being made near and far. 

We’re incredibly fortunate to belong to a supportive and talented textile community here in NYC, but we know that doesn't exist everywhere. By helping to make TAC a reality, you’ll be part of a larger network of makers, designers, and artists who want access to this information, no matter where you live. 

By pre-ordering your subscription now, you’re part of the solution. But, your support now helps us print the first issue. We’ll need your continued excitement and support to keep the following issues coming. We know there’s an audience out there who is hungry for this type of content. This is your moment to prove us right and help make this publication a success. 

SUBSCRIBE NOW!

EACH ISSUE FEATURES:

  • Textile News Features — Full length feature stories exploring current events and trends in the textile world. From visits to solar powered fiber farms, to digging deeper into a designer’s inspiration, these features will keep you informed and engaged.
  • Travel guides — Visually arresting travel journals from far flung locales especially tailored to textile-loving voyeurs. 
  • Tutorials — Each issue has two tutorials where you’ll learn new skills, perfect old ones, and get your hands dirty. Taught by our favorite instructors, designers and artists, they’re like tiny classes you can hold.
  • Editorial Fashion Stories —a chapter of total eye candy celebrating textile trends, designers, styling, photography and the art of visual storytelling. 
  • Artist and Designer Highlights — Go behind the scenes in our favorite artist/designers’ studios. Our interviews will cover their process, inspiration, goals, and struggles.
  • Events Page — Finally, all textile events in one place. These pages will give you a comprehensive, worldwide list of upcoming events, shows, and deadlines from leading museums, schools, galleries and more.
  • The Directory — The last pages will feature a collection of brands, businesses, and labels we love and think you will too. And don’t miss the Swatch Spot — a full page devoted to one designer that includes a fabric swatch from their new collection. (A textile magazine wouldn’t be complete without some actual textiles, right?!) 

PRE-ORDER YOUR SUBSCRIPTION NOW!

Follow us on Facebook and Instagram to join the conversation and stay in the loop!

story:
Why I started this campaign

I am an artist, philosopher, writer, counselor and lover of life. The end goal of this fundraising is to acquire my 200 Hour Hatha Yoga Teacher Certification from Yoga Alliance. With it, I will help others heal through movement, breath and art from symptoms of physical, mental, and emotional imbalances. Managing life depression, anxiety, addiction, etc. A regular Yoga practice will cultivate greater strength, flexibility, awareness, and inner peace.There’s only one catch; Yoga teacher training is expensive. Fortunately, with crowd funding this dream is now a reality. As I welcome abundance into my life, allow me to extend blessings back to you. 

Painting by Jeana Marino- "Glory"

What it covers

Yoga Teacher Training $2995.00

Books and Reference Materials $150.00

9 months of Yoga Classes $355.00


This painting is a piece from my energy series- Good Vibrations, "Violets" by Jeana Marino


Intention

By deepening my practice and taking the leap to become a yoga teacher it will fulfill a natural state of being for me. I have always been passionate about counseling others to find what is possible for them. Through creativity, breath and movement we settle the mind as a collective and why not have some fun with it? We will dive into color and move into joy. :)

Choose to make a difference for mind, body wellness through the beauty of art, movement and meditation. 

One of my favorite quotes is : 

“Don’t ask what the world needs. Ask what makes you come alive, and go do it. Because what the world needs is people who have come alive.”- Howard Thurman


Advisors

For the last 4 years, I practiced  with Jason Fischer, MA, LPC 

http://www.jasonbfischer.com/

Jason is the founder/Clinical Director of Plumeria Counseling Center in Austin. His philosophy about counseling teaches individuals to become masters of their own emotional experience and then use this mastery toward the achievement of personal and interpersonal greatness. The information he teaches is life-changing.

"It is wisdom that is seeking wisdom." Shunryu Suzuki Roshi

Currently studying the The Art of Giving Permission with him.


Here are photos from my pilot workshop...it was a success! Featuring live music and laughter!

Gratitude

I want share with you...this is a huge step in my life and I know prosperity shows up for us in so many ways. With that said, allow me express my deepest gratitude for your generosity. My hope is we will practice together. Peace, Love Art and Yoga.

"RareBird" by Jeana Marino- Available in a limited edition print.

story:
The Project


To Its Beginning To Its End is an exhibition which will take place inside the non-profit art space, Adiacenze in Bologna, Italy. Curated by Elisabetta Modena and Marco Scotti, this project is the collaboration of two artists, Chiara Forti (visual) and Alessio Ballerini (sound), to conjure up in four episodes, one for each room inside the gallery, a sequence of installations and soundscapes around the themes of nature, transformation, mutations, different kinds of variations and rites.

The title itself is a quotation from four Samuel Beckett lyrics, which will guide the spectator inside the spaces.

 

The opening will be on Friday, the 27th of January, with an exclusive sound performance by Alessio Ballerini in the courtyard of the gallery.

 

for more information about the artists

www.alessioballerini.com

 

 

What is Adiacenze

ADIACENZE is a non-profit organization founded in Bologna January 2010, born from the idea of Amerigo Mariotti and Daniela Tozzi: to offer a space dedicated to art  and to young artists, who usually encounter many difficulties to set up their exhibitions while theyâ€™re still studying, practising and researching.

With just two years of experience, Adiacenze has become a special place for site specific projects, where the installations of artists modify the space of the gallery each time an exhibition is set up.

 

The entrance for every exhibition is always free, and various publications and editions about the artists have been produced since its opening.

www.adiacenze.it

 

 

What We Need, Why We Need It & What You Get

This is your chance to be part of the work. 

This exhibition has taken more than a year to set up, and for a perfect result Adiacenze asks everyone to support the project to make it possible in its best form, following the artistsâ€™ needs and requests.

 


Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing is the key.

There isnâ€™t much time left, so we need your full support to finish such an important project aside from the resources needed: just make sure everybody interested knows about it, talks about it in order to sustain a project that they believe in. 

 

youâ€™ll find a full presentation of the project, in Italian, here:

http://issuu.com/marcoscotti/docs/cs_to_its_beginning_to_its_end_giustificato


you can see the photo gallery with cd packaging + drawings + exhibition, here:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/alessioballerini/sets/72157629120807369/

story:
WHAT IS PROJECT SKETCHBOOK?

Project Sketchbook is an annual sketchbook mail-out that culminates in an unjuried public exhibition. The venture began as the brainchild of Derrick Dent and the rest of the Rozelle Artists Guild gang as a way to engage the community around us. Every sketchbook turned into us is displayed in an open exhibition, and featured in our annual Project Sketchbook catalog.


The project is simple: we (the lovely Rozellites) lovingly hand-cut and hand-stitch a whole mess of 16-page mini-sketchbooks. We mail/hand them out to whoever wants one, and they fill it up with whatever they want--pencil sketches, gouache paintings, grocery lists, public transit portraits, collaged magazine cut ups, rants about coffee prices--whatever you deem noteworthy. Some of our participants even turn the sketchbooks into delicate paper sculptures!


Then we collect as many as we can wrangle, sit around picking our favorite pages from each, compiling them into a printed catalog, and put on a big exhibition with all of the books on display. There will be wine, snacks, catalogs for sale, live music by local musicians, and a whole gaggle of Memphis creatives cramming into a gallery.

The event is always an interesting social experiment, but what we're really aiming to create is an atmosphere. This is a show where you can pick up the work, touch it, flip the pages, study the marks and read the notes, and that in itself makes it a personal experience. There is a sense of discovery that sets this show apart from the traditional art openings--you have no idea what will be lurking beneath that cover.


WHAT DO YOU NEED FROM ME?

In past endeavors, we have greatly underestimated the allure of this project--having to extend gallery hours to appease the throngs of attendees that populate the openings, and selling out of catalogs nearly instantaneously. This year, we're working on ways to be ready. A big part of that is funding. And that's where you can help!


Entry into Project Sketchbook is free. All the labor that goes into making it all happen is taken on by unpaid creatives. However, paper and galleries and postage are not free. Our goal of $2,000 will cover all the sketchbook materials, advertising & promotion, postage, gallery rental, exhibition costs and catalog printing.


Even if we do not raise the whole $2k, every dollar helps! We are thrifty, and through our five years of collaborative projects around Memphis, we have a good list of contacts to help us out. We will always find ways to get it done, but it's nearly impossible to get started without a little bank to help.


WHY IS PROJECT SKETCHBOOK IMPORTANT?

Project Sketchbook is one of our favorite events of the year because it best embodies what we as a guild hope to give to the community. Every year we have entrants who have never been in an exhibition, never seen their work in a gallery, and/or have never had their work published. Project Sketchbook gives any interested person these opportunities. The exhibition, while displaying the work of the artists, also serves as a networking event where the directors of art organizations, college students, bartenders, baristas, and muralists can mingle.


BUT WHAT IF I'M BROKE?

Hey, we understand! If you are unable to contribute monetarily, maybe you have a connection at a magazine that would like to run an ad? Maybe you work in a big building that could use some posters on the bulletin boards? Or perhaps you know of a few people who'd be interested in Project Sketchbook if they knew about it? Getting the word out is a highly important aspect to hosting a successful run--and we can't do it alone!
story_txt:
WHAT IS PROJECT SKETCHBOOK?

Project Sketchbook is an annual sketchbook mail-out that culminates in an unjuried public exhibition. The venture began as the brainchild of Derrick Dent and the rest of the Rozelle Artists Guild gang as a way to engage the community around us. Every sketchbook turned into us is displayed in an open exhibition, and featured in our annual Project Sketchbook catalog. 

The project is simple: we (the lovely Rozellites) lovingly hand-cut and hand-stitch a whole mess of 16-page mini-sketchbooks. We mail/hand them out to whoever wants one, and they fill it up with whatever they want--pencil sketches, gouache paintings, grocery lists, public transit portraits, collaged magazine cut ups, rants about coffee prices--whatever you deem noteworthy. Some of our participants even turn the sketchbooks into delicate paper sculptures! 

Then we collect as many as we can wrangle, sit around picking our favorite pages from each, compiling them into a printed catalog, and put on a big exhibition with all of the books on display. There will be wine, snacks, catalogs for sale, live music by local musicians, and a whole gaggle of Memphis creatives cramming into a gallery. 
The event is always an interesting social experiment, but what we're really aiming to create is an atmosphere. This is a show where you can pick up the work, touch it, flip the pages, study the marks and read the notes, and that in itself makes it a personal experience. There is a sense of discovery that sets this show apart from the traditional art openings--you have no idea what will be lurking beneath that cover.


WHAT DO YOU NEED FROM ME?


In past endeavors, we have greatly underestimated the allure of this 
project--having to extend gallery hours to appease the throngs of 
attendees that populate the openings, and selling out of catalogs nearly
 instantaneously. This year, we're working on ways to be ready. A big 
part of that is funding. And that's where you can help!

Entry into Project Sketchbook is free. All the labor that goes into making it all happen is taken on by unpaid creatives. However, paper and galleries and postage are not free. Our goal of $2,000 will cover all the sketchbook materials, advertising & promotion, postage, gallery rental, exhibition costs and catalog printing.

Even if we do not raise the whole $2k, every dollar helps! We are thrifty, and through our five years of collaborative projects around Memphis, we have a good list of contacts to help us out. We will always find ways to get it done, but it's nearly impossible to get started without a little bank to help.



WHY IS PROJECT SKETCHBOOK IMPORTANT?

Project Sketchbook is one of our favorite events of the year because it best embodies what we as a guild hope to give to the community. Every year we have entrants who have never been in an exhibition, never seen their work in a gallery, and/or have never had their work published. Project Sketchbook gives any interested person these opportunities. The exhibition, while displaying the work of the artists, also serves as a networking event where the directors of art organizations, college students, bartenders, baristas, and muralists can mingle.


BUT WHAT IF I'M BROKE?

Hey, we understand! If you are unable to contribute monetarily, maybe you have a connection at a magazine that would like to run an ad? Maybe you work in a big building that could use some posters on the bulletin boards? Or perhaps you know of a few people who'd be interested in Project Sketchbook if they knew about it? Getting the word out is a highly important aspect to hosting a successful run--and we can't do it alone!

story:
My name is Rachel Chase, a video, sound, and performance artist among other things. I have a B.F.A. in Studio Art from University of South Florida. As a teaching artist, I love to get kids excited about creativity. Currently, my outlet for this is teaching Dramatic Arts at Socrates Preparatory School in Casselberry, Florida. I have recently been invited to create a performance art / video installation piece for the upcoming Creative City Project happening in Downtown Orlando, Florida, Saturday November 1, 2014. Please see www.CreativeCityProject.com to feel the magnitude of this city-wide event. Other performers include Cirque de Soleil and many more large and small acts. 

My Dramatic Arts class of fifteen children and I are currently in pre-production generating material for the sound, video, and shadow puppetry that will be part of our video installation piece. Included will also be live musical performance by one of the students who is a brilliant cellist, as well as me dancing and creating choreography to include members of the class as performers. Other class members who are not necessarily on stage performing are learning about running sound, lighting, and set installation. For a list of my artistic honors, please see below. Here's a video of one my performance art works for to enjoy (sound mix includes music by Eluv )  : http://vimeo.com/32550890

The site of our performance art / video installation piece, Once Upon a Dream, requires installation of a large outdoor projection screen in a 20'X20' circular area within a grouping of trees in Heritage Park on Central Ave, part of the Orange County Regional History Center. Also, I require a good sound recording microphone to capture some of the pre-recorded sound we will use, materials for costuming, as well as rigging to make the dramatic lighting and and video projections successful. This will run me around $500 to make it professional and successful. If I don't get the full amount, I will do the best I can with what we've got, but it won't ROCK the way I envision it truly can. I want it to be super successful so these kids have a fantastic experience, so the piece can really come to life, and for the audience to have a magical transcendent experience. Here's another video of one of my performance art / video pieces (a music video for Laura Escude) : CLICK this link for video: http://vimeo.com/32243540

I am ecstatic to be a part of this amazing event, the 3rd annual Creative City Project. It is an honor to be invited, and exciting to be a part of the collaborative spirit of this event! Our assignments as producers for this event was to think in terms of collaborating with another group or entity that is not usual for us, to work with the audience in an unusual way, and to use the space creatively. I believe we are accomplishing this excellently. I am so grateful for all the brainstorming and visioning we've  been doing as well as the incredible support and encouragement from the school's President/Director, Faten Abdellah, as well as my immediate family. 

Those of you who know my work know that I love to share and explore what's possible. Will you be a part of this with me? I promise to share lots of pics and videos of the making of this incredible performance art piece. The kids have never gotten to experience anything like this before, and I want them to see that they can create amazing things!

In addition to the satisfaction of contributing to the creative life of this performance, I will make a special thank you video art piece to inspire you and get it to you personally. You will receive a link to a video documentation of the live performance. 

Thank you so much for your help at this crucial moment as we create a successful show on November 1st!


EXHIBITS & PERFORMANCES

2011-2012         Various dance performances and art events, Metrowest Boston area

2010                Together; Electronic Music Festival, MASSART’s Hansel and Gretel Re:Imagined Boston, 

2009                  Boston Cyber Arts Festival, MASSART’s Dead Video/Live Video (Finalist), Boston

2008                        Ybor City Holiday Art Event, exhibitor, co-organizer, Ybor City, Tampa, Florida

                        Connext Project, Original Music Video (Finalist), Clearwater, Florida

Video and Mixed Media Performance, RIOT! At the Factory, Tampa, Florida

2007         Co-director, performer, Performance Lab (1) – interactive and performance event

Prints & Poems, USF Tampa Library, Tampa, Florida

          31st Annual Juried Student Art Exhibition, USF Contemporary Art Museum, Tampa, Florida

2006         ZerOne, International Symposium for Electronic Arts, San Jose, CA

                        The Whiggs Are Coming!, USF Oliver Gallery, Tampa, Florida

                        Paris Je'Taime, Event Organizer and exhibitor, USF Center Gallery, Tampa, Florida

                        WMNF Presents: Concert for Peace, Friday Morning Musicale, Tampa, Florida

2005                        RPM's Remixed, Streaming on-line telematic Performance, Ethernet

                        Laura Escude Live Electro, choreographer- Red Star Ybor City, Tampa, Florida

                        Tropical Heat Wave, WMNF Event, Ybor City, Tampa, FLorida

2004                        Masquerade, Asher Dance Eclectic, Tampa, Florida

                        Concert For Peace- (dancing with Nandkishor Muley), Common Touch, Tampa, Florida

                        Curator for Muse Hybrid, art and music event, Ybor City, Tampa, Florida

2003                        Creacion, performance for Gifted Productions, Davis Islands, Tampa, Florida

                        Curator for Shock and Awe, Dunedin, Florida

1987-2002         Solo and group performances, Longwood, Leesburg, and Tallahassee, Florida

 

HONORS & GRANTS

2009                  Finalist, Dead Video/Live Video contest, Boston, Massachusetts

2008                  Finalist, Connext Project, Brighthouse Networks, Tampa, Florida

2007                        Undergraduate Research Grant, University of South Florida, Tampa, Florida

                        Best of show award for Prints & Poetry exhibit and poetry reading, Tampa, Florida

2006                        Undergraduate Research Grant, University of South Florida, Tampa, Florida

                        Undergraduate Program Assistance Grant for USF Paris Study Abroad program

                            Selected as event organizer for Paris Je'Taime, in conjunction with USF Paris program

2004                        Accepted as dance teacher with Hillsborough Arts Council's education program

                        College of Visual and Performing Arts Council board member

1998                    Excellence in Choreography award from the Community College Association of Florida

1990-1992            Various dance competition awards – solo and group performances and choreography

story:
We can all remember how devastating Hurricane Sandy was 2 years ago. For many, the inconveniences it caused are now just memories...unless you are one of the families still struggling to return to their home.
 
My high school art teacher Eric Fox, and his wife Suzanne are one of those families. Their Long Beach home was destroyed under 9 feet of water when the super-storm’s seawater flooding mixed with the township’s raw sewage.
 
Federal regulations require that families build a breakaway level—an additional story built above the base flood level— before they can return to their homes.

In the years since the storm, the Fox family has been forced to pay a mortgage on a ruined house, struggle with claims to their insurance companies, all while paying rent on a temporary apartment for themselves and their two small children. My goal is to raise $50,000 to finish cost of rebuilding the home and adding the breakaway level.

Any funds not used by Eric and Susanne, or eventually reimbursed by Travelers, Naragansett, FEMA or New York Rising, will be passed on to a non-profit organization to help other struggling families still reeling from super-storm Sandy.

story:
Help remove barriers to enjoying cinema art!

     My name is Gregory, and I am on the board of directors for OUT Twin Cities Film Festival - an international LGBTQ film festival based in St Paul/Minneapolis, Minnesota. otcff.org - a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization.

     OUT Twin Cities Film Festival is dedicated to the goal that there be no barriers for anyone to enjoy the power of cinema art.

     I am seeking funding to purchase Google Glass to develop a system that will assist people from the deaf community in participating in our film festival. Our success in this project will make an impact beyond just our film festival.

     Google Glass can provide real-time closed captioning and/or signing in a person's field of vision while watching a film. I am convinced that Google Glass holds great potential in increasing access for the deaf community. Here is an article that believes the same.

http://limpingchicken.com/2013/05/07/william-mager-could-google-glass-be-the-deaf-communitys-disruptive-innovation/

Help validate our project!

     Our funding goal is simple - raise $1,700 to purchase Google Glass. I have been invited to the Glass Explorer Program, and we need to raise $1,700 to purchase Google Glass. OUT Twin Cities Film Festival is my passion, and I want to use this opportunity to further our goal of no barriers in cinema art.

     How can a film festival and I develop this innovative technology?

Good question. We already have some big support. One of our sponsors, Agosto Inc., is a leading and award winning IT consulting firm that specializes in utilizing Google technology. And they have already worked with Glass technology. Click here to read about the past work in Glass. Agosto Inc. supports our mission and stands ready to help us in this venture.

     Our $1,700 goal is not that big. What is big is the statement it makes. Any size contribution you make says that you believe in our mission and want to see this project happen. Your contribution validates our project. 

     The end result of the funding goal is this. We obtain the key instrument - Google Glass - with which to begin development along with a collective voice saying, "yes, this is a great idea and I want to see it happen." This will position us to move into the development phase of the project and show future funders and grant makers the demand and support for this project. Google itself is offering $25,000 to five nonprofits who can increase their impact with Google Glass, and we aim to compete.

Help make a tremendous impact!

     Who has not been moved by a film? Cinema art is a powerful medium that entertains, informs, inspires and transforms people's lives. Unfortunately, despite all the technology and special effects in producing a film, the technology in screening the film for the deaf and other under represented communities remains limited. These communities are left out and unable to enjoy and contribute to this art form.

     OUT Twin Cities Film Festival invites you to make a big impact in others lives by shattering these barriers.

Help spread the word!

     Everyone can contribute. No donation here is too small because it adds one more voice in the call for action. And even if your situation does not allow you to make a financial contribution, there is nothing stopping you to share this campaign with others. Please help us get the word out.

story:
Magda's Big LA Adventure

 

In September I'm moving to Los Angeles, mostly based on intuition. But you know, in my defense that's exactly how I moved to Philadelphia in 2012 and look how much I loved it here. 

The pandemic squeezed my life with a vengeance and at a certain point I surrendered to the squeeze and wondered mid contraction what my life would look like after. I didn't go the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. I stopped performing my solo show. I started teaching online zooms for artists to write about their lives. I asked them to tell me stories of being naughty as children and fell in love with it all.

And now I'm moving to LA with a very good feeling about working with some artists there who are exploring film, mortality and lust for the insanity of life. 

My plan is to grow my writing workshops into a dependable business. I want to teach writing workshops about life and writing workshops about death and design Process Mother curriculums for artists of all kinds to make the work that their heart is crying to make.

 

Getting There

I have a little hatchback Honda. I've never been attached to material possessions much. The one silk blouse I own was recently burned by a subletter. My plan is to purge, gift and sell almost everything I own and then on September 1st pack my little self into my little car and drive all the way into my trembling hopeful future. 

The problem is I have some large paintings. All of them self-portraits. Because during the driest, loneliest, most binge watching days of my quarantine I turned to painting to fill the hours. 

But fine, I thought: what if people bought my paintings then I would have some relocation funds and less stuff in my car.

That's where you come in.

 

The Portraits

I am selling small and large paintings. Some are on stretched canvas. Some are on paper. Most are acrylic, some are oil. None are framed.

I'm only doing local delivery and pick up. That means you Philadelphia! Because honestly I always forget to ship to people.

We can schedule a pick-up or drop-off time that works for you or you can come to my Pick-Up Party (date TBA).

Please read the measurements carefully so you're not surprised by the dimensions.

And email me if you would like a full image before buying (all the perk images were automatically cropped): magdawkshp@gmail.com.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you know anyone in LA? Connect me! I'm going to need a lot of new friends because I love talking a lot and I need to spread it out. I don't know many people there yet. If you know an artist or a freaky genius please introduce me!

story:
Help me make the pilgrimage to Burning Man 2016!

I have been invited to be one of the chainsaw carvers in this unique guild...  Ziggy Sawdust and the Chainsaw's from Mars... as the Venus Ambassador at this years Burningman! 

We will be one of 32 international guilds  invited by Burningman to participate!  As far as I know it is the first time Burningman has invited chainsaw carving into the central area... and theme.

"Guild Workshops, modern day maker spaces conceived in the spirit of the Renaissance, will be the central feature of a Piazza at this year’s Man Pavilion. Historically, guilds organized many aspects of a city’s socio-economic life. They may have included wool and silk traders, bankers, furriers and shoe makers. It’s no wonder that in a city like Black Rock, driven by art and experience, you will find glassblowers, blacksmiths, dreamers, chainsaw-wielding portrait makers, musicians, engineers, teachers, and many more." Burningman

Our Guild's art manifests in spectacle, performance, and the creation of beautiful portraits in wood, transformed by fire. 

We will be one of 32 workshop Guilds located on the central plaza, around "The Turning Man", following this year's Art Theme "Da Vinci's Workshop". Using chainsaws, we carve the portraits of patrons as they sit in a moop (matter-out-of-place) proof chamber on a chair of transformation. In 15 minutes or less we render a likeness in a slab of wood. The sound and finesse of the chainsaw in the artist's hands is mesmerizing and a bit unnerving. 

The experience of the sitter/audience is mediated as they see their image being carved via the video stream from an action camera that the carver wears. They are watching and they are being watched. 

At an appointed hour after dark, we rendezvous again for a ritualistic transformation of the wooden portrait by the purifying flames of a propane torch.  The image is animated in the darkness as a glowing ember likeness,  a celebration of each creative spark in the dark with the carvers. 

The next morning we brush selected bits of char to reveal your wood grained charcoal image that is our gift to you to do with as you will.  This performance is breaking down the barrier between the audience and the artist. 

I will be driving a truck to transport some of the materials, art and equipment for this art experience, from Arcata, California to Black Rock City, Nevada. My costs include the purchase of a camera, equipment to camp in, costumes for the space/performance, and gas and supplies to get me and my assistant there. 

Burning Man is a place for creativity and astounding art!  For 10 days a barren desert becomes a city of art, self-expression, giving, volunteering, and celebration.  I am honored to be a central part of this year's gathering with the Guild Ziggy Sawdust!

Be a part of this experience! And help support the Arts!
story_txt: Help me make the pilgrimage to Burning Man 2016!I have been invited to be one of the chainsaw carvers in this unique guild...  Ziggy Sawdust and the Chainsaw's from Mars... as the Venus Ambassador at this years Burningman! We will be one of 32 international guilds  invited by Burningman to participate!  As far as I know it is the first time Burningman has invited chainsaw carving into the central area... and theme."Guild Workshops, modern day maker spaces conceived in the spirit of the Renaissance, will be the central feature of a Piazza at this year’s Man Pavilion. Historically, guilds organized many aspects of a city’s socio-economic life. They may have included wool and silk traders, bankers, furriers and shoe makers. It’s no wonder that in a city like Black Rock, driven by art and experience, you will find glassblowers, blacksmiths, dreamers, chainsaw-wielding portrait makers, musicians, engineers, teachers, and many more." BurningmanOur Guild's art manifests in spectacle, performance, and the creation of beautiful portraits in wood, transformed by fire. We will be one of 32 workshop Guilds located on the central plaza, around "The Turning Man", following this year's Art Theme "Da Vinci's Workshop". Using chainsaws, we carve the portraits of patrons as they sit in a moop (matter-out-of-place) proof chamber on a chair of transformation. In 15 minutes or less we render a likeness in a slab of wood. The sound and finesse of the chainsaw in the artist's hands is mesmerizing and a bit unnerving. The experience of the sitter/audience is mediated as they see their image being carved via the video stream from an action camera that the carver wears. They are watching and they are being watched. At an appointed hour after dark, we rendezvous again for a ritualistic transformation of the wooden portrait by the purifying flames of a propane torch.  The image is animated in the darkness as a glowing ember likeness,  a celebration of each creative spark in the dark with the carvers. The next morning we brush selected bits of char to reveal your wood grained charcoal image that is our gift to you to do with as you will.  This performance is breaking down the barrier between the audience and the artist. I will be driving a truck to transport some of the materials, art and equipment for this art experience, from Arcata, California to Black Rock City, Nevada. My costs include the purchase of a camera, equipment to camp in, costumes for the space/performance, and gas and supplies to get me and my assistant there. Burning Man is a place for creativity and astounding art!  For 10 days a barren desert becomes a city of art, self-expression, giving, volunteering, and celebration.  I am honored to be a central part of this year's gathering with the Guild Ziggy Sawdust!Be a part of this experience! And help support the Arts!

story:
Ron Davis' Symphronica, Daniela Nardi's Espresso Manifesto and Great Canadian Poets at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe! 

Hey There!  Thanks for checking out our campaign. So here's the scoop:My name is Ron Davis, Toronto-based jazz pianist-composer and leader of classical-jazz-world-pop fusion ensemble Symphronica. Along with my partner in crime, singer-songwriter and creator of Espresso Manifesto, Daniela Nardi, and an acclaimed collective of Canadian poets called 'The Shaken and the Stirred' featuring Jeanette Lynes, Ian Burgham and Catherine Graham: we have all been invited by The Scottish Arts Club to perform at the world's largest arts festival, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe! We are being presented as a spotlight on Canadian Arts. We are booked to perform six one-hour shows between August 11 and August 21 and this is the first time in its history that the Scottish Arts Club has invited a Canadian collective to perform at the Edinburgh Fringe. Needless to say, this is such a huge honour for us! 

As soon as we were asked to perform at Edinburgh, we said a resounding YES! How could we turn it down? Shortly thereafter, we realized this is quite an endeavour, and in order to do it right, we'll need a little help from our friends.

What We Need & What You Get

  • TRAVEL for musicians (Ron Davis, Daniela Nardi, guitarist Kevin Barrett) and poets (Jeanette Lynes, Ian Burgham, Catherine Graham) will be flying from Toronto to Edinburgh: $1500 x 6 = $9,000
  • MUSICIANS: Symphronica and Espresso Manifesto will be hiring the following all-star players: British drummer Alyn Cosker, Paris-based bassist Chris Jennings, and string players from the Scottish Chamber Orchestra: $10,000
  • ACCOMMODATIONS (2 weeks): $8,000
  • PROMOTIONAL MATERIALS: $2500
  • SHIPPING OF BOOKS AND MUSIC: $500
EVERY CONTRIBUTION WILL HELP US GET THERE - and we have perks available for every level. They include autographed works by the artists, VIP tickets to performances, house concerts and more! See the Perks section for details.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word!  Please forward this campaign to anyone you think might be interested in helping our cause.
  • Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter or however else you can think of :) Use the hashtag #SendCanadaToEdinburgh

Help us make our way halfway across the world... YOUR SUPPORT MEANS THE WORLD TO US!

In partnership with the Centre for Creative Learning, we are exporting Canadian creativity.

story:
Lesvos, one of the Aegean's most beautiful islands, welcomes the world this summer during the SYMBIOSIS Lesvos Arts Festival. Amid the worst refugee crisis since World War II, the SYMBIOSIS Festival will fill a crucial gap – that is, the facilitation of cultural integration of refugees. This month-long celebration in Lesvos will enable artists, speakers, locals, refugees, and visitors from around the world to celebrate multiculturalism and altruism, and promote cross-cultural exchange and dialogue. 

It is an opportunity for a diverse range of people to come together and showcase their cultures, traditions and values and to share them with each other and the world. We aim to foster a better understanding of the ever-changing local and global identities. 

                                    

The key aims of the SYMBIOSIS Festival are to:

  • Create an understanding and a connection between the local island community, the visitors, the volunteers and the refugees.

  • Give locals, refugees and international participants the chance to demonstrate their talents and express themselves in a safe, non-judgemental and welcoming community.

  • Introduce international audiences to Lesvos: one of the Mediterranean’s architecturally, naturally and culturally richest islands.

  • Introduce new models of sustainable tourism that are best-matched to Lesvos’ position on the frontlines of the refugee crisis.

Why support the SYMBIOSIS Festival?

SYMBIOSIS is filling a gap – that is, the cultural integration of refugees. It is unique as it is an opportunity for refugees, locals and internationals to spend time together as equals and not in the context of supporter and person in need. It is a way of humanising the refugees and making the existing humanitarian crisis more sustainable by inviting them to become active participants in the cultural life of the island.

What is my donation going towards?

All artists have agreed to perform at SYMBIOSIS for free.

However, there are inevitable costs in organising such a big event. Here is what your donation will go towards:

  • Workshop design and delivery at the refugee camps

  • Transportation to and from the refugee camps and between remote villages

  • Sound and light engineering

  • Equipment rental

  • Accommodation & food for our volunteers

  • Funding for administrative costs of an incorporated non-profit event

We expect a great number of people to attend the festival over THE FULL MONTH OF PROGRAMMING. If everyone who attends donates just $10 we will surely meet our fundraising goal! 

Good to know

  • The project is delivered by an all-volunteer team: we spend countless days and nights volunteering our time for this project - we believe in it, and hope you believe in it too.

  • The Festival is FREE as we want to give EVERYONE the chance to attend.
    You read right; you get to see amazing bands from around the world, participate in unique creative and movement workshops, watch a selection of independent films, attend exhibitions of invited local and international artists - all for free.

  • The festival is ONE MONTH long. Why?
    -Because we want to give people from all over the world enough time to make their way here (Australians, there are no excuses!).
    -Because we want to live ‘symbiotically’ for a while and learn from each others’ habits and cultures.
    -Because the island and its people deserve a long break to celebrate life
    -Because we want to have an active, daily presence at the refugee camps and make an impact in refugees’ lives.

  • It will give you a chance to explore the unexplored; we have discovered hidden treasures that you would never find in a travel guide.

  • You will have the chance to participate in the creation of a huge mosaic that will stay on the island - a present from the SYMBIOSIS crowd to the inhabitants of Lesvos who stood in solidarity. Imagine coming back ten years later and recognising your input on a publicly displayed piece of art...

                                   

What will SYMBIOSIS Festival include?

SYMBIOSIS Festival is a huge celebration of life and coexistence!  
Our activities include:

  • Music: World musicians and bands

  • Workshops: Creative and social-awareness workshops
    -Drama therapy, art therapy, music therapy with vulnerable children
    -Creative workshops aimed at showcasing the different cultures of the world; highlight the similarities, learn from the differences
    -Physical movement and choreography

  • Theatre performances: street performances, forum theatre, playback theatre, monologues

  • Exhibitions: painting, photography, sculpture, jewellery and ceramics

  • Panel discussions on: the arts, Lesvos's history, the refugee crisis, human rights, humanitarian aid efforts and the environment

  • Film Festival: a selection of films and documentaries on human rights and social issues

  • Games & challenges: unique opportunity to experience the outdoors, explore top-secret oases, meet and live with people from around the world

  • Food festival: try food from the Mediterranean and the Middle East, taste the local products, use the products to create your own recipe!

What makes SYMBIOSIS Lesvos Arts Festival unique is that it focuses on the cultural integration of refugees. SYMBIOSIS will support refugees through:

  • Cultural mediation: Refugees are faced with many challenges upon arrival in Europe, including a cultural shock. Successful cultural integration requires mutual knowledge and understanding between them and the local communities. We believe that artistic forms of cultural expression can create the basis for dialogue and provide a means of acceptance and appreciation of each other’s backgrounds.

  • Invitation to SYMBIOSIS: The activities will allow refugees to become involved and present their stories to the world and the society they are entering – workshops will be aimed at introducing locals to different cultures of the world, and vice versa.

                               

Can I become part of SYMBIOSIS?

Yes PLEASE! SYMBIOSIS is a community project which welcomes anyone and everyone on board – we need artists, volunteers, translators, participants and people who want to contribute to the creation of a unique atmosphere in the idyllic setting that a Greek island of the Aegean provides. Email info@symbiosisfestival.com with a couple of paragraphs explaining who you are and in what capacity you would like to get involved and a member of our team will get in touch with you within 3 days.

Join our efforts! Every penny counts! 

For updates...

www.symbiosisfestival.com 
LIKE us on Facebook
Follow us on Twitter 
Follow us on Instagram

story:
Our Story

Guess who's back! Gabriel San Roman and Carla Zarate have joined forces again to return with the Subversive Historian’s ‘Calendar of Revolt 2016’! Just like last year, the “Subversive Historian” morphs from its origin as a daily radio segment as heard for years on KPFK-Pacifica Radio in Los Angeles into 12-months of radical history! The 2016 edition comes with bolder artwork and 365 brand new subversive days in history. The Calendar of Revolt continues to focuses on the liberation struggles of workers, radicals, women, people of color, and the LGBT community throughout the history of the United States and elsewhere.

Gabriel San Roman is the “Subversive Historian” and also multimedia journalist whose work has been featured on KPFK Radio and in the OC Weekly, Latino Rebels, and online at TruthOut in addition to numerous other outlets. He’s also the author of “Venceremos: Victor Jara and the New Song Movement” published by PM Press.

Carla Zarate is the designer of the ‘Calendar of Revolt.’ Originally from Mexicali, Mexico, she was a producer, camera woman and documentary directory before becoming a part of SolArt Gallery, a collective promoting solidarity through ALL the arts in Santa Ana CA. Since then, Zarate’s been busy creating graphic design for non-profit organizations, documenting the Latin Alternative music scene, producing videos, collaborating with artists on public art.

The Impact

The Subversive Historian’s ‘Calendar of Revolt 2016' holds faithful to its mission of providing daily histories that have otherwise remained “mysteries.” It's a rhyming nod to the fact that obscuring stories of injustice and resistance to it in the United States and beyond frames establishment history. This has been on display in Tucson, Arizona and Texas before it where critical literature has been banned in the former and textbooks have been subject to ideological revisions in the latter. To hell with that, we say!

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign is primarily aimed at covering the printing costs for the Calendar of Revolt. Carla and Gabriel will be collaborating again with 1984 Printing, an Oakland based printer that suffered heavy loses in a warehouse fire earlier this year. What do you get? Aside from the knowledge and inspiration rulers 'round the world would rather you not have, check out our pledge level perks!

Other Ways You Can Help

Friends, family, comrades, and truth professors!

Help Carla and Gabriel out by promoting our campaign through word of mouth and all your social networking! Share this page on Facebook. Tweet it. Do whatever you can. Give whatever you can. Hell, go ahead and tell a reactionary conservative about our project! All your support is warmly appreciated and we won’t let you down! And remember: It’s no mystery why they conceal our people’s history! Spread the word and the truth!

Carla Zarate and Gabriel San Roman

story:
Aktionsgemeinschaft Holländisches Viertel

Wir, die Aktionsgemeinschaft Holländisches Viertel, sind ein Zusammenschluss von ansässigen Bürgern und Gewerbetreibenden des Holländisches Viertels in Potsdam und setzen uns für den Erhalt der Kultur dieses Viertels ein. In diesem Sinne planen wir saisonbegleitend verschiedene kulturelle Veranstaltungen im Holländischen Viertel. Informationen dazu erhalten Sie jederzeit hier.


Kunst im Viertel

Die Veranstaltung „Kunst im Viertel“ ist eine Idee unserer Aktionsgemeinschaft. Mit ausgefallenen Angeboten möchten wir das Holländische Viertel beleben, bereichern und zeigen, dass moderne Kunstformen in dieser historischen Kulissen ihren Raum haben. Unter dem Motto „Genießen  & Erleben“ planen wir in Zukunft auch weitere Aktionen und Veranstaltungen.

Unser erstes Projekt, welches wir innerhalb weniger Wochen geplant haben, ist ein Kunst- und Handwerkermarkt der etwas anderen Art. Am 15. und 16. August 2015 wird dieser Markt stattfinden. An diesem Wochenende gibt es jeweils von 11 bis 18 Uhr neben hochwertigen gastronomischen Angeboten viele Highlights, wie Live-Art mit Kettensägenschnitzen, Modenschauen, Schmiedekunstvorführungen und Livemusik mit Udo Lindenberg Double Exe zu erleben. Auch die vielen Geschäfte, Galerien und Restaurants des Holländischen Viertels werden sich mit Aktionen beteiligen. Als besonderer Gast wird Friedrich der Große erwartet, der standesgemäß mit der Postkutsche anreist.


Wir brauchen Ihre Unterstützung

Aus unserer Eigeninitiative ist ein Veranstaltungskonzept entstanden, welches für viel Abwechslung und schöne Momente bei den Besuchern sorgen wird. Gern würden wir zu dem Kunst- und Handwerkermarkt einen Streetart-Wettbewerb durchführen, bei dem jeder Gast sich zum Thema "Potsdam 3.0" verewigen kann. Jeder, ob Groß ob Klein kann zur Kreide greifen und sich am Wettbewerb beteiligen. Zu gewinnen gibt es diverse Gutscheine und das schönste, innovativste Bild wird mit 200,00 € prämiert.

Die international bekannte 3D-Streetart Künstlerin Christiane Jessen-Richardsen (Bild oben) wird vor Ort das Hauptbild des Streetart-Wettbewerbs gestalten.

Mit diesem Kunstprojekt möchten wir Potsdam aus einer anderen, innovativen Perspektive zeigen und warnehmbar machen. Für dieses besondere Erlebnis fehlen uns im Moment die finanziellen Mittel. Daher möchten wir probieren, auf diesem Wege Geld zu sammeln und die Finanzierung so zu ermöglichen.

Sollte der benötigte Gesamtbetrag nicht zustande kommen, freuen wir uns nichtsdestotrotz über jeden Euro und werden das Geld für ein kleineres Kunstprojekt auf dem Fest, zum Beispiel Graffittisimulationen, einsetzen.


Das haben wir bisher erreicht

Das Holländische Viertel ist bereits heute ein vielbesuchter Ort für Touristen, allerdings fehlte es bis vor kurzem an nachhaltigen Planungen und einer strukturierten Zusammenarbeit von den Bürgern und Gewerbetreibenden vor Ort. Innerhalb weniger Wochen haben wir es geschafft, uns zu organisieren, ein gemeinsames Logo und einen gemeinsamen Slogan zu entwerfen und eben die Veranstaltung "Kunst im Viertel" vorzubereiten. Für die Haushalts- und Budgetplanung der Landeshauptstadt und möglichen Sponsoren waren wir aber leider zu spät. Daher werden die Händler einen Großteil der Veranstaltung selbst finanzieren und hoffen auf weitere Unterstützung.

Unser erstes Projekt, welches wir innerhalb weniger Wochen geplant haben, ist ein
Kunst- und Handwerkermarkt der etwas anderen Art. Am 15. und 16. August 2015 wird dieser Markt stattfinden. An diesem Wochenende gibt es
jeweils von 11 bis 18 Uhr neben hochwertigen gastronomischen Angeboten viele
Highlights, wie Live-Art mit Kettensägenschnitzen, Modenschauen, Schmiedekunstvorführungen und Livemusik mit Udo Lindenberg Double Exe zu
erleben. Auch die vielen Geschäfte, Galerien und Restaurants des Holländischen Viertels werden sich mit
Aktionen beteiligen. Als
besonderer Gast wird Friedrich der Große erwartet, der standesgemäß mit der
Postkutsche anreist.

Wir brauchen Ihre Unterstützung

Aus unserer Eigeninitiative ist ein Veranstaltungskonzept entstanden, welches für viel Abwechslung und schöne Momente bei den Besuchern sorgen wird. Gern würden wir zu dem Kunst- und Handwerkermarkt einen Streetart-Wettbewerb durchführen, bei dem jeder Gast sich zum Thema "Potsdam 3.0" verewigen kann. Jeder, ob Groß ob Klein kann zur Kreide greifen und sich am Wettbewerb beteiligen. Zu gewinnen gibt es diverse Gutscheine und das schönste, innovativste Bild wird mit 200,00 € prämiert.
Die international bekannte 3D-Streetart Künstlerin Christiane Jessen-Richardsen (Bild oben) wird vor Ort das Hauptbild des Streetart-Wettbewerbs gestalten.
Mit diesem Kunstprojekt möchten wir Potsdam aus einer anderen, innovativen Perspektive zeigen und warnehmbar machen. Für dieses besondere Erlebnis fehlen uns im Moment die finanziellen 
Mittel. Daher möchten wir probieren, auf diesem Wege Geld zu sammeln und
 die Finanzierung so zu ermöglichen. 
Sollte der benötigte Gesamtbetrag nicht zustande kommen, freuen wir uns 
nichtsdestotrotz über jeden Euro und werden das Geld für ein kleineres 
Kunstprojekt auf dem Fest, zum Beispiel Graffittisimulationen, 
einsetzen.

Das haben wir bisher erreicht
Das Holländische Viertel ist bereits heute ein vielbesuchter Ort für Touristen, allerdings fehlte es bis vor kurzem an nachhaltigen Planungen und einer strukturierten Zusammenarbeit von den Bürgern und Gewerbetreibenden vor Ort. Innerhalb weniger Wochen haben wir es geschafft, uns zu organisieren, ein gemeinsames Logo und einen gemeinsamen Slogan zu entwerfen und eben die Veranstaltung "Kunst im Viertel" vorzubereiten. Für die Haushalts- und Budgetplanung der Landeshauptstadt und möglichen Sponsoren waren wir aber leider zu spät. Daher werden die Händler einen Großteil der Veranstaltung selbst finanzieren und hoffen auf weitere Unterstützung.

story:
Thanks to everyone who has supported this cause so far!  You can see more about the building and the fundraising effort at www.dbarchitect.com/BringBeauty 


Help us support Oakland seniors with local artwork!

Lakeside Senior Housing provides 92 homes for low-income and formerly homeless seniors in a brand-new building with healthy interiors, supportive services, and educational programs in Oakland. 

This campaign is to raise money to BRING BEAUTY—works by local artists—into the common areas of Lakeside Senior Housing for color, life, and inspiration. You can sponsor a specific art piece, or make a general contribution.


Sponsor this diptych by Warren Jee, for the Main Lobby Lounge

David Baker Architects is partnering with developer Satellite Affordable Housing Associates and art studio Creativity Explored to bring bright, beautiful artwork into the building. This will provide the final touch to launch this new building as a warm and welcoming community place. 

Why Art?

“It'll liven us up and make us want to get up in the morning and see life and beauty. Art is beautiful!” —Valerie, resident

“It's more than just nice to have art on the walls, it's also part of our human experience.” —Susan, resident

"I like art because it enriches people's lives and it makes people be more encouraged and not depressed." —Kat, resident


Sponsor this piece by Marilyn Wong, for the Community Room Entry 


What Art?

We have selected a wonderful suite of artworks, all by local artists, many of whom are senior citizens themselves. All funds raised will purchase, print, and install artwork in the Lakeside Senior Housing lobby, common areas, and elevator lobbies at each level. Creating a distinct visual identity for each floor, through varied color and style of artwork, helps senior residents orient themselves within the building. 

Sponsor these pieces by Cheryle Rutledge for the Second Floor Landing Lounges
(see Perks: Plum Hero 1, Plum Hero 2)

Sponsor these pieces by Vincent Jackson, for the Third Floor Landing Lounges
(see Perks: Crimson Hero 1, Crimson Hero 2)

Sponsor these pieces by Marilyn Wong, for the Fourth Floor Landing Lounges
(see Perks: Indigo Hero 1, Indigo Hero 2)

Sponsor these pieces by Tony Gomez, for the Fifth Floor Landing Lounges
(see Perks: Evergreen Hero 1, Evergreen Hero 2)


What's the Plan?

All artwork will be purchased from Creativity Explored, a San Francisco-based non-profit art gallery that supports local artists with physical and developmental disabilities. As part of our pro bono contribution, DBA will manage the process from selection through purchase, production, and installation. All of the art selected for the building has been created by local artists, many of whom are also senior citizens. 

Our partnership with Creativity Explored allows for many “wins”! 

It works like this:

  • With the money raised, we will purchase licenses for the selected artworks from Creativity Explored, directly benefiting the artists.
  • Using Creativity Explored’s high-resolution scans, Sterling Graphics will print and mount large-scale versions of the selected artworks to fill the expansive common walls of the building, maximizing the “per square foot” cost of art.
  • All donations are fully tax deductible and will be used by Satellite Affordable Housing Associates toward this proposed art collection.
Please help us support these low-income and formerly homeless seniors by surrounding them with art and beauty and sending the signal that they are important and welcome members of the community! 

You can find out more about the building and the fundraising party at www.dbarchitect.com/LakesideSenior.


Artwork from classes for residents is on display in the building lobby.

The rooftop garden program is run by City Slicker Farms.

Tai chi instruction takes place in the courtyard and on the roof deck.

story:
Manuel Báez is an innovative architect, artist, and educator in Ottawa. Manuel and architecture students from his Crossings Workshop at Carleton University are producing a unique installation highlighting the diversity of the Canadian mosaic within our city. The installation will be featured at HUB Ottawa beginning in the fall. We are fundraising to cover the costs of the installation.

What’s the installation about?

"Resonant Currents" is an expression of connection. It is a representation of the links that exist between the cultures of Canada and the world. This installation explores the parallels between disciplines - between architecture, art, the humanities and science. It is an expression of the local and global connections that happen daily in HUBs around the world.

Created with woven bands of birch plywood with wire-mesh highlights, "Resonant Currents" was inspired by intricate ethnic calligraphy, rich woven patterns and other cultural motifs.

Art that inspires innovation and community engagement.

HUB Ottawa, the future home of the installation, is a coworking space that houses a community of changemakers working to innovate for eco and social solutions to the world’s most pressing problems.

Our creative industrial space acts as a community centre where we create the conditions for hundreds of creative collisions, random introductions, experiments, idea jams and inter-disciplinary interactions every month. We believe that when our community thrives, the result is heightened creativity, new perspectives, valuable knowledge, unlikely relationships – and ultimately, ideas that change lives.

This installation will mirror the work of our community of local and global innovators, and the connections we aim to facilitate everyday at the HUB.

Why this installation matters to you:

Whether you’re someone who appreciates art, believes in the power of collaborative endeavors, or supports local artistic talent, we can all relate to the simple, yet profound vision this installation embodies. We’re asking for your support to cover material costs of this unique installation and showcase a world-class project by an architect and artist and his talented students right here in our community!

All funds raised will go directly to Manuel and his students to cover the costs of creating this installation. Our perks for donating include:

  • Tickets to the opening night party for the installation in September
  • A one month HUB membership
  • Your name engraved on a plaque to showcase your generousity in making this installation come to life

We hope you will join us in making this installation a reality. Please support our campaign to fund Resonant Currents at HUB Ottawa.

Where does your contribution go?

We believe that all Canadians can relate to the vision this installation embodies. The inclusive vision of this installation, and the nature of the connections it seeks to embody represents what we all hope to have in our lives - a sense of belonging and interconnectedness.

All funds raised will go directly to recovering the material costs of the installation. We’re asking for your support to cover these material costs of this unique installation and showcase a world-class artist right here in our community!

The ways that you can help:

Donate: Take a look at the perks we have listed below for the four donation levels. Remember that simply by donating you can become a HUB member for a month!

Help us spread the word: Share the link to this campaign and our video on Twitter, Facebook and throughout your network!

Continue to support local artists in our community: Their work is invaluable and so is our support in getting them recognized. Help the Ottawa art community thrive!

 

Who’s the Architect/Artist/Educator and what has inspired him?

Manuel A. Báez is an Associate Professor at the Carleton University Azrieli School of Architecture and Urbanism. Previously, he taught in the United States at The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art in New York City and the Rhode Island School Design in Providence, RI.

The parallels between the underlying themes of Manuel’s inter-disciplinary research and work as an educator, architect, and artist and those of HUB have motivated him to consider an installation at HUB Ottawa.

His work draws inspiration from the generative potential of the forms, structures and integrative systems generated by elemental processes that exist throughout the natural environment. Manuel’s work has been funded by such institutions as the Canada Council for the Arts, the New York Foundation for the Arts, the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, Cranbrook Academy of Art and Carleton University.

Check out Manuel’s previous works:

http://manuelbaez.pbworks.com/w/page/28543369/Architect-Artist%20Statement

TEDxCarletonU presentation:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZjUpCQFtQck&list=PL96441F832093834A&index=1

Creative Mornings Ottawa presentation:

http://vimeo.com/45668986

story:
The business of helping artists thrive


With YOUR HELP, emerging and established artists who want to paint, teach or live in Portland, Maine will find studios, class and workshop space at Still Life Studio's new location at 82 Elm St.

Portland has been designated by national and international magazines and guides as Best Foodie Town, Best Craft Beer, Best Place to Live, Best Breathable Air, Best Place to Raise a Family, Best Ocean Access, and many more "bests." We want to add "Best Environment for Working Artists." This is the beginning of our part toward that goal.

Plopped in the middle of Portland, my business, Still Life Studio, is undergoing a metamorphosis...from 8 successful years of painting and teaching in a collaborative art space (at the beloved Running with Scissors  ) to my own downtown Portland studio that also caters to the needs of other artists. In addition to me, two local artists/creatives will find new studios, and visiting artists will be able to use the teaching space to give their own classes in small groups or intimate class sizes of approximately 8-10.

Artists from other regions of New England and the U.S. can rent space for a weekend, bring their followers or students, and teach a class, while enjoying the amazing food, cultural, and outdoor exploration options that Portland is known for.

The new space will be fun and funky, reflecting the eclectic mix of its West Bayside surroundings, only 3 blocks from downtown.

About Adria Moynihan Rusk (that’s me)

I’m a native of Maine with a colorful palette of travel to other cultures and institutions under my belt. (I know that’s mixing metaphors, but I’m a creative.) I lived in Oregon for 7 years, and until 2009, my “day jobs” included Project Manager at a trade show booth company and Data Entry Specialist at a grocery chain. I know those jobs seem really important, but I moved on and moved up. Artists (and actors and musicians) will do anything to support their passion. But just so you know, this also happened…

My art and business background

  • BA Painting Portland State University, Portland, OR, 2007

  • Assets for Artists/MASS MoCA Matched Savings Grant Winner 2014

  • Many business planning and finance courses with CEI and SCORE

We are raising $12,500 to convert the space

My own money and in-kind donations are matching the Indiegogo $12.5K campaign for contributions. Here are where our expenses are going:

About half of the build-out expenditures will help with creating the additional studios: mine and two others, for rent to artists. The other half will go toward rehabbing the teaching space. Income from the rental studios will support the ability to keep the teaching space open and affordable. When the whole enterprise is well on its feet, I want to offer gathering space and classes to neighborhood and community residents who can't afford to pay full price.

If we do not reach the full goal of $12.5K, what we do raise will go proportionately toward the sectors highlighted above. If we reach a higher goal, it will be used to fund projects that are currently on hold such as the installation of track lighting, or starting a scholarship fund. 

What will you get for your donation? From regular updates and photos about the project to your name listed as a contributor, to a print of one of my paintings, to - at the top end - a commissioned painting of the subject of your choice or a summer week at a Maine lakeside cottage. Wow! 

The Impact

For a number of years, there have been few new artist studios created on Portland's peninsula. Especially those with street access and easy parking. We're adding 3, including mine.

Artists bring beauty and meaning to the world. Most work a "day job" to get by. The availability of a teaching studio-for-hire gives artists access to a favored source of income: teaching their version of art. I know, because I've been doing it for 8 years. For those who don't teach but need space to spread out for a day or a weekend, we can offer that too. 

I've been saving my money. I've been consulting with business experts. I've had a dozen generous volunteers doing some very nasty jobs. My family and friends are with me. Now I need you.

Risks & Challenges

The good thing about this business model is that the rent of 2 extra studios in the space will subsidize a substantial portion of the monthly lease. That said, risks may include:

  • Slow response to the rental of the studios or teaching space
  • Uncovering a major construction problem
  • Social media, email, and word-of-mouth marketing not being enough to distribute the offers of space and classes.

Yet, I already have inquiries from artists who are looking for studios and/or want to teach. I have done my due diligence on the building, though it's old and it's possible we may find "things." 

I've consulted with the best start-up advisors. I have my financial projections spelled out, including contingencies. My contractor is already at work. I've set my intentions and am crossing my fingers. (Can't hurt.)

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please, get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Email your pals, your colleagues, known givers, art collectors, galleries, artists, newbie painters, your parents, and your third cousin, who used to date an artist and really still loves her. Let them know about this opportunity. The incentives are great!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools. Aside from the direct introductions, social media will be my best bet for campaign success.

And that's all there is to it. We can do this. Right? Please donate now!
