story:
Short Summary

Hello Friends! My name is Ania. I am a mother of four wonderful kids. I am a Baha'i. I weave in spiritual teachings into my daily activities with my children. I noticed that all children are naturally drawn in a powerful way to the animal world. I created the six posters in this campaign to hang in my own home as teaching tools for the kids. The posters were very popular and many were bought by my acquaintances. 

At bedtime, or during morning devotions, I thought this would make a wonderful prayer book for parents and children to enjoy together.

This prayer book has been approved for publication by the National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Canada. 

With your help these beautiful images and inspiring Writings can find their way to the homes and hearts of the world! 

Animals are very special to me and this prayer book will help attract children's hearts to be kind to the animal world. In the Baha'i Writings we are encouraged to show the utmost kindness to animals. With the animals in this book as inspiration, we can educate our children to develop the capacities of compassion and kindness to all life.

Inspirational Quotes

"He should show kindness to animals, how much more unto his fellow man" - Baha'u'llah

"Therefore one must be very considerate towards animals and show greater kindness to them than to man. Educate the children in their infancy in such a way that they may become exceedingly kind and merciful to the animals. If an animal is sick they should endeavor to cure it; if it is hungry, they should feed it; if it is thirsty, they should satisfy its thirst; if it is tired, they should give it rest." - Abdu'l-Baha

"To the blessed animals, however, the utmost kindness should be exercised: the more the better it will be." - Abdu'l-Baha

"Unless ye must,
Bruise not the serpent in the dust,
How much less wound a man,
And if ye can,
No ant should ye alarm,
Much less a brother harm."  - Abdu'l-Baha

What We Need & What You Get

I need $3000 Canadian to print 500 board books. There will be 16 pages with full colour photographs. The six posters you see in this campaign will be included as well as 10 new photos and quotations! You will see a lion, tiger, sea turtle, rhino and more!

As a contributor, you have the option of receiving photographs, books, posters or a custom made poster just for you!

If this campaign doesn't raise all the funds, I hope to be able to fund the remainder myself. 

The Impact

This book of prayers and spiritual Writings will create opportunities for parents and children have a morning or evening cuddle and nourish their spirits. Toddlers and children of all ages will enjoy the beautiful photos and as the child grows the Writings will provide moments for reflection and spiritual growth.

We have a limited number of prayer books for children in Canada in the Baha'i Community. This prayer book captures children's fascination with animals as well as offering spiritual guidance. I am certain it will create lush teaching moments and your children will anticipate prayer time with joyful hearts!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, no problem! Maybe you can share the campaign with your friends and contacts... Thank you so much!

Short Summary

We're a bunch of students in our final year of a 3D animation & CGI program needing to show our final films!

What We Need & What You Get

We need money to put towards booking the theater, and hosting a cool after party for friends, family and members of the industry.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate (or have donated and want to help even more!) spread the word about our campaign!

story:
Short Summary

We're the senior class of the Craft and Material Studies department at University of the Arts in Philadelphia.  We are a group of dedicated craftspeople currently working unfathomably hard to produce cohesive bodies of work.  On Friday, May 1st, we will open the exhibition that allows us to share that hard work with the public.  We are responsible for putting this show together from beginning to end.  This campaign will support every aspect of that show and ensure its success.


What We Need & What You Get

The things we need in order to put together the show and their costs add up quickly.  The most important aspect of the exhibition is that it makes a lasting positive impression.  We achieve this by putting together a catalog of our work.  This gives us something to put forth as we transition into the professional artist community.  In addition to the catalogs, we are also responsible for:

  • Materials for pedestals, partitions, and other displays
  • Catering for the opening reception
  • Hired security
  • Postcards and invitations to get the word out
We spend tremendous amounts of time in our studios to produce this work.  The funds we raise don't offset the cost of making, but they will allow us the benefit of learning how to budget and plan an exhibition of this magnitude.

The Impact

Your contribution matters.  This exhibition not only prepares us for the challenges of putting together professional gallery shows, but also for the stress of raising funds to do so.  Art is an important part of culture; as craftspeople, we make valuable contributions to society; we shape that culture and its history.  Think about how identifiable periods in history are: does the word 'Victorian' draw up a certain image?  How about 'The Roaring 20s'?  We can picture these historical movements because of the art and craft that came out of them.  This is what we are doing today.  We are striving to bring craftsmanship back into the public eye.  This exhibition is just a small part of that, but it is a centerpiece of the Philadelphia crafts community each year.  Your contribution helps to illuminate the importance of art to the general public and helps to keep events like this free to attend.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you may not be in a position to contribute.  Of course, we will spout the old adage 'every dollar counts!'  However, should you be unable to make a donation, we would be very grateful if you could help make some noise about our campaign.

Indiegogo has those very convenient little tools at the bottom to make it easy for you to share this on all of your social media platforms!  Please just hit 'share' and spread the word so we can spread the word and gain steam to plan an exciting, successful exhibition.


And please... join us on May 1st to celebrate our work!

story:
For the third year in a row, Center for Creative Works will participate in the Outsider Art Fair in New York City in January 2020.  

This internationally-renowned exhibition is a major showcase for self-taught, visionary, folk, and outsider art, and it is an honor to be asked to participate. The CCW booth will feature new works on paper by Doug Tan, sculpture by Cindy Gosselin, and drawings by Tim Quinn, with additional works on paper by Clyde Henry, Brandon Spicer-Crawley, Jenny Cox, David Schumckler, Jenny Garrity, Eric Stewart, and Olubunmi Ojo.

The Outsider Art Fair gives our artists unprecedented exposure to curators, collectors, arts professionals, and art lovers from around the world. Bringing their work to this elite audience is a major endeavor for us, and we need your support to make it happen!

We're raising $4000 to get ten CCW artists to NYC

To participate in the OAF we need funding for the following:

  • Professional framing & preparation for the artwork included
  • Transportation for staff and artists to NYC
  • Outsider Art Fair booth fees

For your donation, you'll receive a limited-edition inkjet print of an original artwork featured in the 2020 Outsider Art Fair,  a limited-edition CMYK screen printed tote bag with an image of a Cindy Gosselin sculpture OR a portfolio of all ten OAF 2020 prints.

Limited-edition prints by the following artists available:

  • Jenny Cox
  • Clyde Henry
  • Jenny Garrity
  • Cindy Gosselin
  • Olubunmi Ojo
  • Tim Quinn
  • David Schmuckler
  • Brandon Spicer-Crawley
  • Eric Stewart
  • Doug Tan

*All donations made before Friday, December 20th will receive their perks by Christmas Eve*

 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Why Support Press Fest?

We believe art can change the world! By supporting Press Fest, you are helping keep art in Austin and support the zine/comics scene which is filled with working artists who create content to share their personal stories, inspire others, send compelling messages to make positive change and so much more. This is also a chance for children to discover ways to express themselves and discover their gifts and talents. Do it for the kids! 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $1500 to pay off the services to make Press Fest happen as well as supplies needed for the awesome workshops we have in store. These expenses really add up and this is where we have to reach out for support. 

Anything you can contribute helps! We understand that we all have our own finances to take care of, but if you are able to give $30 or more, you'll get a rad shirt from us as a big thank you! Beautifully printed local by the awesome folks in Raw Paw. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you absolutely cannot donate, there are other ways you can help!

Please share our campaign on your social media! Spreading the word can make a huge impact and the more people who know about Press Fest , the more support we can receive. Our goal is to grow this festival with more artists, more zines/comics, more workshops and more attendants! But we can't do it without your help!

story:
Inverse Performance Art Festival is a three day festival of performance art located in Northwest Arkansas on March 30 - April 1, 2017. Organized and curated by Cynthia Post Hunt of Fayetteville, AR and Emma Saperstein of San Luis Obispo, CA, the festival seeks to elevate the medium of performance art and immerse residents in the performative practice through workshops, lectures, panel discussions and open rehearsals. Including artists recognized on local, national, and international platforms, this festival will host a variety of performances with diversity of content and duration. Inverse is educational and collaborative, working with students, emerging artists, and professional artists to exchange ideas and form new connections. 

Locations and Dates:

Thursday, March 30

University of Arkansas Jim and Joyce Faulkner Performing Arts Center

Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art

Friday, March 31

Foxhole Public House

21c Museum Hotel Bentonville

Saturday, April 1

University of Arkansas Art & Design District

Feast Gallery

The artists are housed by members of the Fayetteville community, creating new relations and deepened connections between visitors and locals. By drawing on the resources and generosity of our venues, and building on established relationships with many individuals and institutions who are actively participating in the growth of the arts in NWA, we hope that we can foster broader engagement, participation, and support for the arts for people of all diversities of race, class, age, and gender.

In its second year, Inverse is expanding and evolving. We are constantly seeking innovative ways to share our vision with the world. We need $5,000 to help make this work. Thanks to our generous community, we are able to provide local hosts for each artist’s stay. Our goal for additional funding is to cover travel, materials and documentation for all artists involved in this year’s festival. $5,000 will cover the travel of artists from Japan, New York, Minnesota, Texas, Oklahoma, Missouri, Georgia, Illinois, and Massachusetts. It will cover photo and video documentation for all the artists. And it will cover the cost of materials - from planks of wood to astro turf. The money we raise goes straight into the pockets of the artists who have created these important, challenging, and beautiful works to share with you.

We see this festival as a contribution to the world. One of substantial, thought provoking work. Inverse provides an opportunity for performance artists at all levels to collaborate. It introduces new work and new ideas into the local community. And it is constantly working to build bridges to communities around the world. Last year, in just four short months, we introduced a festival that impacted over 650 people. This year, we hope to at least double that.

For more information please visit www.inverseperformanceartfestival.org

story:
About the Exhibit

Art for All Spaces is breaking new ground with its boldest exhibition to date: The Monument as Art: Commemoration and Controversy.  We need your support to fund this innovative exhibition at the CityArts Factory in Orlando Florida. The aim of the exhibit is to recognize the monument as an object of influence in the public sphere and to generate dialogue about the role of the monument in contemporary society. This is the first art exhibit to date to address the recent controversies surrounding public monuments.  We expect a terrific turnout and show of support!  The public is invited to attend the opening reception on Thursday, April 19th from 6-9 PM at the CityArts Factory in Orlando Florida.  A secondary opening featuring brief gallery talks by local scholars and professionals will take place at CityArts Factory on May 3, 2018 from 6:00-9:00 pm. 

The Inspiration 

Monuments are commanding public attention like never before, from the near daily removal of confederate-era statues to the hotly contested reversal of national monument protections. The controversy surrounding monuments in the United States and abroad is a testament to their power and importance in the public sphere.  The word ‘monument’ derives from the Latin monumentum, which can be translated as ‘something that reminds.’ Monuments remind us that we cannot run from history, however disgraceful it may be. But do we really want such reminders in public spaces, and should the oppressive symbolism of certain historical monuments go unchallenged? Should new monuments reflecting contemporary values, challenges and concerns replace those reflecting the values of a by-gone era? How are visual artists responding to the many questions and conflicts generated by monuments, past and present? 

The Monument as Art: Commemoration and Controversy takes on these challenging issues.  The exhibition will feature artists’ responses to monuments, past, present and future. Exhibited works will include concept sketches and maquettes of proposed monuments, as well as works addressing existing public statues of historical figures, national monuments, ancient monuments, digital, ephemeral, and non-traditional expressions of remembrance.

What we need

Art for All Spaces is seeking to raise $2,000 in contributions to produce this exhibit.  Major expenses include rental of gallery space, payment to gallery assistants to install the show, payment to guest speakers, catering, production of posters, marketing and other miscellaneous costs.

Are you a fan of any of the following artists?  Samantha Shumaker, Danny Rock, Diego Ocampa, Jessica King, Bonnie Sprung, Scotty Culpepper, Linda Brant, Marsha Debroske, Doris Smart, Patricia Byron, Cathy Hempel, Scott Fraizer, Tr3, Parker Sketch, Josh Garrick, Janae Corrado, Peter Forster,Richard Reep, Kayla Prommersberger, Paul Vicente ,Natasha Schaidt. Saulius Jankaskaus, Irma Kirveilne as well as students from Lake Highland Preparatory School!  Did you know that your contribution directly supports these artists? With your support, participating artists are able to show their work without having to pay a submission fee.  

Please help by giving any amount ($5.00 or more) to fund this important endeavor. 

Why support Art for All Spaces?

Art for All Spaces produces quality exhibits that focus not only on visual appeal and revenue generation but also on education, learning, dialogue and interaction. ­ Galleries and exhibition spaces in the Orlando, Florida area have traditionally been reluctant to produce exhibitions that challenge viewers to consider the sometimes thorny interface between contemporary social issues and visual art. Art for All Spaces has an impressive track record of developing thought-provoking exhibits that generate dialogue and community engagement.

Our Track Record

Our track record speaks for itself. For the past five years, Art for All Spaces has been hosting exhibits at the CityArts Factory in Orlando.  These shows have included:

  • I Believe (2013): An extraordinary exhibit pairing poetry with visual art and featuring a viewer’s choice award.   
  • Reviving the Ancients (2014): Exploring connections between the ancient past and the present, this show featured interpretive talks by three guest speakers from local colleges and universities at the secondary opening.  
  • Eureka! The Moment When Art and Science Collide (2016): In this exhibit, artists showcased work involving the many fortuitous intersections between art and science
  • Theatrix! (2017): The theatrical aspects of life and art were featured in this exhibit, along with a special performance by Phantasmagoria at the secondary opening.

How You Can Help

Our goal is to offer professional, emerging and student artists the opportunity to exhibit work addressing the role of monuments in contemporary society, and to produce a one-of-a-kind educational exhibit that promotes community learning, dialogue and exchange.   You can help us accomplish our goal by making a contribution.  The success of this campaign depends on many small contributions. You can also help by sharing this campaign with others who love the arts and want to help make The Monument as Art: Commemoration and Controversy a reality.  


Thank you!  Your patronage is much appreciated.

*All donation by March 12 are guaranteed to be in printed promotional material, donations after will be on online promotionals.

Our goal is to offer professional, emerging and student artists the opportunity to exhibit work addressing the role of monuments in contemporary society, and to produce a one-of-a-kind educational exhibit that promotes community learning, dialogue and exchange.   You can help us accomplish our goal by making a contribution.  The success of this campaign depends on many small contributions. You can also help by sharing this campaign with others who love the arts and want to help make The Monument as Art: Commemoration and Controversy a reality.  
Thank you!  Your patronage is much appreciated.
*All donation by March 12 are guaranteed to be in printed promotional material, donations after will be on online promotionals.

story:
We need you! To help weary citizens!

All of our benches are getting a full overhaul. We want to make the playa more accessible for disabled and tired citizens. And we want it to be a comfortable and beautiful experience.

 

Money raised will go into the travel, lights and batteries, and upkeep of the benches.

story:
Donations through this campaign are NOT tax deductible. Tax deductible donations can be made in the USA through our fiscal sponsor, the Black Rock Arts Foundation, or in New Zealand through direct donations into the Temple for Christchurch Trust bank account. Please contact us or click here for more information.

The Temple for Christchurch

The Temple for Christchurch is a community mental health initiative based on the Temple at Burning Man in the Unites States. It is driven by the need for emotional healing in Christchurch after the prolonged upheaval and stress caused by the Canterbury earthquakes which have shaken the city for the past two years.

We are building the Temple on a central city site where once finished it will be opened to the public who will be invited to write their earthquake experiences on its’ walls. After two weeks it will be de-constructed, taken out of the city, reconstructed, and ceremonially burned.

Who's involved?

This is a project of the Temple for Christchurch Trust and involves several core members of the International Arts Megacrew (builders of the Temple of Transition at Burning Man 2011) and Kiwiburn (New Zealand's regional Burning Man event).

Why donate?

By donating, you are helping us gift the Temple experience to a large group of people who are in need of the healing that it has to offer. Everyone in Christchurch has their own story to tell. The earthquakes were a constant threat, they just kept coming, and most people have not been able to deal with the trauma that these events have left behind. Emotional healing has been set aside as survival becomes priority number one. We hope that through this process we can offer people a way to deal with these emotions and to begin moving on with life.

Where's the money going?

All money raised through this campaign will go to the Temple for Christchurch Trust which is a registered charity in New Zealand. As a registered charity, 100% of the money raised must be put towards the Trust’s charitable purpose.

The money will be used to fund core resources needed to build the Temple, including:

  • Structural timber for the subframe.
  • Vehicle costs for collecting demolition timber.
  • Nails, screws and nail plates.
  • Saw blades and other consumables.
  • Foundations to hold the structure down.
  • Transporting the Temple to the burn site.
  • Consent and permit fees.

Other ways you can help

If you can't afford to donate to our campaign you can still help:

  • Like and then share us on Facebook.
  • Follow us and tweet about us on Twitter.
  • Email your personal network about what we're doing.

There are many ways you can get involved with this project other than giving to this campaign: this is a community project and we will need a community to come together to make it happen.

Check out our get involved section on our website for the latest details.

About the Temple for Christchurch

The Temple for Christchurch rendered into the build site.

The design

The Temple design is based on the seismic data taken from the Heathcote Valley Station during the February 22 earthquake, the largest and most damaging of the earthquakes to hit Christchurch. These waveforms inspired the shape and dimensions of the structure, with the central line of cones corresponding to peaks in the acceleration readout, while the shape of the waves reaching out from the centre are taken from the velocity. The finished structure will be approximately 40m long, 25m wide, and will reach 6.3m at it highest point. This creates a visual interpretation of the earthquake itself.

Building materials

The pile of demolition wood used to collect materials for the Temple.

The Temple will be clad with recycled wood gathered from city-wide demolition sites. With so many houses and other buildings being demolished there is no shortage of materials to be used. After collection, the wood is de-nailed and then ripped into slices to be used as cladding.

The cladding will be placed upon a structural subframe which has been designed by engineers. This subframe will be made from a mix of recycled and new timber.

Project progress

We are currently building the Temple on the old Convention Centre site. The convention centre, like many buildings around it, has been demolished due to damage caused during the earthquakes. What is left now is a large gravel-covered vacant site; a blank canvas on which the Temple will be built.

Who we are

The Temple for Christchurch project is created entirely by volunteers. Members of it's core team include four of the organisers of Kiwiburn, New Zealand's regional Burning Man event; several temple builders from Kiwiburn, Burning Seed (Australia) and Burning Man (USA); and “Kiwi” Chris Hankins, the project lead for the Temple of Transition at Burning Man 2011.

Why the Temple for Christchurch is needed

Since September 4, 2010 the Canterbury region in New Zealand has experienced over 10,000 earthquakes. More than 40 of these were magnitude 5.0 or over and four were over magnitude 6.0. It has been a seemingly endless series of shakes and every time we thought we were getting back on our feet, another quake hit and we were brought back to square one.

The worst earthquake occurred on February 22, 2011. Although it only registered as a magnitude 6.3 , the energy it released was huge. On the Mercalli intensity scale the quake measured 9 out of 12 making it one of the largest earthquakes ever measured near an urban centre. Several buildings collapsed and 185 people died on this tragic day.

As a result of these series of quakes , large parts of the central city have been severely damaged with estimates as high as 80% of it needing to be demolished. Thousands of homes have been physically destroyed and nearly 7000 more are on land that has been determined to be uninhabitable by the New Zealand government. Families have been displaced and communities destroyed.

Most of the central city was immediately cordoned off after February 22 and large parts are still cordoned off to this day; it's been like that for over two years. We are only just starting to move into the rebuild stage. Held up by insurance companies and bureaucratic problems, thousands of people are still living in damaged homes. It's no surprise that the region has the highest anti-depressant prescription rate in the country. There has been an immensely prolonged disruption of daily life and many people are suffering from post traumatic stress.

Needless to say, life has been tough in Christchurch.

story:
Short Summary

OmniArts nebraska is a non-profit company whose mission is based in three intertwined, unique interactions with its community: artistic, economic, social. 

  • Artistic - to enrich and foster creativity in the community and the region through collaboration and outreach programs by creating fully-integrated pieces of art and the utilization of four main artistic disciplines (literature, visual art, music and performance). 
  • Economic - to provide a viable income to local and regional artists as well as to stimulate and contribute to the local economy.
  • Social - To enlighten, educate, and inspire empathy and open-heartedness in the community and region by creating performances where audiences have a shared, communal, and cathartic experience.


What We Need & What You Get

OmniArts nebraska's production of "Sunday in the Park with George" seeks tax deductible donations for the following:

  • Performers, technicians
  • Music Director, musicians, actors  
  • Set design/designer, costume construction 
  • Lighting/sound equipment, management 

The Impact

OmniArts nebraska is offering a new voice for local artists. Through a non-profit sector, the goal is to stimulate not only an interest in creative projects that serve the community, but to also contribute to economic needs of artists and local businesses.

As we celebrate the close of our second season with plans for an even bigger third season, reaching out to and collaborating with new communities on large scale musicals and plays, we will continue to grow and become even more sustainable, 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways to contribute 

  • Attendance is a great way to show your support. The show runs October 11th-12th & the 17th-19th at Pershing Center Exhibition Hall in Lincoln, Ne. For ticket information, see the OmniArts homepage: http://omniartsnebraska.org/ 

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Who are we:

We are Frida Alvinzi and Raisa Veikkola, a creative partnership called ‘Theatre of Dolls’ and are based in London. We produce four-dimensional art pieces, using puppets as storytellers and our bodies as sculptural landscapes, creating the illusion that alternative realities are alive. We handcraft all the puppets, costumes and sets using mainly recycled materials and found objects from nature as media. We have worked together for six years and have created seven productions so far. You can view our previous work here.

We have received a great reception from our performances and have performed in venues such as Tate Modern, Barbican and Victoria & Albert Museum and also in galleries, festivals and events worldwide.

 

The project:

We want to stage Dolls of Love, a production investigating the concept of love; from the myth of the origin of love in Plato’s Symposium, to the definition and universal meaning of the concept. The narrative, which will be mainly told by puppets and dolls, is loosely based on the story of Cupid and Psyche, but the core of the performance is to create a visual poem that we will be physically part of. We are using the ideas of Russian dolls and dolls houses as visual references for the costumes and sets.

This piece is aimed at an adult audience and it will be 40 minutes long. We are currently on the production stage of the project and want to take it on tour from November through all of next year and perform it in venues across the UK, Europe and U.S.A. 

 

What we would like you to fund:

We are looking for funding to cover some of our production costs; mainly for the costumes, sets and equipment, and the film and soundtrack production that is incorporated in the performance. Creating each production is a painstaking process as we handcraft every element of it, from every puppet to the costume, sets and sound. This production is our most ambitions project yet so any sum is extremely helpful.

Thank you so much for your support.

theatreofdolls.com

story:
"Teddy Tedholm is rapidly gaining recognition as one of the most exciting new talents in modern dance. “Urban Deity” creates the traditions of a new religion, fusing simple ideas with the complexity of 21st century living. An explosive, meticulous, immersive atmosphere of new and old...with a smirk.."


I (Teddy Tedholm) was recently invited to present a new 45-minute work as part of the Take Root Series at the Green Space.

"Urban Deity" is the title of the piece and will be like nothing you've ever seen before!

Dancers include Emma Portner, Kelsey Ludwig, Teddy Tedholm, Amanda Kmett'Pendry, Ellena Takos and more to be announced!

 

I am trying to raise money for things like costumes, rehearsal space rental, and possibly even paychecks for dancers! Any amount helps so feel free to contribute whatever you can! If you have any questions just email teddytedholm@yahoo.com

story:
Hi, my name is Amy Leggin and I am a visual artist living in Baltimore City, Maryland.  I graduated from the Maryland Institute College of Art in 2008 where I received a BFA in painting.  Since graduating, I have been working on a series of onsite outdoor paintings as well as a number of landscape-inspired abstract pieces.

 

Painting on Location

            I have always drawn inspiration for my artwork from my passion for the outdoors and exterior landscapes. As an avid hiker, I try to spend as much time outdoors as possible.  My on-site paintings are direct reflections of my experiences in and with nature.

            When I am hiking or camping, I bring my supplies along to create paintings and drawings of my surroundings.  Usually, I wonder around the woods exploring the creeks and riverbeds until I find a solitary place to paint.  This process of exploration is quite meditative and the act of drawing or painting the specific location allows me the time to sit and reflect within the space.  Although it is sometimes troublesome to carry an easel, canvases, and painting supplies while climbing over rocks and through trails, I enjoy the process.  The challenge makes the trek even more worthwhile.

         I take similar walks in the city where I have experimented with a variety of media including painting, printmaking and video.  At first I struggled to find inspiration in the city environment until I realized what an interesting relationship I had been witnessing between the urban and natural landscapes.  Since recognizing this fascinating juxtaposition, I have found myself exploring the city and the wilderness as much as possible, finding solitary space to paint, photograph, or film these environments.  It is the process of the walk and the exploration that is the backbone of my work.

        Over the last few years, I had the opportunity to explore and travel in Arizona, Colorado, and the Canyonlands of Utah. These places struck an emotive vein within me.  Backpacking, hiking, and painting in landscapes of catcti, canyons, and unbroken horizons inspired me to create new works on a greater scale and higher level than I was able to do back home. Ever since these perspective broadening experiences, I have sought out opportunities to return to the West. 

 

Landscape Inspired Abstraction

           An important aspect of my creative process comes after my exploration of outdoor space.  Once I have stood, sat, climbed, descended, observed scenes, recognized smells, and felt breezes, I return to my studio space with a clear sensory memory of my recent experience.  I then use highly expressive motions to create and translate the memory of my experience that now exists within my psyche into a visual manifestation.

           This after-image has been really important to my work because I can see the reflections of the purity of nature as well as those of my closer surroundings; the dismal parts of a city, the litter and dirt, the homeless and the addicted.  Our societal relationship with nature and the man-made world has always been a strange and dynamic relationship. 

 

Teaching

           Since my graduation I have been fortunate to work with a number of great students and instructors at the Griffin Art Center in Frederick, Maryland.  At the Griffin I teach children’s art classes on the basics of drawing and painting, and elementary techniques for abstract painting.  I also work at Rivers Edge Learning Center, a pre-school and day-care where I am the regular substitute teacher.  Both of these teaching situations have been really beneficial for me.  I enjoy working with children and I feel that while I teach them new things, they tend to also teach me.

 

Glacier National Park, Artist In Residence

          Glacier National Park is one of the largest and most intact ecosystems in North America.  It was the world’s first International Peace Park, created when Wateron Lakes Park in Canada and Glacier National Park in Montana joined in 1932. This monumental park is home to more than 700 lakes, dozens of glaciers, and a plethora of wildlife.

           Every year the park staff selects two artists to live in the park and make work as a reflection of their time spent in Glacier.  I am proud to have been selected as the artist-in-residence for August 2013.  I am very eager and excited to have the time and space to quietly reflect and create within this effervescent landscape.  I am hoping that by creating work that reflects the pure beauty of this space, I can raise awareness about Glacier and its importance to the natural world.

           While in the residency, I will participate in a number of public programs that include painting demonstrations and informational sessions with children and other park-goers about artists and their relationship to the park.  After the residency I will make a presentation in my hometown where I will talk about my experiences and present my work.  I am hoping that my experience can highlight the importance of preserving this natural place and sustaining its thriving eco-system.

 

Why I need your help!

           In order for me to participate in this residency, I need to be physically and mentally prepared.  I will be living in a small cabin that the park has provided for me.  Aside from the cabin, I need to provide all of my other supplies: food, gear, painting/drawing materials and transportation.  I am going to begin my trip almost two weeks in advance to make the long haul across the country from Maryland to Northern Montana.  I am in need of certain colors of paints that I have been unable to afford, new painting surfaces, sketchbooks, and possibly some of my other living costs such as some food and water.  I would deeply appreciate your help in preparing me for this amazing experience by making a donation to my site.  I am sincerely grateful for your time and generosity, and I look forward to sharing my journey with you.

 

Thank you!!!

           In order for me to participate in this residency, I need to be physically and mentally prepared.  I will be living in a small cabin that the park has provided for me.  Aside from the cabin, I need to provide all of my other supplies: food, gear, painting/drawing materials and transportation.  I am going to begin my trip almost two weeks in advance to make the long haul across the country from Maryland to Northern Montana.  I am in need of certain colors of paints that I have been unable to afford, new painting surfaces, sketchbooks, and possibly some of my other living costs such as some food and water.  I would deeply appreciate your help in preparing me for this amazing experience by making a donation to my site.  I am sincerely grateful for your time and generosity, and I look forward to sharing my journey with you.
 
Thank you!!!

story:
A quick look at how we bring color and life to our community through art!


Update: Thank you! With 63% of our goal reached, we can build our art center! We've already purchased and received the connecting hubs for our dome. We can also buy art supplies and host regular community art events for one year. We still need your support for building storage/furniture, our startup office expenses, garden setup and overhead charges. Only ONE WEEK left to contribute and share our campaign link: igg.me/at/sankalpaart!


Sankalpa facilitates insight, healing and connection through art. Our art therapy programs serve as a bridge between village youth and women in south India, the international community of Auroville, and beyond. 

Your contributions will help us erect and maintain a 30' diameter geodesic dome as our art center. It will allow us to expand our team and facilitate more art therapy sessions, community art events, and host visiting student groups, specialists and collaborators. Here we can develop a curriculum to share with teachers, parents, counselors and others who might benefit from art therapy.

Establishing this base for our work will ensure that art can touch the lives of at least 300 individuals in the following year. Most importantly, the quality of each interaction will deepen within this safe and supportive space.

Give & Receive

Our $6,000 USD goal will fund the following:

With gratitude for your contributions, we are offering a variety of handwritten or handmade items including a postcard for $10; or an intention pouch for $25, each which is uniquely embroidered and includes a written message inside. There are original items like art from the video above, and a collaborative art sari hand-painted by women in our programs! Several of these are also pilot products we are developing as part of a sustainable business model.

In case we raise less than $6,000, the dome is the priority, followed by art supplies, community art events, startup office expenses, storage and furniture. Funds can also be gradually raised through programs in the space.

The Impact

The range of potential benefits for participants in our programs:

• Increased self-esteem, self-worth and overall empowerment
• Non-verbal communication, storytelling through imagery
• Processing and release of emotions, healing of trauma, transformation
• Exploration of identity, self-awareness through group interaction
• Development of original self-expression, imagination, spontaneity
• Improvement of concentration, and balancing through relaxation and play!

In the last four years, we have worked in three existing village centers to learn more about applying art therapy training in this cultural context. Through careful study and integration of ancient traditional Indian arts, and partnerships with existing programs, a promising foundation has formed.


We chose a geodesic dome for the unique holding environment which supports deeper psychological processes and circle work, while also being physically easier to manifest. It will rest on a short mud-brick wall, giving ample space for movement, exhibition and storage within a circular structure. The connecting hubs are sourced from the US, paired with local pipes to keep costs low. The covering will be a mixture of local and recycled materials, ensuring water/moisture do not enter but that light/air can enter easily.

Recently, our idea for a mobile Art Cart was fully funded, and is soon to be launched as a form of outreach for wide-reaching participation and expression in nearby villages and Auroville. A second annual funded community art event, Art Break Day, is also happening on September 5th.

Sankalpa is a Sanskrit word for intention, affirmation, willpower and determination. We are continuously inspired to persevere, no matter what, by so many resilient survivors that have crossed our paths in this work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Be a bridge. Join us in making this dream possible and even if you cannot contribute to this art center, please share the campaign far and wide! 

Share the campaign link: http://igg.me/at/sankalpaart

Follow us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/sankalpajourneys

Share your Sankalpa (intention) with us on Twitter: @SankalpaArt. #MySankalpa is to use art as a tool to heal and empower.

Nandri! Shukriya! Thank you!

story:
Dragon Con

I don't need $500!

I really want to go!

  • I'm Chayce.
  • I really want to go to Dragon Con but i can't. I need money!
  • i'm willing to wait one year to go.

All I need is 45 dollars

  • Even dollar works!
  • Thanks to everybody who donates :D

story:
indieTHI3VES™ noun 1./ˌində'/THēvēs/ - a thought-provoking label & brand that uses ART from the independent spirit of thieves who believe in the intrinsic desire for greatness inside of each individual that can be shown through visual, auditory, & performance arts & through those means, heal the ills of the world brought on by socio-economic pressures...curse the darkness or light a candle

The fundraising goal for this project is twofold; part admissions fee for the Master's of Fine ARTs Film Program at SCAD (Savannah College of ART & Design) & part funds to keep producing ART through indieTHI3VES™

indieTHI3VES™ was created because we got tired of begging people to let us get on a song, record something or listen to what we had to say, and in the rare instance that they did listen they didn’t understand it because we refuse to make dumb, unintelligible noise. Being  tech kids & children of the digital age, we knew creating a digital presence that could & would transform into a real force for mental elevation would not be hard, only tedious. Coming up we can remember having some type of recorder with us all the time, whether it was a camera or a voice recorder or a notepad...we wanted to hold memories forever because we don’t have too many of them that are worth holding onto. Our creator recently graduated from an HBCU with a Bachelor of ARTs Film Degree where he learned how to more effectively tell stories because we believe the stories & ART of indieTHI3VES™ can & will change the world. If the Mass Media can promote violence, death destruction, idiocracy & hard drug lifestyle’s (whether you want to admit it or not, the media controls everything you see, hear, feel, & ultimately think) maybe, just maybe indieTHI3VES™ can get in there & bring LIGHT to the darkness showing people that even though the world "ain't so beautiful all the time", the beauty that is still here is immeasurable & has power in the vibrations of LOVE, BEAUTY & ART

indieTHI3VES™ noun 1./ˌində'/THēvēs/ - an ART label for & of thinkers explaining sunlight to those who never left the darkness...

story:
Recently, with "Hot Shot Tragedies" and "Wildfires at Our Door", we have all become acutely aware by experiencing first hand the sacrifices and dedication our heroic firefighters and first responders across the country are making on our behalves. Our Dalmatian sculpture project was borne out of the devastating emotions brought about by the impact of 9/11 and the subsequent onslaught of wildfires and terrorist acts.

Artists KAREN & TONY BARONE are fundraising to donate their larger-than-life bright blue “R. HERO” Dalmatian puppy sculpture honoring firefighters & first responders to the City of Palm Springs, CA and the people of the Coachella Valley.

Karen & Tony are a legendary artist couple working side by side in the execution of their very large-scale sculpture and paintings. This extraordinarily creative husband and wife team’s works have been exhibited and acquired by individuals, cities & museums worldwide.

The all aluminum 6’-2” tall shimmering bright blue “R. HERO” outdoor sculpture honoring firefighters and first responders has been approved by the City Council for installation in front of Palm Springs Fire Station #3, (on Racquet Club Drive across from Victoria Park and down from The Buena Vista Elementary School). As a gift to the City “R. HERO” will become a permanent & significant part of the City’s Art-in-Public-Places collection and a vital teaching tool for its citizens, especially the children.

The artists have created "R. HERO" as a unique series of sculptures to be installed at public sites: children’s museums, children's hospitals, municipal buildings, fire stations, schools, parks and other not-for-profits, to honor and recognize our valiant firefighters and first responders who operate in relative obscurity to save, rescue & protect humans and animals alike. Through the creative & instructive expression of art, the “R. HERO” sculptures serve as a reminder of their indefatigable heroism. 

Karen & Tony Barone are passionate about making their “R. HERO” sculptures available to communities across America – creating a “Dalmation-Nation”.

To date “R. HERO”, Dalmatian puppy sculptures honoring firefighters & first responders, have been successfully sponsored and gifted to the following not-for-profits:

•The Children’s Discovery Museum of the Desert, Rancho Mirage, CA                                     •The Historical Society of Palm Desert (CA) on El Paseo, the City’s 1st fire station                         •The Children’s Museum of Phoenix (AZ)                                                                        •The EverWonder Children’s Museum of Newtown, Connecticut – “(R. HERO was selected) as a symbolic, beneficial teaching tool in our well laid-out plan of having the museum become a part of the cure for this emotionally devastated community.”              . . . .Kristin Chiriatti, President 

What happens if we surpass our goal? The short answer is – the more we raise, the more “R. HERO” Dalmatian puppy sculptures honoring firefighters & first responders we will be able to donate – there is no shortage of deserving recipients.

We have EXCITING PERKS (see sample image below) – however, it is acknowledging these unsung heroes that we hope motivates you to CONTRIBUTE

“FLY OF  VALOR” is original micro sculpture art jewelry by artists Karen & Tony Barone. In Egypt (1550-1069 BC) the “Fly of Valor” was awarded for bravery because of its persistence in the face of opposition.

$500. CONTRIBUTION PERK –14K SOLID GOLD “FLY” PENDANT/CHARM – by Karen & Tony Barone ©MMXIII .................. ($250. CONTRIBUTION PERK – SAME “FLY” IN SILVER). 

Karen & Tony Barone are independent working artists and NOT a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization. They honor firefighters & first responders by donating “R. HERO” sculptures through funds raised privately.

Please get the word out and act as an "R. HERO" emissary.

We hope you can support us in helping us donate this “R. HERO” sculpture to the City of Palm Springs, CA by clicking on the 

CONTRIBUTE NOW button – thank you!

story:
GET PIERCED


.: THE MISSION: IN A NUTSHELL :.

HELP PIERCED EAR POETRY IN SENDING THEIR FIRST EVER TEAM TO THE 2012 NATIONAL POETRY SLAM INVITATION IN CHARLOTTE, NORTH CAROLINA


ENTER THE NUTCRACKER
For two consecutive years (2010-11) Stockton, CA has been deemed the most miserable city in America. The time for change is at hand. The Pierced Ear Poetry Slam team is comprised of members from all different walks of life and located all across California. From Cotati to Santa Cruz, these artists are combining their powers like Planeteers to spread the California love from the local Stockton community all the way to North Carolina. This is the first time Stockton, CA has sent representatives to the annual National Poetry Slam -- any help you give is helping to make West Coast history.



.: NATIONALS? SLAM? :.

ARE YOU AS CONFUSED AS A FIRST TIME GLEE VIEWER? HERE'S SOME BACKGROUND INFO!


SLAM POETRY
Slam Poetry is a spoken word competition in which poets are given a time limit to read or recite their work and are judged by selected members of the audience. Tracing its origins back to 1984 Chicago, Slam spread to the rest of North America and has touched every continent on the globe.

NATIONAL POETRY SLAM
The National Poetry Slam (NPS) is an annual competition that began in 1990 at Fort Mason in San Francisco, CA with just four competing teams. This year, NPS is hosted in Charlotte, North Carolina and will feature 72 teams from all across the nation and beyond. 

 

.: MEET THE TEAM :.

YOU MAY BE ASKING YOURSELF, "WHO ARE THESE PEOPLE?!" YOU'RE NOT? OH...WELL HERE THEY ARE REGARDLESS OF THAT

 

 
THE POET -i-
"-i-" allows listeners to share her world by helping them to look through her eyes, labeled the "storyteller", her words are a raw truth that brings both laugher and tears to their audience. A multi-time representative of the Bay Area at Nationals, "-i-" is a mother, a student, and native of Oakland, CA. 

 

 
LEO
Leo is a Bay Area based, born and raised poet. In his rookie year, after just 8 months in the scene, Leo became Grand Slam Champion and member of the 2011 Berkeley Slam Team. His honest performance has been described as possessing the ability to "heal midair". He is the 2012 San Francisco Grand Slam Champion and an advocate of all things hug-related.



 
JAZ SUFI 
Jaz Sufi is a poet, a Bay Area Native, an excavator of the human condition, and delighted to make your acquaintance. At 18, she became the slammaster of the Legendary Santa Cruz Indie Slam and the youngest slammaster of a PSI-certified venue in the country. She was a featured poet at the 2011 USF Creative Justice Art Show, and has performed at art showcases across the Bay Area.



 
PEREZ
Perez is a Latina Slam/Performance Poet. Her work is sometimes bilingual, self-exposing, and she hopes, connecting. A member of the 2011 San Francisco team, Christina is the slam-master for the Coast Slam in Fort Bragg, CA. Christina teaches workshops for at risk youth in Mendocino and is a Poetry Out Loud Teacher for Santa Rosa and Rancho Cotati High Schools in Sonoma County.

 

 
COACH: THE SAINT
Anthony Lemuel "The Saint" Gonsalves is slammaster of the Pierced Ear Poetry Slam, The Saint has spent the last few years working the mic as the 2009 Ill List Champion, member of the 2010 San Francisco Slam Team and the 2011 Oakland Slam Team. He's now ready to try his hand at coaching the loveable band of misfits you've just been introduced to.

 

 

.: WHAT WE NEED AND WHY WE NEED IT :.

WHERE'S YOUR MONEY GOING? ON AN ADVENTURE TO SAY THE LEAST


After thorough negotiations with the US Postal Service, it turns out that not only is it unethical to mail human beings, they require much more than just forty-five cents in postage costs. 

So, while the Pierced Ear poets are rich in talent, talent doesn't buy airline tickets or pay for hotel rooms. The money you donate will enable the team to travel across the country to North Carolina for Nationals, and while there, keep a roof over their heads for the 5-day event.
 

IMPOVERISHED AT THE MOMENT?

If you can't afford to donate at this time we ask that you just promote this page, pass it along to a friend, a relative, a generous benefactor with an affinity for the written and oral arts, anyone. Facebook it, tweet it, retweet it, e-mail, mass text, spell it with your Alphabits, send out messenger ravens, put a message in a bottle, ANYTHING. Publicizing our cause is just as important, if not moreso, as giving a monetary donation (which is not to say we wouldn't love a monetary donation, 'cause we really really would)

 

 

.: WHAT'S IN IT FOR YOU :.

WHEN BENEVOLENCE JUST ISN'T ENOUGH.

We don't know who you are. We don't know what you want. If you are looking for ransom, we can tell you we don't have money. But what we do have are a very particular set of skills; skills we have acquired over a very long career.

Just kidding. Only slightly, beyond their talents in Slam, the Pierced Ear squad does indeed possess a wide-array of talents ranging from massage therapy to crocheting to graphic design. Empty space on your dining room wall? Need a logo for your new business endeavor or blossoming superhero career? Feeling overworked and underappreciated? We are offering our skills to you in exchange for your support: Original paintings, hand drawn illustrations, massages, gourmet dinners, hand knit clothing, in-home performances, the works.

Even if you cannot meet the minimum donation required to receive one of the aforementioned incentives, every donor will receive a haiku-a-day for every dollar given to the team. Haiku will be topic of your choice.

 

THAT'S ALL FOLKS

To those of you who read this section in its entirety I wish nothing but organic milk and oven fresh cookies. We, the Pierced Ear Poetry Slam Team, thank you for your time and in advance, for any show of support you give us, monetary or otherwise. You rock and we like rocks!

The money you donate will enable the team to travel across the country to North Carolina for Nationals, and while there, keep a roof over their heads for the 5-day event. 
IMPOVERISHED AT THE MOMENT?If you can't afford to donate at this time we ask that you just promote this page, pass it along to a friend, a relative, a generous benefactor with an affinity for the written and oral arts, anyone. Facebook it, tweet it, retweet it, e-mail, mass text, spell it with your Alphabits, send out messenger ravens, put a message in a bottle, ANYTHING. Publicizing our cause is just as important, if not moreso, as giving a monetary donation (which is not to say we wouldn't love a monetary donation, 'cause we really really would)
 
 
.: WHAT'S IN IT FOR YOU :.
WHEN BENEVOLENCE JUST ISN'T ENOUGH.We don't know who you are. We don't know what you want. If you are looking for ransom, we can tell you we don't have money. But what we do have are a very particular set of skills; skills we have acquired over a very long career.
Just kidding. Only slightly, beyond their talents in Slam, the Pierced Ear squad does indeed possess a wide-array of talents ranging from massage therapy to crocheting to graphic design. Empty space on your dining room wall? Need a logo for your new business endeavor or blossoming superhero career? Feeling overworked and underappreciated? We are offering our skills to you in exchange for your support: Original paintings, hand drawn illustrations, massages, gourmet dinners, hand knit clothing, in-home performances, the works. Even if you cannot meet the minimum donation required to receive one of the aforementioned incentives, every donor will receive a haiku-a-day for every dollar given to the team. Haiku will be topic of your choice.
 
THAT'S ALL FOLKS
To those of you who read this section in its entirety I wish nothing but organic milk and oven fresh cookies. We, the Pierced Ear Poetry Slam Team, thank you for your time and in advance, for any show of support you give us, monetary or otherwise. You rock and we like rocks!

story:
The Effigy

Ke'el K'aak' meaning "cold fire" in Yucaten, the language of the Mayans embody the concept behind our effigy. We propose to build a tiered 14’ x 16’ pyramid reminiscent of Mayan structures found in Chichen Itza and Calakmul, Mexico. Within the walls of the effigy will be a combination of inlaid Mayan patterning and various snow crystal motifs. There will be four archways that let participants enter the structure. Each door will face one of the four cardinal directions: North, South, East or West. In the center of the pyramid will be a 6’ snowman, fabricated out of wood. As the effigy burns the snowman will rise through the pyramid; via a pulley and weight system that we have designed. The snowman will come to rest at the top of the structure until it burns down.

Our Team 

Aaron Pinchevski (Kombo)– Designer, Engineer, Badass 

Frank Castanien (Tank, Fran) – Fabricator, Mistake

Dustin Click (Dusty Rhodes)– Fabricator, Mindless Self-­‐Indulger 

Evan Collier (H’evan) – Spiritual Guide 

Brian Sharrock (Bri Bri, Bee Baby) – Brought against will 

Eric Coolidge (E Claire, Ogre) – THE CREATOR

What We Need & What You Get

The funds recieved will go to materials, equipment usage, space usage, and transportation. Our main focus is to acquire the highest quality pulley system which will ensure a successful burn.
 
With every donation comes a perk. Our perks are Handcrafted and fabricated by our build tesam in Brooklyn, NY. Below are our Perks.

story:
Bliss Dance, Truth is Beauty and The Bliss Project

___________________________________________________________

UPDATE:  Yay, thanks to all of you we made our Indiegogo goal early!!! We are so grateful for all of the love and support!!  It's not to late to keep it going though...Any donations above our minimum goal will be used to help compensate those who have already dedicated 100s and 1,000s of hours to help build Truth is Beauty, fund planned actions and activities on playa, as well as to starting the next and final sculpture in the Bliss Project, R-evolution, which we plan to start working on when we return from Burning Man 2013. Pendants are still available and the support and share campaign is still in effect!

gratefully yours, Marco and the Bliss Dance Crew

____________________________________________________________

 

Do you remember the first time you saw Bliss Dance at Burning Man in 2010, or on Treasure Island in San Francisco?  Her impact was inspiring, even to those of us who spent a year building her.  We wanted more...Did you want more?!

Well, we want to give it to you... Truth is Beauty is the second sculpture, following Bliss Dance, in a three-part series of monumental sculptures of a woman, Deja Solis, expressing her humanity.  But my crew and I really need your help to make this happen for Burning Man 2013 and beyond!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Announcing the Truth is Beauty Support & Share Contest!

The prize: A pendant of your choice (Truth is Beauty or Bliss Dance). Here’s how to enter: scroll up and find your unique “share this campaign” link under the video (you must sign into your indiegogo account to get your unique link). You can use your link to share on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram, Pinterest, G+, and anywhere else you can think of. Send an email to friends & family, share on your blog. The top two referrers will each get a pendant. Good luck and thanks for sharing!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here's What We Hope to Accomplish

I believe the world is out of balance and that we need to listen to women’s voices and understand their intent.  They do not speak up as often as men.  I believe that one of the reasons for this is the systemic violence against women that has been present throughout history.  I think it’s time to take the next step in evolution, to actively create a safe environment for women and to take responsibility for our society.

Truth is Beauty and my other sculptures are intended to demand this change in perspective. They are intended to be catalysts for social change; to de-objectify women and express the basic truth of femininity, a truth that is dangerous for individual women to express.  They are a reminder of what we gain when we value women.  My hope is to inspire men and women to take action to end violence against women, thus allowing all of us to live fully and thrive. 

Standing 55 feet tall and weighing 7,000 pounds Truth is Beauty will be constructed using:

  • 55,000 single welds
  • 25,000 feet of steel rod and pipe
  • 6,500 steel ball connection points
  • 2,000 square feet of stainless steel mesh

One thousand five hundred (1,500) individual multi-colored LED lights will be distributed throughout her body. These lights will be controlled by a custom iPad application to create a spectacular light show that will enhance and expand the visual experience.

Like Bliss Dance before her, she will be unveiled at Burning Man and then we plan to place her out in the world (Bliss Dance debuted at Burning Man 2010 and has been installed on Treasure Island in San Francisco since 2011.) 

 

My Inspiration

The story of Truth is Beauty and The Bliss Project began when I was 7-years old and my best friend was a 9-year old little girl.  One day I was told, in way too much detail for a little boy, that she had been raped right outside of my house.  It was incomprehensible, horrible, I never forgot, I never understood...it still haunts me.  I thought...that man couldn't have realized my friend was a person, that if he really could see her, this wouldn't have happened.

I grew up in the Bay Area in the 60's and 70's, in the philosophical revolution and turbulence of those times.  I learned to deeply appreciate feminine energy, influence and strength…and realized that the objectification of women imprisoned women and also men.  I also saw first-hand that one person, or a small group of people, can start a movement that can make a difference and change the course of history.

In my 20s I discovered sculpting, and in particular, the joy of seeing and then sculpting women; of the healing energy and power that I saw when women were not afraid...when they could be present, when they could be themselves, speak their minds...and the heroism it takes to do this in the face of real danger in their daily lives.  For more than 25 years I have been sculpting women.  At first glance, they appear to be classical figurative nudes, but they are not.  They are radically modern...revolutionary.   These women are safe, present. Look at them. They have chosen their own expression, so you will see the actual woman, the person, her energy and spirit.  It is my intent that these sculptures exude this healing energy and inspire us to take action; to finally say enough is enough.

 

How You Can Help!

Right now we are raising money so that we can complete Truth is Beauty!

She began her journey as a bronze sculpture in 2007.  Using a pantograph — a medieval-era enlargement tool — she is being built by hand using classical sculpting techniques from my life-size original, first to an 18 ft clay version and then to her final 55 ft steel form. In 2011, with the help of generous donors and an amazing crew, we brought the 30 ft torso to the Playa. This year we have been awarded a grant from Burning Man toward her completion, but the grant does not cover all of our costs. 

Now, we need funds to cover materials (steel, stainless steel mesh, nuts, bolts, screws, welding materials) waterjet parts, insurance, rent, transportation, certified welders, structural engineers, heavy equipment, lighting and the list goes on.  If we go above our goal, we will be able to support the people who have dedicated themselves to bringing this project to life.  They have already put in months of work to get her to this phase of the build!  

Please donate what you can, but also, and just as importantly, we really need you to collaborate with us on how we can take this healing out into the world.  These pieces are about taking action together.  We have already heard great ideas from the community.  One idea that comes from my friend, Aaron Schiller, is a reflection circle around the base of Truth is Beauty (in the form of two circles of chairs facing each other) where men and women will be invited to share their own true person with each other, thus “empowering each other to be stewards of the truth, the respect and the beauty that is man/women existence on this planet.”  Another idea that comes from my friend Aaryn Herridge, is to give anyone who is inspired by Truth is Beauty the opportunity to write a healing letter, a letter of hope, to be delivered to a young girl or woman affected by violence.  My letter would say "I am sorry that happened to you.  I am standing with you. I will do what I can to stop this."  What would your letter say? What is your idea? 

So please visit our website at www.blissdance.us where we are asking for and sharing your ideas as well!

 

The Bottom Line

Art can illuminate the human condition and be a catalyst to social change ...it can foment revolution and, with your help, art can help change human consciousness around violence against women and begin a healing process that will make room for women’s voices! I am asking you to stand with us!

Thank you to everyone for the incredible support I have received in the past, and to everyone who is considering supporting Truth is Beauty.  Projects like this could not happen without you!

Marco and Bliss Dance Crew

 

P.S. We appreciate our donors so much and have some great rewards to show our gratitude including Truth is Beauty swag (including pendants shown to the left) and invitations to special events! See full descriptions to the right.

 

For more information, please watch the video and go to www.blissdance.us.

You can follow Truth is Beauty and The Bliss Project on Facebook.

story: _ _

‘Sapfo Fest’ is a first independent community-initiated festival in the Baltics aimed at combating discriminatory practices against LBTQI. A community-led festival, the ‘Sapfo Fest’ seeks to empower the LBTQI community and combat prejudice and discrimination, as well as increase visibility of LBTQI individuals in Lithuania and Eastern Europe more generally.

For the third year in a row the Festival will be strengthening ties among LBTQI individuals by bringing people together into a shared space and providing knowledge related to LGBTQI situation internationally and in Lithuania.

This year, through lectures and workshops as well as the LGBTQI art, the ‘Sapfo Fest’ will take a closer look at the ‘identity’. How do we shape our gender, how do (not) conform to the normative roles, and how it affects our identities? How it unites/divides us? How it relates to other LBTQI problematics and issues?

In addition, the festival will bring together the queer scene faces in Lithuania to the ‘Sapfo Fest’. A well know poet and an art critic Laima Kreivytė, a queer poet and activist Gabrielė Labanauskaitė, Neringa Danngvydė, a writer, whose fairy tale book was banned because of its homosexual content, among others. With its diverse educational program – from Soviet mental institutions for lesbians to today‘s trans* rights – the ‘Sapfo Fest” hopes to create a learning, sharing, and appreciative space for everybody.

Background:

Lithuania is a post-Soviet ‘transitioning’ democracy, which gained its independence from Russia in  1990.;  Lithuania, just like Russia, maintains national laws that are directly and overtly discriminating against LGBTQI individuals, and many oppressive ‘values’, perceptions and practices regarding LGBTQI have remained despite the material changes of the  last twenty-five  years. As an example, our national Pride Parade can only be arranged under heavy police protection due to verbal threats and physical attacks by organised right-wing groups, and both our love life and attempts at organising is routinely attacked by high ranking members of leading political parties. Consequently, our private lives and individual determination; as well as our right to freedom of expression and freedom of association is constantly under threat. 

Whereas the visibility of gay men in Lithuania has been growing steadily and quite a few male artists and entertainers 'have come out' publicly, the women’s community remains largely ignored and marginalised. 

Earlier festivals

Back in 2012, two community members - Sandra and Agne - organized the first ever LBTQI festival in Lithuania - 'PiLeFe' (acronym for 'Angry Lesbians' Festival'). Over the last two years (2012 & 2013) the pioneers of the festival have provided a platform for the LBTQI community in Lithuania to strengthen ties through various cultural and educational activities, share ideas and brainstorm new projects. Even without any institutional support, the festival has proved a great success and attracted around 90 participants last year. 

Only around 30 participants out of 90 are in the photograph from the ‘PiLeFe’ of 2013. In our current political and social climate in Lithuania, most of them are prevented from publicly sharing their faces with you due to potential humiliation, bullying and discrimination, as well as physical safety issues within both professional and personal circles.

New vision 

This year the organizational committee has increased and now includes 13 human rights activists, who combine their experience, knowledge, passion and determination for advancing the goals of LBTQI community and more inclusive society. Organizers come from various backgrounds and have both national and international LBTQI advocacy experience. Some community members returned to Lithuania after getting their degrees and activism experience in London, New York, Athens, Barcelona & many other places, and combined their energy and passion with the ones who have been working in Lithuania and contributing to the ‘Baltic Pride’ in 2010 and 2013, among others. Our vision is to grow with the Festival and attract way more participants this year, who could benefit from the Festival's shared space, educational, cultural and artistic activities. 

New face

Although the organizers strongly believe that community-building needs to be continued, however, they also think that more visibility, awareness-raising and representation are needed for the LBTQI community and women in Lithuania on political and public level. Therefore this year in addition to the various artistic, educational and cultural events, the Festival aims to provide a platform for connecting with a public and 'coming out.' Willing LBTQI community members, who include well-known arts & cultural scene individuals, will openly communicate and 'come out' for the media and public. Thus the Festival in itself will seek to encourage the Lithuanian society to acknowledge the existence and marginalization of the LBTQI community and open up a dialogue for future collaborations. 

No fee: We think it would be unfair to impose a festival participation fee, because it would exclude many individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds. Thus, we wish to keep ‘Sapfo Fest’ as inclusive as possible and free of charge for the participants. This year the Festival is aimed for at least 200 - 300 community members. To make our vision a reality, we are looking for possible contributions so we could cover the direct costs, such as rent of the festival space, food, sound and multimedia equipment. Anything over this amount will go to cover lecturers’ travel expenses and stretch goals in inviting and paying for the travel expenses for other LBTQI rights organizations in the post-Soviet sphere. All activists are devoting their time and energy on the voluntary basis, not a single dollar will be spent on something that is not completely vital for the festival to happen.


Help us to be visible, support the ‘Sapfo Fest'!


Risks and challenges

‘SapfoFest’ has a passionate and determined team and a picturesque place for the festival, however it really needs Your financial support. As almost no other organization or foundation is funding the initiative (we only have received $160 from Lithuanian Gay League), and there are no potential funders left on the horizon, we would be eternally grateful for any assistance in keeping the 'Sapfo Fest' open to as many LBTQI people as possible. Every donation will be truly and greatly appreciated!

Help us to be visible, support the ‘Sapfo Fest'!
Risks and challenges 
‘SapfoFest’ has a passionate and determined team and a picturesque place
for the festival, however it really needs Your financial support. As almost no
other organization or foundation is funding the initiative (we only have
received $160 from Lithuanian Gay League), and there are no potential funders
left on the horizon, we would be eternally grateful for any assistance in
keeping the 'Sapfo Fest' open to as many LBTQI people as possible. Every
donation will be truly and greatly appreciated!

story:
The project was originally conceived December 2009 in one form of a static sculpture as the Monolith from 2001: A Space Odyssey – a film from 1968 where Kubrick broke into new dimensions of film making.

The monolith itself is a representation of peace and evolution. Given the the sequel to 2001 was the Arthur C. Clarke book 2010 from 1982 which was quickly made into a film, it seemed appropriate given the nature of this event to bring it to life at Burning Man this year.

A quick story about the life of this project so far: why is this funding so late?
Though the concept was sewn in December 2009, it was proposed and sent to Burning Man by February. A partner joined and we were going to amplify the project by making it interactive. Partner bailed, 3 funding attempts to get $3k faltered miserably, and finally the structure that was built so far was stolen just recently.

This Rendition
Because of all the changes and the refusal to go empty handed, adding the desire to bring to life what this represents to me, I forged ahead with a newly realized static version.

Will build a box in the same proportions 9′ x 4′ x 1′ out of plywood:

x paint it jet black

x place a polyurethane coat around it to make the surface smooth

x some silver glitter will be added to the coat

x on face add stencil from 2010 closing; see graphic

x on back mount bone from 2001 intro and David graphic; see sample

x mount on steel tracks that will be used to anchor into the ground with re-bar posts.

x surround by spot lighting operating off solar power

This project is:

x an homage to Kubrick and Clarke for their vision in 2001: A Space Odyssey; with notes on 2010

x a representation of peace and a message of evolution of the planet

x and is is a beautiful representation of Kubrick’s translation of the monolith from the movies

This is a much more simplified version of the original concept. It will not be sustaining in it’s form and will not probably come back from Burning Man as a result. Hopefully, with better planning and realistic strategy future expressions will prove to be more of an asset both sustaining and environmentally friendly.

Past Funding
I have made 3 attempts to achieve funding so far that have net very little because of the overhead or failure to sell the project to my vision.
1. Red Angel party fund raiser (www.redangelvegas.com) where I actually lost money
2. Red Angel 2: Monolith Condition where I broke even
3. Kickstarted where I only got 7% funding and it was not rewarded because there you have to make 100% of goal to get the money
However, there is a new simplified version of the project because of the short time to make the project happen given the misfortune of the past.

I have a positive and optimistic vision of this project.
