story:
IMPORTANT UPDATE

Please note: In the midst of our initial fundraising attempt, we enjoyed an important "update conversation" with the community of Newtown, Connecticut. A commission to determine quantity and site placement of selected monument donations was just being formed—and the community asked us to postpone our significant efforts until they had made their final evaluations.

Although our project previously received excellent feedback from community stakeholders—and we expect more from this commission—we agreed to restart our campaign after hearing from the new group.

Please check back for important developments, and thanks for your support!

Our Inspiration

Unfortunately, we all have become familiar with tragedy—and we're REALLY familiar with feeling powerless to help people who are far away. With this awesome project, we're going to cast a 13-foot bronze monument and donate it to Newtown, Connecticut. The figure is holding origami cranes, which are symbols of peace and hope.

Participating in this project allows all of us to make a lasting, permanent contribution to the lives of an entire community—and the world.

The piece was sculpted by Lorri Acott, a former teacher who reacted like all of you did when the Newtown tragedy occurred last December. As a sculptor, she is able to express her own deep connection to those who suffer by making artwork. Sculpture is her loudest voice, and it's permanent. By contributing to this project, you can speak with her, and with the community of Hill City, South Dakota.

Lorri is joined in this effort by many. Black Hill Bronze will help with casting and installation. The students at Bethel High School in Bethel, Connecticut began by folding cranes and  have decided to join us in raising money for the big sculpture. The Hill City Arts Council is lending their support, and various people from all over the US are stepping forward to assist in this effo

What we need & What You Get

We're asking for $70,000 to make this piece and transport it to Newtown. If we receive extra funding, we will enhance the base of the sculpture and landscaping—and if we receive a LOT of extra funding, we'll contribute to the college funds of Sandy Hook Elementary students.
 
You get a ton of great perks for participating, from our heartfelt thanks, to sculptures, to in-person visits to our studio and the casting foundry. This is a community project—and the community is getting larger every day. By participating, you join other people who are MAKING A DIFFERENCE. Why not just save the world with art?
 
If we don't raise the entire amount during this time, we will begin the casting process and move forward with the sculpture with what we have.  It is important enough to us that we will make it happen either way. Your help will allow us do it in a timely manner, as well as give you the opportunity to be a part of a the transformational power or art.

The Impact

The impact of this project will be a permanent memorial that commemorates the strength and resiliency of Newtown—as well as the compassion and hope of the world around Newtown. Our world is small, and we all have to share whatever love and support we can give.

As a sculptor who works in large format, Lorri has experienced the emotion of families and communities who place monuments in public spaces. She's watched people cry and laugh; she's read letters years later from those who have just then seen an important sculpture for the first time.

Monuments literally transform a physical space. They provide a gathering place, a positive aspect to history. All of us involved with this project can't wait to see this particular sculpture, which is called Peace, in this particular community. We can already feel it there.

Other Ways You Can Help

If this project speaks to you, then please share it! Link, Facebook, Tweet, chat, do whatever you can to spread the word. We already successfully accomplished our first collaborative phase of this project—helping school kids to fold paper origami cranes filled with "love notes" and sending them to Newtown. Word of our tiny town's efforts spread like wildfire across the country, and other kids and their schools also folded cranes. Let's do the same with this project! Spread the word. Spread the love.

Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks for your excitement about this. Join us in whatever way you can!

Phase One—December 2012

In cultures around the world, people have used the crane as a symbol of peace and hope—a way to soothe souls of their suffering. Following this tradition, children in Hill City, South Dakota—population 900—sent an irrefutable message of love to the
families in Newtown, Connecticut. They folded origami cranes—embedded with drawings or written prayers, wishes, and personal messages—intended as physical representations of what is impossible to say.

“Each crane is a representation of a prayer,” Lorri Acott said. “One person, one crane, one prayer.”

Bethel, Connecticut, is just minutes away from Newtown, and students in its high school also had started folding cranes, with the hope of creating one string of 1,000 cranes for each of Newtown’s 26 grieving families. Hill City’s cranes first flew to
Bethel to assist with that project—but the dream did not end there. Other communities around the country also provided their own crane “populations.”

“Art has a transformational quality,” Lorri said. “Art gives people a place to put their grief, sorrow, and pain—and a way to begin to transform it. Art gives both children and adults a way to share a silent prayer that cannot be adequately expressed in words—and if anyone needs our prayers right now, it’s the folks in Newtown.”

“This project is a tangible way that people can actually do something to help others—and themselves,” said Kristin Donnan Standard, president of the Hill City Arts Council, the organization that linked Lorri Acott to the school administration, the state arts council, and a video production company that volunteered its services. “This is art at its highest service.”

She said that folding cranes for a particular purpose reminded her of a traditional Native American practice of making prayer ties—in which tobacco is folded into small squares of cotton.

“You really focus your heart while you fold, whether it’s a crane or a tie,” she said. “And when you hang up a string of cranes, it’s like hanging Tibetan prayer flags. You’re putting your message out to God.”

The Legend of the Crane

This large and graceful bird is the subject of many legends, thanks to fables claiming that a single crane can live for a thousand years. The fossil record suggests that today’s cranes are probably relatives of the oldest birds on earth, which gives some credence to our human interpretations of their power of endurance.

More than a dozen species of crane inhabit five continents, with the most majestic standing five feet tall with a wingspan of more than seven feet.

The crane has been connected to ideas of joy and the celebration of life since Greek and Roman times, thanks to their association with Apollo, the sun god. Throughout Asia, the crane has symbolized happiness, eternal youth, longevity, and good fortune. In some legends, these powerful birds are said to carry a person to higher levels of spiritual consciousness—or a soul up to paradise.

If any bird has broad enough shoulders to carry messages of hope across the land, surely it is the crane—in the flesh or in paper. It is said that a thousand folded cranes, one for each year of the bird’s life, makes a wish come true.

“Art can help us heal,” Lorri says. “There are many examples of how art has been used to help people recover from traumatic events in the past. The crane project—both paper and bronze—is the vehicle we can use to help people who are so desperately in need of healing right now as a town, community, and country.”

The Team

LORRI ACOTT

A teacher for 25 years in elementary, junior high, and high school, Lorri taught in both general and art classrooms. She also taught children with emotional
and learning disabilities.

“When I taught in the elementary school, I remember all the wonderful things the first grade teachers did to help kids understand the concept of 100,” she said. “They collected things all year long—they laid out bottle caps, jelly beans, and pennies, one by one, so that a hundred could really be understood.”

As she folded practice cranes, in brightly colored origami squares, she asked, “What do a thousand prayers look like? What about ten thousand, or one hundred thousand, or a million? The only way we will know is by seeing them.”

Learn more about Lorri, and her partner, sculptor Adam Schultz, at www.DreamBigSculpture.com. Lorri's personal site is www.LorriAcott.com.

BLACK HILLS BRONZE

Just miles from the country’s largest and most renowned sculptures—Mount Rushmore and Crazy Horse Memorials—Black Hills Bronze offers full-service bronze casting to artists, businesses, organizations, industry, and the public. As avid supporters of using creativity to help unify and strengthen, we believe in making connections. We believe that creativity can heal us, individually, tribally, and as human beings. And we believe that it will take all of us, working together, to save the world.

Learn more at www.blackhillsbronze.com.

HILL CITY ARTS COUNCIL

The Hill City Arts Council has been called "the glue that holds Hill City together," and we accomplish loads of work each year thanks to the effort of a generous volunteer board. We host several significant events each year, and love supporting initiatives like Lorri Acott's idea for Newtown.

Learn more about our annual programming, as well as our partners and supporters, including: the South Dakota Arts Council; South Dakotans for the Arts; Arts Midwest, our regional contingent of the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA); and the NEA itself at www.hillcityarts.org.

Join Us!

Prayers strung as paper—or bronze—cranes. The tiny village of Hill City in the Black Hills wants Newtown residents to know that more people love them than don’t, more people are good than bad, and although horrible things happen, there is still good in the world.

story:
Sam and Toaster rep the Bay poetically

Sam Sax is a Bay Area based writer, educator, and performer. He’s the first ever Bay Area Unified Grand Slam Champion and Oakland’s first two-time queer Grand Slam Champion. Sam curates 'the new sh!t show', a reading series in San Francisco aimed at producing new poetry, and is the poetry curator for The Modern Times Bookstore. He has toured internationally, performing at universities, slams, basements, alleyways, and amphitheaters. Sam is currently leading writing and literacy workshops for queer at risk youth. You can find some of his other work [or forthcoming] in Rattle, Muzzle Magazine, The Evergreen Review, The Orange Quarterly, Union Station Magazine, The Nervous Breakdown, DeComp etc. SF Weekly's Evan Karp said of Sam's work "His use of metaphor is so masterful and his commitment to emotional candor so zealous that you identify with his words regardless of gender, sexual preference, or penchant for danger. More of this, please!"

Tim "Toaster" Henderson is an explosion of energy originally out of Chicago, IL. A poet, mural artist, educator and musician, Toaster uses a kaleidoscope of artistic vision to create, express and teach. He has been featured on NPR (National Public Radio), at the legendary Green Mill, and at the largest youth poetry festival in the nation, "Louder Than A Bomb." In 2011 Toaster moved to the Bay Area to build a name for himself and he started winning slams immediately on his arrival. Most recently he won the hotly contested Berkeley Slam Indy Championship and is B-Town's iWPS (Individual World Poetry Slam) rep for 2012. You can find Toaster's work on: TVOAG.COM, all over Youtube and at facebook.com/timtoasterhenderson.

Sam and Toaster are headed to iWPS - the individual World Poetry Slam. This years tourney will be in Fayetville AR from October 4th - 6th. Please, Poetry and Poetry Slam fans - be a true patron of the arts by opening not only your hearts but also your wallets! Help us get these two to iWPS - Arkansas and the WORLD need to hear what these two have to say.

We Need Your Help Getting Sam and Toaster to Fayetville!

There are various expenses involved in getting a poet to and through iWPS. There's airfare and lodging of course, but there's also stuff like event registration and getting to and from the airport, printing CDs / DVDs / Collections to sell and exchange not to mention food while there.

  • We need to get Sam and Toaster to Arkansas.
  • We have PERKS! You know you LOVE Perks!
  • 100% of the funds raised in this campaign go to registration, travel, lodging and iWPS related expenses for these two fabulous poets!

story:
Short Summary

Friends,

We set ourselves a modest goal and accomplished it, but in addition to the expenses listed below, we have had a few new unexpected costs: a print that needed to be professionally framed; a larger catalogue print run; a carnet for an artwork.  Please do help us go beyond our modest goal and help us reach $1900. And please peruse the press our project has received in the links below our project overview. THANK YOU!

Opening on May 2, 2014 at Gallery400, Encounters at the Edge of the Forest is a compelling and provocative contemporary art exhibition that addresses trees as sites and pawns in diverse histories of political and social injustice. Our exhibition draws together both international and domestic artists to excavate complex local and global issues.

We are a diverse team of 11 passionate graduate students, led by curator and educator Rhoda Rosen, PhD. We have exceptionally generous, yet partial funding from the supportive Museum and Exhibition Studies program at the University of Illinois at Chicago, but we need your help! Your generosity will support:

- The $1200.00 negotiated cost of a 24-page, full color catalogue containing radical new research uncovered by students

- $500.00 expenses for funding for dynamic exhibition programs including:

o collaborations with local schools, facilitating hands-on activities and discussions

o film screening fees

o Scholarly partnerships with leaders in the fields of race studies, border studies, and geopolitics to foster and cultivate further discussion about cultural practice and social justice

o Hospitality costs

Even if you can't contribute, visit the exhibition and please do share this campaign widely.

discussions o   film screening fees o   Scholarly partnerships with leaders in the fields of race studies, border
studies, and geopolitics to foster and cultivate further discussion about
cultural practice and social justice o   Hospitality costs 
 Even if you can't contribute, visit the exhibition and please do share this campaign widely.

story:
Print info:

"CeCe Is A Hero," edition of 175. Printed on a Vandercook Universal One Letterpress using a rainbow (5 color) split fountain. 12.5x12.5" on French Paper Brite White 100lb. Due to the nature of letterpress printing, no two prints are the same. Some display brighter colors than other, some may appear to contain more colors than others. Each print is unique.

Check out this video documenting the printing process.

Ordering Info:

Diana and I are not affiliated with any group or organization, we are just two friends working together on this benefit. All money from this benefit will be automatically sent to CeCe's legal support paypal when this campaign ends.


No posters will ship until September.

For More Info:

Check out www.astropressdc.com/cece.html for more info on the poster, the printing process, and the CECE IS A HERO photo project.

story:
Michael X. Rose and Fountain Art Fair

Fountian Art Fair is the most exciting Art Fair in the world. Hosted at the legendary 69th regiment armory in NYC at 23rd st and Lexington Ave., it was home to the first eponymous "Armory Show" in 1913. Master of Doom, Michael X. Rose wants to show his macabre art there as part of this incredible fair.
http://www.fountainartfair.com/
http://www.sixtyninth.net/armory.html

What We Need & What You Get

Fountain Art Fair costs money, real money.

  • The Booth costs 1000$. The rest of the money raised is for the prizes and rewards.
  • The rewards and perks offered are INSANE! I'm offering oil paintings at less than half my standard price, starting at 100$ for an 8x 10." Tempera paintings (not as light fast) can be had beginning at 50$. Original T-shirts and artists books are available for even less. You get your money back and more!
  • If we don't reach the entire goal, we'll need to sell even more paintings at the fair, and sleep on a park bench, but pledgers WILL get there rewards!

The Impact

Your contribution :

  • Obtain an original Michael X. Rose painting at a very low entry price point
  • Michael X. Rose delivered amazing rewards last year. Over 6 oil paintings to all.
  • Check out my website, you can choose your theme.
  • If you want to be a fan of fantastic original art, your support gets this to a broader collecting public.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • You can share thus URL and  get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Please  use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
ITALIANO

Il dipinto della Chiesa del Rosario di Gallipoli (Lecce, Italia) ha bisogno dell’aiuto di tutti voi per essere restaurato. Aiutateci a ridargli il posto che si merita in chiesa! A causa della mancanza di fondi, quest’opera rischia di scomparire per sempre.

Chi siamo?

“RestaurArti” nasce dalla volontà di tutelare, promuovere e valorizzare il patrimonio storico-artistico e di ricercare fondi da destinare al restauro di opere che, a causa del degrado e della mancanza di risorse finanziarie, rischiano di andare perdute per sempre.

Il team che è composto da Rossana Loiacono e Laura Corchia.

Rossana Loiacono è una restauratrice specializzata in opere pittoriche di area meridionale. Formatasi ad Arezzo nel laboratorio del prof.Carlo Guido, ha svolto la sua attività principalmente in Basilicata e in Puglia e collabora con la Soprintendenza dal 1980. Ha restaurato opere di artisti importanti ed ha svolto lavori per conto del Museo Provinciale di Lecce. Ha, inoltre, condotto i laboratori di restauro pittorico dell’Accademia di Belle Arti della stessa città ed ha partecipato all’allestimento di importanti mostre, tra cui “Il Barocco a Lecce e nel Salento, “La Puglia, il Manierismo, La Controriforma”.

Laura Corchia ha conseguito la laurea in Conservazione dei Beni Culturali discutendo la tesi di laurea dal titolo: “Il restauro dei dipinti su tela tra minimo intervento e tecniche tradizionali. Esperienze di Laboratorio” presso l’Università del Salento e, attualmente, prosegue gli studi nello stesso Ateneo.

Vorremmo realizzare questo progetto per diverse ragioni, sentimentali e professionali. La porta si trova in una chiesa di Gallipoli che attualmente non ha i fondi per restaurarla e, a causa del disinteresse delle autorità locali, rischia di scomparire per sempre. Vorremmo inoltre rispondere a degli interrogativi: che cosa è raffigurato? Chi lo ha dipinto? Quando? Perché è stato convertito in porta?

Qual è la situazione del dipinto?

Il dipinto è venuto alla luce lo scorso anno casualmente. La storia del suo rinvenimento è degna di un romanzo. Mentre il priore della confraternita trasportava una giara piena d’acqua ha urtato rompendo il contenitore. L’acqua si è rovesciata, bagnando il pavimento e la porta. Preso uno straccio per asciugare, il priore si è accorto che, sotto la laccatura marrone, emergevano delle tracce di colore. Avvicinando una lampada alla superficie della porta ha potuto constatare che quelle che all’inizio erano solo tracce di colore in realtà componevano delle figure: forse, un angelo e un santo domenicano. La superficie pittorica  completamente deteriorata non consente di identificare correttamente il soggetto.  

Il dipinto potrebbe essere opera di un pittore locale ma, a causa del degrado attuale, non è possibile individuare uno stile pittorico o una firma apposta sulla superficie.

Si trattava in origine di un dipinto ad olio su tavola, misura m. 2,10 x 1,03 e potrebbe risalire alla prima metà del XVII secolo. In un periodo non precisato, è stato convertito a porta di separazione tra il presbiterio e la sagrestia e ciò ha causato il totale degrado del dipinto. Questa porta separa l’altare da un piccolo vano di servizio. La Chiesa del Rosario apparteneva all’ordine domenicano giunto a Gallipoli nel XVI secolo. I seguaci di San Domenico fondarono la chiesa intitolata al loro protettore a cui era legata la Confraternita del Santissimo Rosario, una delle più antiche della città di Gallipoli, espressione della devozione cristiana dei sarti.


Il lungo cantiere ha visto collaborazioni importanti come quella tra Vespasiano Genuino e Gian Domenico Catalano e i capolavori che decorano gli altari che costeggiano l’unica navata e che formano il tesoro della Confraternita ne sono una testimonianza.

Di quali interventi ha bisogno?

1)  Protezione e fermatura del colore con carta di riso e colletta di coniglio;

2)  Smontaggio delle vecchie cerniere e chiavistelli della porta e, se necessario, interventi di falegnameria per liberare il dipinto dagli elementi applicati per modificarlo in porta;

3)  Pulitura dell’intera superficie pittorica con solventi adatti a rimuovere lo sporco e la vecchia vernice ingiallita;

4)  Indagini chimico-fisiche per facilitare il lavoro di restauro e lo studio dell’opera inedita;

5)  Pulitura e parchettatura del verso;

6)  Trattamento antitarlo;

7)  Stuccatura delle lacune;

8)  Integrazioni pittoriche;

9)  Verniciatura.

Il lavoro sarà eseguito sotto la direzione della Soprintentenza per i Beni Storici Artistici ed Etonoantropologici della Puglia e prevede l’impiego di materiali e di tecniche assolutamente reversibili e rispettose dell’oggetto.

Qual è l’obiettivo finale?

Riportare il dipinto alla situazione d’origine, arrestare il degrado e dare all’oggetto una collocazione più consona all’interno della chiesa.

Campagna

La campagna di crowdfounding mira a sostenere il restauro dell’opera d’arte attraverso il contributo di ciascuno di voi.

Potrete aggiornarvi costantemente sul procedere dei lavori attraverso la nostra pagina facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/RestaurArti/713354805354554. Inoltre, iscrivendovi alla nostra mailing list, riceverete periodici aggiornamenti: restaurartipr@gmail.com

Restaurare un’opera vuol dire consegnarla ai nostri figli

L’importanza della tutela e del restauro di un’opera risiede nella possibilità di poterla tramandare alle generazioni future. La cultura passa attraverso la valorizzazione del passato e, per fare ciò, occorre fermarne il degrado senza cancellare le modifiche apportate dal tempo.

Si può dare di più.

Se non potete sostenere economicamente la nostra campagna, potrete comunque aiutarci a diffondere il nostro messaggio:

- fateci arrivare migliaia di LIKE

- postate questo messaggio sui tutti social che conoscete

- scriveteci e esprimeteci la vostra opinione e le vostre idee

- parlate a tutti del nostro progetto.


ENGLISH

The painting of Rosary Church in Gallipoli, Lecce (Italy), needs a restoration. This plan lacks funds. For this reason, your help is necessary in order to save precious works of art.

About us

“RestuarArti” is an association of volunteers who gathered to promote our artistic heritage and to increase its value.

Basically, “RestaurArti” is searching for some contributions in money which will be assigned to the restorations of damaged art-pieces.

Team members:

Rossana Loiacono

Laura Corchia

Rossana Loiacono is a restorer specialized in recovery and conservation of paintings collocated in the Southern areas of Apulia. Her professional training started out with studies in this sphere of art, in Arezzo, under Professor Carlo Guido. She managed mainly her activity in Apulia and Basilicata.

She has been collaborated with Monuments and Fine Arts Office since 1980. She was engaged in other important activities as such as a collaboration with the Provincial Museum, in the city of Lecce.

Laura Corchia, instead, got her Bachelor’s degree of Conservation of Cultural Assets with the final work “The restoration of canvas paintings through minimus means of interventions and typical techniques”. She had some important professional experiences at the University of Salento,Faculty of Cultural Heritage Conservation. Now, she is going on with her studies at the same Faculty.

“RestaurArti” would this project to come true.

The door where our painting is placed is located in one of the Churches of Gallipoli.

Money lacks and this condition could definitely lead to the loss of this art-work.

Although a strong support is necessary, local authorities are not able to make better the situation.

As far as money is concerned we are searching for some contributions to know more about the history of the art-piece, as well.

 State of the painting

The painting was accidentally discovered last year.

While the Prior of the Confraternity was dragging a big jar full of water, he tripped up and broke it.

The water fell on the ground sprinkling the door. So, the Prior tried to wipe it with a cloth when under the brown lacquer some traces of colours appeared. He examined them and he noticed that those lines of colours belonged to a more complex figure such as an angel or a Dominican Saint.

The surface of the painting  is completely deteriorated and the lack of funds enables us to discover something more about its subject or its style. The work could be made by a local painter but, at the moment, a signature is impossibile to be discerned.

We know that this art-piece was an oil painting on a wooden board and that it measures 2,10x1,03 m. It probably rises from the first half of the VIIth century.

According to our suppositions, in a vague period, the work was used as a door to separate the presbytery from the sacristy. This kind of use worn it out.

The Rosary Church belonged to the Dominican Order arrived in Gallipoli during the XVIth century.

The followers of St. Dominicus, in fact, in devotion to him, founded the Church which became very important for the Confraternity of the Most Holy Rosary. Now, it is one of the most ancient churches in the city and it represents the Christian faith of tailors.

Some precious ornaments of the altar and of the nave constitute the evidence of the collaboration at the building between Vespasiano Genuino and Gian Domenico Catalano.

OUR CAMPAIGN

“Crowdfounding’s campaign” aims to substain restoration through contribution of every single one of you .You can always follow our progresses on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/RestaurArti/713354805354554

or you can subscribe  to our mailing list: restaurartipr@gmail.com

Restoring a work of art means to let other generations know their past, their history which has to be protected.

HOW YOU CAN HELP US

If you can not contribute in money you can spread our message.

We need more LIKES

Share this message on facebook, twitter and other social networks

Let us know your opinion through comments

Talk about our project to your friends, your family. It could be fruitful.

story:
Some Background Info

My name is Mandy Cano Villalobos and I'm an artist based in Grand Rapids, MI. I work in a variety of mediums, from drawing and textiles to performance and installation. All of my projects are related to time. How do we understand our unfolding lives through story-telling? How do we use rituals to make meaning in everyday routines? These are the kind of questions that drive my artistic practice.

This Summer I've been invited to attend Hambidge Residency. With your help, I can take advantage of this tremendous opportunity. As a mother of three young kids, it's hard to be a full time mom and a full time artist. Your contributions would allow me to focus on my art and help nurture my career.

While at Hambidge, I have lots of goals. I will continue my Sisyphus series for upcoming exhibitions at Lafontsee Galleries in Michigan. I'll also produce small paper works for a November show at James May Gallery in Algoma, WI. In addition to studio production, artist residencies are an excellent way to network with colleagues and explore collaborative possibilities.

Basically, I'm excited for this Summer! Please consider supporting me, at any amount, to give me the time and space to focus on my craft.

 

Getting there...

The fee to attend Hambidge is $500, which is an amazing bargain. But I also need to cover travel costs, meals and supplies (with a detour to the grandparents to drop the kiddos off in Alabama). Below are some estimated costs:

$500 Lodging and Attendance Fees

$300  Travel                                  

$400   Food 

$600   Materials

$200 Miscellaneous costs, including Indiegogo fees

That's a total of $2000.

Any little bit helps. Even $10 will cover the cost of a meal! And if I don't achieve my funding goals, your contributions will still help meet my needs. If I exceed my goals, I will invest that money into studio production costs so I can keep making art through the Summer and Fall. Either way, it's a good cause!

 

Thank you!

This whole artist thing is so rewarding. It also takes a lot of time, money, and perseverance. Recently I've come to realize that there are a lot of people who want to support the arts and who value what I and other artists do.  I am so grateful for everyone who has helped me over the years - not only through funding, but through free materials, watching my kids while I finish that painting, helping me in the studio, and just showing up to my exhibitions. 

I can't do this alone, but a community of art advocates can. You are my community, and I am so grateful for your support.  Thank you!

For those of you who are able to donate to this trip, I'd like to give you a small gift in return. Handmade thank you cards, tea bag quilts and hand embellished prints are all available at different levels of donation. Each item is one of a kind, and it's my way of showing you my appreciation.

As I said, I feel called to this profession - it's how I contribute to our culture. But with opportunities come challenges. I have a lot of exhibitions this year, and I need funding and support to make art, frame it, ship it and travel to gallery openings. It all begins at Hambidge.

 

Others ways you can help

You might not able to contribute right now. That's okay! One way you can help is to get the word out! Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or email. There are nifty little icons to the right of the pink "Back It" button that makes sharing super easy. 

 

Got questions?

Don't hesitate to contact me either through Indiegogo, or at mandycano.v@gmail.com. I welcome your questions and hope to hear from you.
story_txt:
Some Background Info
My name is Mandy Cano Villalobos and I'm an artist based in Grand Rapids, MI. I work in a variety of mediums, from drawing and textiles to performance and installation. All of my projects are related to time. How do we understand our unfolding lives through story-telling? How do we use rituals to make meaning in everyday routines? These are the kind of questions that drive my artistic practice.
This Summer I've been invited to attend Hambidge Residency. With your help, I can take advantage of this tremendous opportunity. As a mother of three young kids, it's hard to be a full time mom and a full time artist. Your contributions would allow me to focus on my art and help nurture my career.
While at Hambidge, I have lots of goals. I will continue my Sisyphus series for upcoming exhibitions at Lafontsee Galleries in Michigan. I'll also produce small paper works for a November show at James May Gallery in Algoma, WI. In addition to studio production, artist residencies are an excellent way to network with colleagues and explore collaborative possibilities.
Basically, I'm excited for this Summer! Please consider supporting me, at any amount, to give me the time and space to focus on my craft.
 

Getting there...
The fee to attend Hambidge is $500, which is an amazing bargain. But I also need to cover travel costs, meals and supplies (with a detour to the grandparents to drop the kiddos off in Alabama). Below are some estimated costs:
$500 Lodging and Attendance Fees
$300  Travel                                  
$400   Food 
$600   Materials
$200 Miscellaneous costs, including Indiegogo fees
That's a total of $2000.
Any little bit helps. Even $10 will cover the cost of a meal! And if I don't achieve my funding goals, your contributions will still help meet my needs. If I exceed my goals, I will invest that money into studio production costs so I can keep making art through the Summer and Fall. Either way, it's a good cause!
 
Thank you!
This whole artist thing is so rewarding. It also takes a lot of time, money, and perseverance. Recently I've come to realize that there are a lot of people who want to support the arts and who value what I and other artists do.  I am so grateful for everyone who has helped me over the years - not only through funding, but through free materials, watching my kids while I finish that painting, helping me in the studio, and just showing up to my exhibitions. 
I can't do this alone, but a community of art advocates can. You are my community, and I am so grateful for your support.  Thank you!
For those of you who are able to donate to this trip, I'd like to give you a small gift in return. Handmade thank you cards, tea bag quilts and hand embellished prints are all available at different levels of donation. Each item is one of a kind, and it's my way of showing you my appreciation.
As I said, I feel called to this profession - it's how I contribute to our culture. But with opportunities come challenges. I have a lot of exhibitions this year, and I need funding and support to make art, frame it, ship it and travel to gallery openings. It all begins at Hambidge.
 
Others ways you can help
You might not able to contribute right now. That's okay! One way you can help is to get the word out! Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or email. There are nifty little icons to the right of the pink "Back It" button that makes sharing super easy. 
 
Got questions?
Don't hesitate to contact me either through Indiegogo, or at mandycano.v@gmail.com. I welcome your questions and hope to hear from you.

story:
Short Summary

Toronto is the city we call home; it’s bursting with talent and we want to be there to provide that talent with a professional platform. Kirsti Langen & Mohammed Yassin here, two Toronto-bred artists involved in the local arts scene and we’re looking to contribute in a different way. Together we’ve started FountainHead, an arts exhibition series geared towards the youth of Toronto. The arts are always first to face funding cuts from our various levels of government and the first to suffer from these cuts tends to be the youth. Instead of waiting for a change from the government, we’re turning to you to help us support the art of the youth. We are planning to have our first exhibition this August and need your financial help. Your money will be going towards securing a downtown Toronto venue, decorations to be used inside the gallery, show programs for the public to take home, marketing and promotion of the event and our next exhibition.


Kirsti Langen is a Ryerson graduate with a BFA and is currently working towards her MDes at OCADU. In 2013, she was one of four coordinators for Maximum Exposure, Ryerson's Photography end of year art show. Mohammed Yassin is a Ryerson Sociology student and lead vocalist of the Toronto-based band The Beaudifulhors. He has been independently organizing and hosting a monthly music showcase series in Toronto since late 2013.

What We Need & What You Get

We have put together a budget that details what we need for one exhibition. Our end fundraising goal will support two exhibitions. Contingency costs will cover shipping costs for the rewards given to our donors and any unforeseen expenses.

Venue: $1000

Marketing & Promotion: $500

Show Programs: $500

Decorations: $200

Food & Drinks: $150

Contingency: $150

Beyond the satisfaction of knowing you are supporting a good cause and also being able to attend the exhibition, you can find what you will get at each level of donation on the right side of this page.

Picture of India Photograph below.


Picture of typography piece below.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! You can also help us by telling your friends about FountainHead, Both on-line and offline. Go ahead and follow us on our social media platforms if you are not already and come meet us this August!

story:
Our Wine - Pink Doesn’t Equal Sweet & Great Rosé Doesn’t Just Come From France

Paper Planes is an authentic California rosé. Born from vines in the Russian River Valley, our wine and the people who make it are distinctly, and exceptionally, Californian. We want to celebrate what makes a California rosé unique. Made from 100% pinot noir, the cool climate allows our grapes to fully ripen and develop their flavors without getting too fruity or sweet. Paper Planes will be dry, bright, fresh, slightly floral and crisp, with a complexity that comes from blending pinot noir from several different vineyards across the valley.

Who We Are - Laura Maguire + Kyle Gabriel (+ our mascot, Boomer)


A Note From Laura -

Wine has always been a big part of my life, but growing up in Napa Valley I took it for granted. When Kyle and I met in college, I happily tagged along as his interest in craft beer led us to seek out unique wines. Seeing his love of wine develop reinvigorated a passion that I thought was just a small part of me. Since we met six years ago, we’ve loved entertaining and introducing friends to new wines, and rosé is always our go-to. It’s light, versatile and complex, but doesn’t take itself too seriously. To us, wine is about more than great quality and taste; it's about sharing it with our friends and creating lasting memories together. No other wine does this better than rosé. It’s our passion for rosé and creating these experiences that made us realize we had to make Paper Planes, so we could share this on a larger scale.


Why Rosé? It’s Not An After Thought, It’s Our Only Thought

Two years ago, after drinking our way through just about every California rosé there was, we started thinking about why, despite how great it is, does rosé still seem to be an afterthought? We thought, “Maybe winemakers aren’t really interested,” or “Maybe people still have misconceptions about rosé.” In the end, it didn’t matter. All that did matter is that for us, rosé isn’t an afterthought - it's our only thought. We're proud to be the first winery in the Russian River Valley to make exclusively rosé. With Paper Planes, we aren’t just setting out to make a product that the growing number of rosé drinkers will love, but one that will convert non-rosé drinkers everywhere.


Great Wine and Great Company - What It’s All About

We are part of the next generation of wine drinkers. We crave adventure and innovation in our wines, and we revel in the simple moments around a communal table. Whether it’s a backyard dinner party, a spontaneous cocktail hour, or an afternoon picnic in the park, Paper Planes is the perfect complement to easy-going enjoyment, and we hope that it will inspire spirited connections in simple moments.


Our Progress - We’re Harvesting!

We’re so happy to be sourcing our fruit from winegrowers who we’ve known for years. We’ve also found the facility where we’re going to make the wine, formed our LLC & trademark, created our label and website, and ordered all the materials like glass, corks and boxes. We’re crowdfunding to raise money to produce the initial batch which we’re harvesting this month. Our goal, with your help, is to make 300 cases.


Your Contribution

Your contribution will help us buy the physical things we need to make our first batch. The first vintage of Paper Planes Rosé will be available February of 2015. Due to strict state laws, we aren’t distributing outside of California this year, but we plan to expand with our next vintage! 

‪Here’s where you’re contribution is going:‬ 

•  ‪Barrels: $500‬

•  ‪Labels: $3,000‬

•  ‪Corks: $2,000‬

•  Glass + Boxes: $2,500 


The People Who Made It Happen:

Label designed by Project M Plus

Gift Baskets provided courtesy of Bundles Gift Co. 

Video by Sam Stratton

Song: "Catacombs" by Bird to Beast - courtesy of MUK Records / Hitcher Music 

Thank you to our friends and family for all your help + support! 

Perks!

Gift Basket from Bundles Gift Co. 

T Shirts

Go Vino Wine Glasses

             

Our Label

story:
Thames: Dark River, Still Shining is a photography project documenting people and communities living along the course of the River Thames from the source to the sea, examining their connections to the river and surrounding landscape. The resulting photographs will form a touring exhibition in the last 2 weeks of August 2014 stopping at 8 locations along the river from Oxford to Walton-on-Thames and ending in London where the images will be exhibited during September in conjunction with 'Totally Thames'. I have arranged all the touring and exhibition details but I need your help to cover printing, material and transportation costs and to help with the production of a limited edition book, please help me to make my dream a reality! 

The project has been over two and half years in the making; it started because of my interest in ‘the photographic journey’ and how this can be used as a method to explore relationships between people and their surroundings.  The idea for this project came from my desire to undertake a photographic trip with a preformed route, which could give the project a focused narrative. My grandparents lived by the Thames for 40 years, so I felt the urge to explore an area that has a personal significance and that also covers many regions previously unknown to me; which are connected by a unifying force. I began by walking sections of the Thames path, exploring the different areas and photographing the people I met along the way. Through each meeting I began to understand more about the way the river interconnects with peoples lives and the spirituality felt by having a deep connection to the Thames.

The longest river entirely in England; The Thames is steeped in tradition and culture, described by some as being 'Liquid History' it is an inspiration to artists and musicians, a river of leisure, of sport and a place people call home. Having now covered the entire route of the river I want to bring my photographs to as wide an audience as possible and you can help me do this by supporting the project!


What I Need & What You Get

My goal is to exhibit the photographs at 8 locations along the river and at the Embassy Tea Gallery in the Bankside area of London, near Tate Modern, and to produce a photobook to accompany the exhibition. I have arranged a mixture of venues including riverside pubs, arts centers and Environment Agency locks. By exhibiting in a variety of venues, many of them next to the river itself, I hope to enhance the artistic experience for audiences and bring the images to life by placing them within the areas where the pictures where taken. I also really like the idea of exhibiting in the open air or in place not normally associated with exhibitions as this allows different types of audiences to become engaged with the work.

I need to build 4 freestanding exhibition boards on which I will display the images at the touring locations.  The pictures will be shown at each venue for one night only, so I need to be flexible and the boards will provide a pre-prepared space on which to show the images.

The photographs will be printed and mounted on aluminum for durability as they will be transported and re-hung a number of times and I will also need to hire a large van to transport everything needed for these exhibitions. Your donations will cover the cost of making and printing a limited edition photo book, as well as marketing and promotional costs. Every pound donated will bring me one step closer to being able to show my project to an audience and the more I can raise the better the exhibition experience will be for everyone, thank you so much for your support! 

In return for your kind support I am offering a number of perks or gifts, including a set of 4x 6x6 inch postcards, 4 different sizes of prints, 2 of which will be framed  (you can choose your favourite image from the exhibition)  and of course the photobook! All perks come with a personal thank you note


Set of 4 Postcards:


Sample page layout from the book:


The Impact

Through the exhibition and book I aim to promote the unifying force of The Thames and highlight the importance of preserving all the eccentricities of life by the river, as well as celebrating its rich history, culture and traditions. All the participants will be invited to the exhibitions to share their experiences and stories and I have organised guest speakers and live music at many of the events. The exhibitions are being promoted by 'Totally Thames' and will form part of their events schedule in August and September. During the tour I will be linking up with the Source to Sea River Relay and my exhibitions will link up with the relay at certain points along the river. You can read more about Totally Thames and River Relay here:

www.totallythames.org/events/info/source-to-sea-river-relay

"Totally Thames - an exciting new, month-long arts and cultural celebration of London’s river" 


Tour Schedule:

Town

Venue

Date of Exhibition

Oxford

The Isis Farmhouse Pub

Thurs 21st August

Abingdon

The Old Anchor Pub

Friday 22nd August

Wallingford

The Boathouse Pub

Saturday 23rd August

Reading

Mapledurham Lock

Sunday 24th August

Henley

River and Rowing Museum

Monday 25th August

Maidenhead

Boulters Lock

Tuesday 26th August

Windsor

The Firestation Arts Centre

Thursday 28th August

Walton-on-Thames

Riverhouse Arts Centre

Friday 29th August

London

Embassy Tea Gallery, Bankside

4th – 7th September

Risks & Challenges

The main obstacles I face are time and money. I have been planning the exhibitions for over 6 months, everything is organised and has been thoroughly researched, I just need a little bit of help from all of you...


Other Ways You Can Help

Any contribution is hugely valuable to the project so please share with anyone you feel would be interested!

story:
Robot Turtle At Car.

This is a giantic disco two-headed turtle. With lots of lights. We are building an interactive piece everone on the Playa can enjoy. We have over ten years experince bringing funky beats to Burning Man. Now we are taking to the next level and we want EVERYONE to enjoy the Robot Turble. 

A car of this scale is huge. Obciously, it's going to The Black Desert to bring joy to everyone who wants to explore the turtle, dance, and have fin on an enormouse TURTLE!

Yes we truly mean everyone. Part of our inspiration for the projec came from Dr. JJ Jones, resident DJ for many theme camps,  sound camps. He realized that we NEEDED to put a ramp on the car so everyone coukld hop on the Robot Turle as easily as possilbe. T

hat is why we have launched this fundraiser. We want to finsh our project so EVERYONE can enjoy rocking our on our Robot Turtle at Buriing Man, 2013. 

We are also experimenting with solar power and various ways to bring this giantic turtle to the Playa while doing our best to leave as little trace as possible. 

We are making a kick ass, tumping, turtle out of a minvan. We want to take you on the car for some awesome 

It used to be a minivan! 

Robot Turtle started out as an 93' Astro Van, and has come together with layers of uni-strut, conduit, and ply wood.  After making sure our structe is sturdy for you playa folk we've made  ten  A turtle shell will protect use from harsh winds and sun. The driver has been moved above the engine block 8 ft to ensure maximum visablity. Our 2 headed TurtleBot will be covered in bright green turtleskin and fuzzy seating for a comfy smoth ride.   

 Our Mutant Robot Turtle would be great addition to this years community bring fun interaction to all those looking for a ride, or a by stander looking at a 20 ft fully lit Disco Robot Turtle for the first time. 

To our donors  

Our contributors will not only receive the gift of having our TurtleBot on playa for a whole fun filled week of shenanigans. But depending on your contribution you can receive up to 4 different levels of TurtleBot swag, or a Turtle night on the playa including drinks, food, fun.

 This project like many other playa pieces of art, has been completely funded out of our own pockets. We've now reached a point were  our funds have depleted completely, but we are oh so close to bring our mutant creature to life on the playa. 

 The monies we will receive will go towards, lighting, foam and fabric for seating and Turtle Skin, paint (also for turtle skin), and transportation to get to and from the Playa. 

If we can reach our goal of $1000 dollars we'll be able to get TurtleBot to this years Burn, anything over will just make it that much more detailed to what we've envisioned as a Playa Robot Turtle. 

 If for any reason we do not receive our full amount anything contributed will still go towards TurtleBot and we will continue to work on him throughout the year till he's fully ready. 

Thank You! 

 Any and all contributions, including word of mouth means a great deal to us, Thank you to my family and friends for helping me bring this project to light with your time, effort, money, support, and the countless times you've heard me dream of this Mutant creation. I can't wait to see the art of my imagination coming to life and all of you out on the Playa this year. 

Thank you
story_txt:
Robot Turtle At Car.
This is a giantic disco two-headed turtle. With lots of lights. We are building an interactive piece everone on the Playa can enjoy. We have over ten years experince bringing funky beats to Burning Man. Now we are taking to the next level and we want EVERYONE to enjoy the Robot Turble. 
A car of this scale is huge. Obciously, it's going to The Black Desert to bring joy to everyone who wants to explore the turtle, dance, and have fin on an enormouse TURTLE!
Yes we truly mean everyone. Part of our inspiration for the projec came from Dr. JJ Jones, resident DJ for many theme camps,  sound camps. He realized that we NEEDED to put a ramp on the car so everyone coukld hop on the Robot Turle as easily as possilbe. T
hat is why we have launched this fundraiser. We want to finsh our project so EVERYONE can enjoy rocking our on our Robot Turtle at Buriing Man, 2013. 
We are also experimenting with solar power and various ways to bring this giantic turtle to the Playa while doing our best to leave as little trace as possible. 
We are making a kick ass, tumping, turtle out of a minvan. We want to take you on the car for some awesome 
It used to be a minivan! 
Robot Turtle started out as an 93' Astro Van, and has come together with layers of uni-strut, conduit, and ply wood.  After making sure our structe is sturdy for you playa folk we've made  ten  A turtle shell will protect use from harsh winds and sun. The driver has been moved above the engine block 8 ft to ensure maximum visablity. Our 2 headed TurtleBot will be covered in bright green turtleskin and fuzzy seating for a comfy smoth ride.   
 Our Mutant Robot Turtle would be great addition to this years community bring fun interaction to all those looking for a ride, or a by stander looking at a 20 ft fully lit Disco Robot Turtle for the first time. 
To our donors  
Our contributors will not only receive the gift of having our TurtleBot on playa for a whole fun filled week of shenanigans. But depending on your contribution you can receive up to 4 different levels of TurtleBot swag, or a Turtle night on the playa including drinks, food, fun.
 This project like many other playa pieces of art, has been completely funded out of our own pockets. We've now reached a point were  our funds have depleted completely, but we are oh so close to bring our mutant creature to life on the playa. 
 The monies we will receive will go towards, lighting, foam and fabric for seating and Turtle Skin, paint (also for turtle skin), and transportation to get to and from the Playa. 
If we can reach our goal of $1000 dollars we'll be able to get TurtleBot to this years Burn, anything over will just make it that much more detailed to what we've envisioned as a Playa Robot Turtle. 
 If for any reason we do not receive our full amount anything contributed will still go towards TurtleBot and we will continue to work on him throughout the year till he's fully ready. 
Thank You! 
 Any and all contributions, including word of mouth means a great deal to us, Thank you to my family and friends for helping me bring this project to light with your time, effort, money, support, and the countless times you've heard me dream of this Mutant creation. I can't wait to see the art of my imagination coming to life and all of you out on the Playa this year. 
Thank you

story:
Who am I and what do I need from you?

My name is Sarah Smith. My bachelors is in Landscape Design and I also spent three years in school for Architecture. Through out this seven year period I discovered a passion for ink drawing, watercolor, and photography.

 

I moved to the Seattle, Washington area a little less than a year ago to find work in my degree field.

Here in lies the catch. I owe the school and my Perkins loans people money. This has created a hold on my account, which in turn makes it to where I can not get my transcripts.  After hundreds of resume's and applications placed, I still have not been able to find a job in my degree field. Much of this is due to my lack of ability to provide transcripts to prove I even went to school, and my lack of the proper equipment with which to take quality photographs of my work, In case you guys are wondering, I do have a job! I am lucky enough to work as a manager at a retail store, but this is not where my passion lies.

 

 

The Transparent Details...

So how much do I need? 

My goal is $5500.

  • $1,900 to pay off my final semester of school
  • $700 to pay off the back due amount on my Perkins loans
  • $1300 for a Nikon D300 body
    • I chose this model due to its weatherproofing since much of my photography is done in inclement weather. Also, it is 12.3 megapixels which is a good midrange camera for my needs.
  • $700 for a Nikorr 24-85mm f2.8-4 lens
  • $400 for a Nikon 55mm f/2.8 Micro lens for good macro shots
  • The remaining $500 is for Indiegogo's percentage and for taxes I will have to pay on your donations.

If I get more than I have asked for, I would like to get a Nikon 105mm VR macro lens instead, but it runs about $800.

So what's in it for you?

Other than knowing that you are helping me to be able to further my goals with my design/photography/career and "help a starving artist", I have a few incentives for you.

As detailed on the right, depending on your donation, I am willing to give prints of my drawings, photographs, and possibly landscape design plan drawings.  For higher donations, I also will send you an original drawing,watercolor or photograph of my choosing (you can specify which media type is your preference).

Thank you so much for your time and thank you in advance for your help!

 

I had a nice power point presentation done, but couldnt figure out how to upload it to youtube. Sorry!

story:
What's this campaign about?

This is my first year being given an opportunity to have my photography presented in a gallery in Wynwood during Art Basel- Miami. For those of you who are not familiar with what Art Basel is, it is a 4-day event where over 250 of the world's leading galleries show the work of masters of art to newly emerging artists like myself with over 50,000 people including artists, collectors, enthusiasts, and curators in attendance. For more details/information on Art Basel you can visit their website: Art Basel Miami Beach.  For the past few months I have been working up to participate in this great event, stepping out of my boundaries and doing a series consisting of color photographs (I mostly work with black and white film). The photography that I will be displaying in Art Basel pertains to color psychology, how color affects us and what emotions we draw from seeing certain colors. If you are not familiar with my work and would like to see my photography, visit Olivia Perez Photography. 

How you can help!

Although the gallery has expressed that they really like my photographs and want to showcase my work, in order for it to be displayed I must rent out the space for the month of December which is where I could use your help! The costs for processing film, printing, and framing alone have been and are very draining financially, and the cost of renting the space for the month is over $1200. Anything you can contribute would help me out exponentially, $1, $2, seriously anything you can afford or would like to contribute to help making my dreams come true! I know a lot of people are tight on money so even if you can't contribute anything, pass the word along and share this campaign with others :) **you can use the indiegogo share tools to promote on facebook and other websites

How to claim your perk

If you donate $25 or more, email oliviasartbaselfundraiser@gmail.com with your name, mailing address, and what picture you would like to receive. All pictures will be sent out once my campaign time limit is up (December 2) and if my goal is reached before that date then they will be sent out earlier :)

What you would be helping me accomplish?

For the many years that I have been passionate about doing photography, these past 2 years have really been the first time I've been more open and motivated with my photographs; I've been sharing my work in art shows or online and have been constantly creating, becoming more comfortable with exposing what I do to the world, or at least anyone who is willing to enjoy them and relate. Getting the exposure which Art Basel provides with it's over 50,000 attendees is more than I could have ever imagined or hoped for. By donating money you will be helping me to share my art, myself, with not only people in Miami, or Florida, or even the U.S. but people from all over the world and I can feel nothing but the highest gratitude and appreciation for those who do and even those who share. Thank you!

story:
Welcome to The Mandela Poster Project! I'm Robbie Conal, that “guerrilla poster guy.” Since 1986 (“MEN WITH NO LIPS,”) I’ve done over 90 satirical street posters, mostly of too powerful ugly old men in suits and ties. I do an original oil painting, then get 1000’s of posters printed up. With the help of terrific local volunteer guerrilla-postering crews, I put them up on city streets around the country. 

But this time is different. A few months ago, our good friends Tom Harding & Dorothy Garcia, from non-profit ARTAIDSART.ORG based in Cape Town, South Africa, asked me if I would paint a positive, celebratory street poster of Nelson Mandela. I haven’t done many positive portraits. But the few I have made, (including WATCHING, WAITING, DREAMING of Gandhi, The Dalai Lama, and Martin Luther King, Jr.) have been much more soulful fun for me, and everybody else! 

This portrait of Mandela is especially meaningful to me. During the past year we all became sadly aware that Nelson Mandela had fallen very ill. We felt that making a positive portrait of him, and distributing it with the help of ARTAIDSART.ORG in South Africa and around the US, could be a powerful way of celebrating his life, honoring his courage, and engaging people in conversation about his enormous and ultimately successful struggle to overcome the oppression of Apartheid in South Africa. Thus The Mandela Poster Project was born.

  

Most people know Mandela fought long and hard to abolish Apartheid. Most know he was the first black African elected to the Presidency of South Africa. All South Africans know Mandela loved music and dancing (doing his signature "Madiba Shuffle," at every public appearance). Mandela once said, "Music and dance are what make me at peace with the world, and at peace with myself." When I heard this (on a You Tube video), it really moved and inspired me personally. How someone who was imprisoned–for more than 27 years–for resisting his government’s harsh policy of Apartheid, could still find optimism and humanity through music and dance, that just blew my mind!

"WALKING" AND "DANCING": THE MANDELA POSTER PROJECT

We decided to print not one, but two matching versions of the Nelson Mandela poster. “WALKING”, is a reference to Mandela’s autobiography, “Long Walk to Freedom.” “DANCING,” is in honor of the “Madiba Shuffle.” With your support over 5,000 posters will be sent to Cape Town, South Africa in the next few months, courtesy of ARTAIDSART.ORG. There, with the help of its eKhaya EKasi Art & Education Center members and partners, the posters are being distributed for free throughout townships surrounding Cape Town. Additionally, I’ll take them “on tour” to cities around the US. With your help we hope to cover Los Angeles, the Bay Area, Seattle, Chicago, New York, and Washington DC during the coming months.

YOUR SUPPORT MEANS THE WORLD TO US!

This is the biggest project we’ve ever undertaken. To ensure that we achieve all we’ve set out to do, we’ve created this Indiegogo campaign to ask for your support. Your tax-deductible contribution will help cover the major costs of printing 9,500 posters, as well as packing and shipping expenses to Cape Town, South Africa and across the US. 

Also, 50% of any funds raised beyond our initial goal of $10,000, will go to serve the members of eKhaya eKasi Art & Education Center, ARTAIDSART’s non-profit outpost in one of the largest townships in the world, just outside of Cape Town. Their creative arts, literacy, and entrepreneurship programs encourage self-esteem and self-expression, and provide the financial education needed to help people pull themselves out of poverty. The other 50% will help us spread Mandela posters to even more cities and towns across America! 

Humanity is not free until we’re all free of poverty. Hopefully, we can apply Mandela’s example, that of his courageous life as well as the lessons of the worldwide campaign to free him, to lead us in the right direction. We’re all in this together—and that’s the point. Ubuntu! 

WE HAVE SOME GREAT TAX-DEDUCTIBLE PERKS FOR YOU!

In return for your support we have some fantastic perks, starting with high quality, weather proof stickers of both "WALKING" and “DANCING.” We also have posters of both "WALKING" and “DANCING," personally signed and dated by Robbie Conal. We're also introducing two beautiful sets of limited-edition prints on archival paper, printed by POVevolving, in Los Angeles. Each is signed, numbered and dated by Robbie. And for those few of you who may be inclined to help out in a really big way, Robbie would be delighted to have you plus three guests (of your choosing) over for lunch and a special private tour of his L.A. art studio. All donations go to ArtAidsArt.org and are completely tax-deductible!

FEBRUARY 24TH UPDATE: WE'VE JUST ADDED A NEW PERK! T-SHIRTS! We are nearing the final days of our Indiegogo campaign, and we hope this will inspire those of you who are still on the fence to make the leap, and help us over the hump. These beautiful, soft poly/cotton blend t-shirts manufactured by Next Level, come in charcoal grey. There are only 12 WALKING T-shirts and 12 DANCING T-shirts. One size only: Men's Large, fitted. Buy it for yourself, for a friend, for a loved one; wear it anywhere. We really want you to grab one while they last, so we're throwing in a free Walking or Dancing sticker!



THANKS SO MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT! 

We know some of you may want to donate but don't have the spare cash right now. We totally understand. You can still help us out enormously by passing this fundraising project on to your friends and family. Please encourage them to make tax-deductible contributions and you just may see these posters in your town one day! 

Heartfelt thanks to all who’ve pitched in with their talents and expertise so far: David Mayes and Harry Montgomery, our incredible printers at Typecraft, Wood & Jones, Inc, in Pasadena, Doug Dearth and his amazing film crew, editor Elizabeta (Boom Boom) Betinski, designer Brian Lauzon, studio assistant Lindsay (Goldilox) Sochar, and especially Tom Harding and Dorothy Garcia of ARTAIDSART.ORG. This poster project wouldn’t have happened without their amazing inspiration, support, and encouragement. 

AND NOW WHAT HAPPENS?

Everything is ready to go. All that’s missing is you, and your own unique brand of support and encouragement. Please help us reach our financial goal by clicking on any of the goodies below. We can't wait to fill your pledges, and get Nelson Mandela up and WALKING and DANCING on the streets of America, and especially in the townships around South Africa, as soon as possible. We can't do it without YOU!

Thanks–and bunnyhugs–from Robbie Conal & Deborah Ross

WALKING and DANCING posters, stickers, and limited edition prints by Robbie Conal are just waiting to be yours.

MORE INFORMATION:

If you want to find out more about the amazing work that eKhaya eKasi Art & Education Center does for the people of Khayelitsha, one of the largest townships in South Africa, please visit and explore their websites: ArtAidsArt.org, CapeTownshipTour.com, and LovingAfrica.com.

story:
Hi Guys!

I need to get some medical tests done and the doctor is 150 miles away in one direction. This is going to cost me $30 in gas one way and I have at least 4 appointments to look forward to.

My hubs has terminal cancer and cannot work so we are asking for help. We have both worked all our lives and this is very hard for us to do but circumstances arise at times where you must do what you have to.

What proceeds that are not used for gas or meds will be used to further the goals of my wood shop. I plan to offer weaving looms with a rigid heddle in the future and I need to expand my tools to do so.

What We Need & What You Get

 I'm asking for $500 which will cover the fees for this fundraiser program and my expenses.

If you pledge $15 you will get an 18 mm crochet hook that I make on my lathe.
For $20 you will get a 25 mm hook. 

For the smaller items the price will include shipping. Larger items will have shipping added later. Shipping depends on your location.
 
Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please share the link to my campaign if you contribute or not.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
What is #TRIPTYCH?


#TRIPTYCH is an exhibition of three hilarious and haunting portraits of society and psyche: Phenomena & Existences by Daniil Kharms, SPIDERS ARE REAL! THEY'RE ALIVE AND THEY HATE YOU!! by T. Adamson, and Le Mort de Tintagiles by Maurice Maeterlinck. These three shorts are being staged by a gathering of radical performers, designers, and writers who together desire to reinvigorate the spirit of the old-avant-garde within a visual, visceral, and ecstatic production bursting with the vulgar vitality of artistic rebellion. 

Three centuries, three nations, and three billion spiders collide in a triptych of three underperformed plays which will be imagined and re-imagined this August 20-23rd @HERE 145 6th Ave. as a part of SubletSeries@HERE: Co-op, HERE's curated summer rental program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support.


August 20-23 @ 7:00pm

Buy Tickets!


What is Le Mort De Tintagiles?


Le Mort de Tintagiles by Maurice Maeterlinck. The Belgian Nobel-laureate’s eerie and devastating allegory of fate, fear, and death. Performed with a new American re-translation by T. Adamson, the play enchantingly orchestrates the  powerlessness, futility and beauty that inspired Maeterlinck's Static Drama.  Within the sickness of the castle, Tintagiles will die. 



The Competition:
3 plays. 3 campaigns. 1 show. 

While all three #Triptych plays will be presented as a single show with a shared company, each play largely functions as its own production with its own featured actors and singular production needs. SO In the spirit of friendly competition, each play will fund-raise separately to try to reach their individual goal of $500 before the other two productions.
So donate to your favorite show! Donate to your friend's show! Donate to the shows that your enemy isn't in! Donate to all three! The possibilities are endless, and all donations go towards making a night of innovative theater a reality.
To see the progress of the competition, visit triptych.me.


To donate to the other shows check out:

Phenomena & Existences


SPIDERS ARE REAL! THEY'RE ALIVE AND THEY HATE YOU!!


What We Need & What You Get

What Is The Money You're Donating Getting US?

  • #Triptych creates three sumptuous, lush theatrical worlds, rich in visual poetry and texture. From the jungles of the Leeward Antilles, to the castles of Belgium, to the phenomenal countrysides of Russia, we hope to infuse each play with exotic, beautiful style and substance.
  • We're building crazy, crazy costumes.  Necklaces. Kerchiefs. Wigs! Don't even get us started on the wigs.
  • Spiders. Billions of them.
  • The #Triptych team values our artists, and while we can't pay them nearly as much as they deserve for a month of hard work, we do hope to give all participating artists a small stipend as a message that we appreciate artistic bravery and value the struggle of creatives in all fields.
  •  Rehearsal space.
  • Glitter and surprises.
  • A Purple Jade Monkey Skull. (This is not a joke. Thanks, T. Adamson, for including that one on your props list.)
What Is The Money You're Donating Getting YOU?
  • Mad perks and mad thanks! Check out our column on the right over there! 
  • Every event has different perks, so check out all three!
  • Good vibes and good Karma! (Kharms-ma?)
  • Team Tintagiles is offering up thoughtful inspiration and soothing bedtime tales to ease your tragic worry! Tintagiles may have it rough, but there's no reason you can't add a little sunshine to your own day (and ours)!!

Who are we?

T. Adamson :: Writer/Retranslator :: plays have been performed in NYC, California, and Colorado. He is a member of Fresh Ground Pepper NYC’s Playground Playgroup and a Capricorn.

Mike Axelrod :: Actor :: is an actor, writer, and teacher, currently hiding in Brooklyn.  He's also a Bat @theFlea, where he does silly things onstage late at night and serious stuff at a decent hour.  This summer he taught theater in the Galapagos and chasing sea turtles.

Hollis Beck :: Actor :: Hollis Beck: Actor and Playwright, previously in The History of the Donner Party: A Country Musical, and Black Wizard / Blue Wizard. Writes movie reviews at the site For Your Inebriation.

Kelly Colburn :: Production Team :: is 1/2 of 2girls1asian.com, full kellycolburn.com and is the only female member of the video team at Blue Man Group. #iwokeuplikethis #triptychproducingteam

Matt Cox :: Actor :: Matt Cox is an actor, playwright, and improviser who lives in Queens. He works at a comic book store. That's it really. 

Asia Kate Dillon :: Actor :: Asia Kate Dillon is a performer living in New York City. facebook.com/asiakatedillon

Anna Abhau Elliott :: Actor :: makes shows! She's been a resident @ FGP's BRB and Rubber Repertory's Pilot Balloon Church-House and she's now chipping away on a new show about scientific espionage during the Manhattan Project. Also, she was in a Beirut music video once. www.Anna-Elliott.net

Shelley Farmer :: Actor :: Shelley Farmer just graduated from Barnard College, where she acted in and directed many Columbia University productions. She’s now wasting her Russian degree to try to become an artist. 

Joe Faustine :: Production Team :: directs loud messy plays and performs loud messy music with the Gandor Chorale. If spiders were dogs he'd have a big one.

Alex J. Gould :: Actor :: Originally from Massachusetts. Bat @theFlea. Hasn't slept since joining in 2012. Just finished performing in The Mysteries. If you missed it, there is a book called the Bible. Great read. Also, in #serials@theflea

Madeline Bugeau-Heartt :: Actor :: Madeline is a  theater artist and dreamer. She recently directed Homage, an original work which dissected celebrity worship and the supernatural. She is pumped to partake in #TRIPTYCH! 

Bryn Herdrich :: Production Team :: Director, Designer, and theater-person living in NYC. Past work seen at Danspace, the Connelly Theater, and Ars Nova's ANTFest. Coming up- a play about Subway (the chain, not the transportation). 

Cem Kocyildirim :: Production Team :: likes to be called a sculptor and his work ranges from old school  printmaking and paper sculptures to interactive digital/analog art.

Teri Madonna :: Actor ::  is a performer, sound designer, dramaturg, and creator of original work. Old films, crystals, and vegan food might be her favorite things.

Carissa Matsushima :: Production Team :: Small but mighty, with a foundation in the experimental, Carissa Matsushima finds herself dancing the African Diaspora with Choreographer Ni'Ja Whitson, singing soul, and crashing bikes in Brooklyn. 

Joel Soren :: Director :: is a Freelance Theatrical Artist in NYC. He's currently directing #Serials@theFlea, has travelled with Theatre-Mitu to India, to BRB with FGP, and worked for the world's foremost expert on crystal skulls @ the Smithsonian Museum of Natural History.

Mike Wesolowski :: Production Team :: Off-off-b'way specialist! Under St Marks (monthly show!), Atlantic, Bridge, Clarion, Stage Left, 133AC, 45th, Magnet, PIT, Secret, etc... MngDir, Grey Room NYC



Graphic & Web Design: Cem Kocyildirim
story_txt:
What is #TRIPTYCH?

#TRIPTYCH is an exhibition of three hilarious and haunting portraits of society and psyche: Phenomena & Existences by Daniil Kharms, SPIDERS ARE REAL! THEY'RE ALIVE AND THEY HATE YOU!! by T. Adamson, and Le Mort de Tintagiles by
 Maurice Maeterlinck. These three shorts are being staged by a gathering
 of radical performers, designers, and writers who together desire to 
reinvigorate the spirit of the old-avant-garde within a visual, 
visceral, and ecstatic production bursting with the vulgar vitality of 
artistic rebellion. 
Three centuries, three nations, and three billion spiders collide in a
 triptych of three underperformed plays which will be imagined 
and re-imagined this August 20-23rd @HERE 145 6th Ave. as a part of SubletSeries@HERE: Co-op, HERE's curated summer rental program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support.


August 20-23 @ 7:00pm
Buy Tickets!

What is Le Mort De Tintagiles?

Le Mort de Tintagiles by Maurice Maeterlinck. The Belgian Nobel-laureate’s eerie and devastating allegory of fate, fear, and death. Performed with a new American re-translation by T. Adamson, the play enchantingly orchestrates the  powerlessness, futility and beauty that inspired Maeterlinck's Static Drama.  Within the sickness of the castle, Tintagiles will die. 






The Competition:3 plays. 3 campaigns. 1 show. 



While all three #Triptych plays will be presented as a single show with a shared company, each play largely functions as its own production with its own featured actors and singular production needs. SO In the spirit of friendly competition, each play will fund-raise separately to try to reach their individual goal of $500 before the other two productions.

story:
I'm looking to raise $3500 to fund the next few issues of my (maga)zine Vaein, which focuses on empowering young LGBTQ people and artists.

The money raised towards this project will go towards professionally printing the next few issues that I'm currently working on putting together. This also includes paying the appropriate artists and contributors, distributing it, and putting on events so that they can be released. This project is to jumpstart zine "merchandising" and once the zines are made I intend to go forward from there with things like promotion. The money made off of these zine sales will be put back into subsequent issues, and as this continues to happen, it is my hope that demand and exposure for the zine will continue to grow.

Why is it necessary to provide creative spaces for young LGBTQ people?

While the experiences of a young gay teenager are vastly different to someone who is, for example, coming out as a young trans person, the opportunities not offered to them are just as limited. 
Young LGBTQ people of all kinds experience a dissociation from the kind of people they see being represented in mainstream media, and often the things they are going through are not portrayed in a relatable way. This is why creating our own media can be a very powerful tool.
The suicides of young teens like Leelah Acorn have left a bitter sting on our public consciousness. By giving a platform to artists and young creators we can make them feel like their contributions and lives are worthy just like everyone elses. Even for those LGBTQ people who are not creative, by reading the zine and witnessing it come to life, they will respond to narratives that are life affirming to them and that make them feel less alone. Making a zine will not cure the depression of every young queer person, but it certainly is a step in the right direction.

This is where the indiegogo benefits you!

The rewards for this project include a lot of art that I myself have designed (which was also a big part of the first two zines) stickers, posters, copies of the mag, and other such rewards donated by my very talented friends, many of whom have been involved with making this zine possible. I ultimately need $3500 to guarantee I can get these professionally printed the way I would like them to be. I hope to produce a few hundred this way at the very least, for distribution around Australia. An LGBTQ zine for young people is hard to find and much of the media does not relate to youth or create spaces that are safe or humanising for them, which is why a collaborative, open project like a zine can have so much potential.

(Sorry for saying "um" so much and waving my hands around, I might seem uncertain but that's just because I feel odd doing videos. I'm very enthusiastic about this project!)
