story:
EMAIL

If you need to get ahold of me, please contact me at naomiromero4@gmail.com! :) Please include your full name, address you used to pledge, and updated address!

---------------------------------------


UPDATE!

Tri colored corgis are now 100% funded! Thank you all so much! Once the campaign is over, everyone will be receiving a survey. It will ask to confirm your address and confirm what color of corgi you want! :)

---------------

Hi! My name is Naomi Romero and I am illustrator and corgi enthusiast. I am lucky enough to work from home as a freelance children's illustrator for the Bright Agency, as well as working on cool projects from BOOM! Studios and even character design for an upcoming movie that will hit theaters soon! I have started selling at conventions last year in order to get myself out there and meet wonderful people. People often ask me if I would ever make a plush based off of my work. The thought has always been in my mind and I wanted to bring this dream to life. I am a crazy corgi enthusiast, having one of my very own! Artists usually know me as a corgi artist and I couldn't think of anything better than to create a corgi plush based off of my style!

The plush is based off the following illustration!

Kiernan Sjursen-Lien helped me plushify my illustration in an easy to read turn around! They did a wonderful job translating my illustration into something Shine Down Productions can immediately turn into a plush.

After approaching Shine Down Productions and working with them closely, I can now show the world my corgi plush prototype! This incredibly cuddly plush is made out of ultra soft minky fabric and stuffed just right, making it perfect for hugging! It stands 8 inches tall from head to paws and 11 inches tall with ears! It features beautifully embroidered details and interfacing in the ears, to ensure they stand up right and happy. 


This is a photo provided from Shine Down Productions!

Producing a professional plush is no easy feat and it can be quite expensive. In order to bring 500 of these corgis to their new owners, I need your help! 

Indigogo Campaign Costs

Here is the breakdown on costs.

$5620 production costs, which includes the actual costs of making the plush and shipping from the company to me.

$300 boxes to ship your plush in.

$592 Indiegogo fees.

In order to combat costs, I am having each backer pay for shipping. 

Every dollar helps bring this little corgi to life! :) You can pledge as much as little or as you wish. 

How do I get a plush?

It's easy! Just pledge click the appropriate pledge amount for the amount of corgis you want!

Risks and Challenges

The prototype is completed and ready to go into production. Once Shine Down Productions is paid, the corgi army will ensue. At this point, unforeseen delays may occur which are out of my control, including slower production times, shipping.etc. Rest assured that your plush will make it to you in one piece!

Thank you so much!

Frequently Asked Questions

--------------------

The Campaign is already way more than double! Can't you use that to fund the tri?

Contrary to believe, the campaign cash pool isn't what it seems! All the shipping is added to the pool so it looks a lot larger than it should be! I believe Kickstarter doesn't do this, which makes it a lot easier to figure out how much money the campaign actually raised!

Can I choose what colored corgi I want once the campaign is over?

YES! Once the campaign is over and IF the tri colored corgi is funded, you can choose which one you want once I send out a survey! :) If you  ordered more than one, you can mix and match!

Can you add tails?

I am trying my best to work with the plush company to add tails. It is hard since it requires me to order an additional 500 corgis with tails! I am trying, though, since I would love to satisfy the cardigan corgi crowd!

Can you make this colored corgi?

I will need to order 500 additional corgis in order to honor any other colors! I wish I could but our apartment is too small! :) However, if the demand is high, we will rent storage space and see if we can make other colors available!

story:
Dear Friends, Family, Colleagues, and Peers,

We have been fortunate enough to receive confirmation that two spaces have agreed to host our exhibition, Futurographies, in Cambodia and France but we need your help to get there!!!

Futurographies, which represents 10 months of research and interdisciplinary collaboration among five students and three faculty advisors from The New School, opened in New York this past month with resounding success and we can’t wait to share this collection abroad.  

Cambodia, France and the U.S. share histories of violence— colonial repression, war, bombing campaigns, genocide, migrations of refugees, deportations, and forced “repatriations.”  Futurographies opens up the contested terrain of future-driven creativity that has always existed both alongside and as part of it, featuring photographs, books, sculptures, music videos, models, documents and installations from U.S., Cambodian and French artists.

As the exhibition aims to illuminate the entwined histories of these three locations, we believe that presenting it to audiences in all 3 countries is a unique and integral component of its design.

With your support, this show will be moving from New York to the Sa Sa Bassac Gallery in Phnom Penh in February ’16 and the Parsons Paris Gallery in April ’16.  Your contribution will help us to ship these amazing artworks and to support some local programming.  We’ve even got some advance press in Phnom Penh that you can read here. 

The artists in the exhibition are Binh Danh, Genealogy of Bassac Group/Pen Sereypagna, The Cambodian Space Project, Chath Piersath, Eng Rithchandaneth, Charles Fox, Stuart Isett, Klap Ya Handz/Sok “Cream” Visal, Komlang Khmer, Dave Kyu, Roland Neveu, Michelle Nugent, Peuo Tuy, Pete Pin, Monica Sok, Studio Revolt/Anida Yoeu Ali, and Yim Maline.

This exhibition wouldn’t be possible without your support and we are incredibly grateful to be supported by such a generous and inspiring community.
 

THANK YOU

story:
Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder, more specifically a movement disorder, that affects the cells of the brain that control muscle movement. These cells located deep in a section of the brain called the substantia nigra, produce an important nuerotransmitter called dopamine. Dopamine is important because it is the chemical messenger used to send signals from the brain to the muscles to complete smooth, cooridnated movements. When 80% of these dopamine producing cells have died, symptoms of Parkinson's disease appear. The cause of death of these dopamine producing cells is still unknown.

Who Gets Parkinson's Disease?

It is estimated that approximately 1.5 million Americans are currently living with a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease. Estimates also show that that there are 60,000 individuals newly diagnosed each year or one person every nine minutes. Parkinson's disease affects men and women in equal numbers and shows no preference to ethnicity, race or socioeconomic status. While the average age of onset is age 55, 15% of those diagnosed with Parkinson's disease are under the age of 50.  (From Houston Area Parkinson Society website)

My Dad was diagnosed 4 years ago with Parkinson's Disease.  I've been trying to come up with an fun, exciting, informational way to raise money for Parkinson's Disease that also appealed to my love for the camera.  The Houston Area Parkinson Society serves the area with information and patient programs & services.  All proceedes from this calendar will go to HAPS.
story_txt:
Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder, more specifically a movement disorder, that affects the cells of the brain that control muscle movement. These cells located deep in a section of the brain called the substantia nigra, produce an important nuerotransmitter called dopamine. Dopamine is important because it is the chemical messenger used to send signals from the brain to the muscles to complete smooth, cooridnated movements. When 80% of these dopamine producing cells have died, symptoms of Parkinson's disease appear. The cause of death of these dopamine producing cells is still unknown.
Who Gets Parkinson's Disease?
It is estimated that approximately 1.5 million Americans are currently living with a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease. Estimates also show that that there are 60,000 individuals newly diagnosed each year or one person every nine minutes. Parkinson's disease affects men and women in equal numbers and shows no preference to ethnicity, race or socioeconomic status. While the average age of onset is age 55, 15% of those diagnosed with Parkinson's disease are under the age of 50.  (From Houston Area Parkinson Society website)
My Dad was diagnosed 4 years ago with Parkinson's Disease.  I've been trying to come up with an fun, exciting, informational way to raise money for Parkinson's Disease that also appealed to my love for the camera.  The Houston Area Parkinson Society serves the area with information and patient programs & services.  All proceedes from this calendar will go to HAPS.

story:
Me&Me Partners is: 

> A creative studio based in Rome, that operates in Italy and abroad. 

> An international cooperative platform between young creative intrapreneurs and artists. 

> A strong union that constantly originates new possibilities and opportunities. 

> An existing reality that operates in creative fields : architecture, multimedia and performing arts. 

You can take a look at our work and projects here: www.meandmepartners.com

 

Me&Me runs a cultural promotion centre: APP Arti Performative Pietralata, 

APP’s objectives are: 

> The promotion of art and culture 

> The creation of links between people in search for collaborations 

The key concepts are creativity, exchange, education and entertainment.

You can take a look at APP here:

https://www.facebook.com/pages/APP-Arti-Performative-Pietralata/27833414222344 

 

10-13 May APP will be hosting its first significant event : 

EAST : Oriental festival 

Performances & workshops. 5 disciplines, 4 days, 1 space. 

From India Ashtanga yoga, Kathak dance and Kathakali theatre; from Japan Butoh dance. 

11 highly qualified artists dedicated to oriental disciplines have been invited to Rome from India, Italy, UK and Switzerland.

During the day, the workshops will rotate; in the evening the guest artists’ performances will take place.

This is EAST: http://eastfestival.blogspot.it/

 

EAST is quite ambitious and we have decided to launch it without official fundings.

Time flies and we need to get active to give life to APP.

This is the reason why we are directing to you through this alternative channel. 


YOU can become a promoter of the festival and an APP supporter in a very simple way:

By buying the tickets to the performances or paying the participation fee to the workshops in advance. 

As you will see the benefit is an incredible discount on the original prices of tickets and fees. 

If you think about it, is a smart way of helping us ;) 


Our goal is to reach 2500€ to cover the basic costs of the festival:

> Print of the the diffusion material: flyers, posters, depliants.

> Audio and video equipment rental. 

> Travel tickets, lodging and cachè for the guest artists. 


Whatever amount we get will be destined to cover part of these costs. 

 

If we manage to reach our goal be sure we will let the world know!

As a collaborator you will have contributed to an initiative that is the concrete proofthat alternative strategies work. 

It is possible to give life to projects in a self-sufficient and dynamic way.

 

Thanks to the collaboration of all the people that as us believe that the promotion of art and culture creates a richer diverse society where EVERYONE is given a chance to go for his/her own passion and unicity!

story:
//////////9th Shanghai Biennale 2012\\\\\\\\\\\\

"For some time, effectively for some years, I have been playing with the idea of articulating life's spaces - bios - in a map"

~Walter Benjamin

Hi there, my name is Dorian Batycka and I am an artist and curator based in Hamilton, ON, Canada. My background involves attempting to challenge the boundaries of curatorial practice through nontraditional approaches to exhibition making, seeking to blur traditional distinctions between artist/curator/audience/artwork.

I have been active as a curator since 2009 and have curated numerous exhibitions in addition to developing various forms of artistic research pertaining to curatorial practice and theory.  In June 2011, I developed a curatorial method that sought to combine traditional scholarly approaches to understanding the history and origins of the Venice Biennale, with a series of actions, interventions and performances. This culminated in a DJ set at the Osloo Floating Bar (part of the Danish Pavilion), in which I used archival sound clips taken from the Historical Archives in the Giardini, in addition to a spoken-word manifesto from the guerilla-artist collective the Anonymous Stateless Immigrants, combining the two together with rhythmic drum loops, sounds and samples, in the process curating an environment of overlapping texts, art histories and experimental sounds.

Since then, I have been active in a variety of different contexts. In September 2011, I co-founded an artist-run project space called Temporary Projects located in the diverse James North neighborhood downtown Hamilton.  Recently, I have also been invited to develop a project at La Chambre Blanche in Quebec City for an international symposium and exhibition on Network Art, which is scheduled to open October 30th 2012. My work has also been published in a variety of internationally syndicated journals and magazines including Art & Education, ArtLeaks, and Lump.

The opportunity to attend the 9th Shanghai Biennale as part of the “Academy for Reciprocal Enlightenment” is an even more recent development in my artistic life and work. The “Academy” consists of a series of workshops exploring new typologies of curatorial practice, organized by Qiu Zhijie, Jens Hoffman, Boris Groys and Johnson Chang. The “Academy” will culminate in the development of an exhibition proposal for the 10th Shanghai Biennale in 2014. An exciting opportunity for me indeed!

 The website of the Shanghai Biennale (http://2012.shanghaibiennale.org/en/) describes the program as:

“The Academy refers to a Platonic-style community of wisdom and criticism.”

“It embodies our educational philosophy: education is a self governing action by learner communities, which serve as a platform of exchanges and dissemination of opinions”

“The Shanghai Biennale 2012 will occur under the theme Reactivation, interpreting among other aspects the social mobilization and structure of community, as well as the critical role of education.”

Although the Shanghai Biennale is graciously covering the cost of the program and my accommodations throughout my stay in Shanghai, I am responsible for round-trip airfare to and from Shanghai, visa fee and living expenses (meal and local car fare), as well as the cost of materials to develop any new projects/art works while I am there.

In order to participate in the 9th Shanghai Biennale, I will therefore need to raise enough money to cover the cost of my flight to Shanghai and back, along with associated Visa costs. The remaining expenses including meal and local travel costs along with costs associated with the realization of new art works I will incur myself.

In total, I am hoping to raise $1,500-$2,000 CDN enough to (hopefully) cover the following:

$1,200-$1,800 – round trip airfare (Toronto/Shanghai)

$100-200 – Chinese VISA fee (conditional upon how quickly I need it processed)

Please kindly consider supporting this endeavor through whatever financial contribution you are comfortable with. To make things a little more interesting, there are also some perks/giveaways I will be making to those who are able to make a contribution.

story:
Short Summary

Santa Cruz is competing in Boston at the National Poetry Slam competition from August 12-18.  We need funds, and this is just one of our fundraisers.  Let's keep Santa Cruz on the map!

What We Need & What You Get

This trip is expensive.  the total cost for the trip will be almost $2500.00.  We hope to pay for registarion and hotel for a total of $1500.00,  Our friends and family are needed in order to get this money raised.  We know people all over the US, and this is the best way for everyone who wants to help to be able to help.

The Impact

Your donation will help make sure that the voice of your friends and family are heard.  Santa Cruz is working on poems that will change the freaking World, and that change cannot happen without your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, please send us to people that can.  Every little bit counts!

story:
scrapartmagazine.com

scrapartmagazine@gmail.com

What is Scrap?

Scrap is a student-funded, student-organized art magazine comprised of student artwork and literature. It's an inclusive space for students to display their art and recieve recognition for their talents. All of us on the Scrap team are higly motivated and dedicated. We aspire to take Scrap to a city-wide level by increasing our scope for submissions and expanding our audience.

How are we going to achieve that, you ask?

We intend to print as many copies of our magazine as our funds will allow. To give you a rough idea of how many copies we need, 100 copies are $450, 200 copies are $840 and 300 copies are $1,200. We hope to print up to 300 copies, and begin to gather a base of submitting student artists at high schools all across the city by sending student representatives and sample copies to other schools.

Complete Budget Breakdown:

$1500 - indiegogo fees ($105) = $1,395

$1,395 - printing fees ($1,200) = $195

$195 - price of paper ($40) = $155

The excess $155 will be used either towards some sort of Scrap-related event (a gallery-type event, perhaps?), or towards printing even MORE copies. 

But who cares? What is the purpose of Scrap?

As I said before, Scrap is a open medium for students to submit their artwork, in all senses of the word. It will hopefully eventually be a publication that not only inspires our student following, but the the public as well.

Now I care. How can I help?

Well, you can give us your money. But if you can't donate, for whatever reason, forward the page to others. You can also send us an email or leave comments on our website, whether they're comments of encouragment or disgust, we appreciate your interest.

"The art changes--but our vision doesnt, and that's to unveil your vision." - Sonja Tsypin, Founder

 From Left to Right: Lara Finnerty-Haggerty, Ada Wolin, Odette Blaisdell, Nora Delf, Sonja Tsypin, Niki Rice, Noa Street-Sachs and Maggie Duffyx

story:
Summary

This is an opportunity to fund an extensive body of wood engraving original prints. These are not machine-made copies from a digital file. Eric Robinson, MFA engraves wood to produce a raised surface from which to print fine, oil-based artist inks onto archival printmaking papers. The resulting prints, like those of Albrecht Durer and Rembrandt Van Rijn can last as long as any painting.

Engraving is a painstaking process that yields beautifully and minutely detailed result. Eric layers multiple wood engravings to produce rich, polychromatic prints.

The body of work I have begun explores temporailty and celebrates the diversity of human life through color and the metaphor of a time piece. Some of the prints will express emotions in moments of life, others will convey a sense of personality or a life's occupation.  Some will evoke times of day or passages of seasons.

Each print Eric produces is completely unique because he combines a huge variety of colors and prints the layers in various sequences.

By supporting this work you are helping to push wood engraving, a traditionally black and white medium, to contribute to the expressive world of color. You are also promoting the thoughtful exploration of our shared, yet diverse humanity.

You will be rewarded, of course, with a real work of art (or a group of them if you want to contribute accordingly).

Contributions and Rewards

Here is how it works:

  • The wood engraving prints are border prints. The image area is 10 x 10 cm and the paper size is 14 x 14cm. There will be at least 140 prints in this series.
  • For every $99 you you contribute, you get one print of my choosing. Remember, each print is unique and beautiful. I would never give you an image that I would not be proud to hang on my own wall or in any public space. This is a discount level of contribution intended to make this project broadly accessible. The prints are truly worth the $150.
  • For every $150 you contribute you get to select one print before I select prints to send to those who leave the selection to me. I will make images of the prints accessible to this group of patrons simultaneously and selections will be granted on a first come, first server basis.
  • 45-50% of the funds for this project will be income for Eric Robinson's family.
  • 36% of the funds will be donated to World Vision International to help fight against sex trafficking and poverty around the world. World Vision uses 85% of donations to directly benefit children, families, and communities; that means up to 30% of your contribution will work for social justice.
  • I estimate about 10% of the funds will be spent on shipping art to patrons.
  • 4-9% of funds will be taken as commission by indiegogo.com, which makes this crowdsourcing service, depending on whether the funding goal of $3500 is reached. The goal of this campaign is set at only $1000 not because that is the value of the project, but because that makes the threshold for the least loss on commission completely attainable.

The Impacts

Again, your patronage will have these excellent results:

  • You will own a unique work (or group) of fine art wood engraving(s).
  • You will help World Vision International fight sex trafficking and poverty around the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know some of you can’t contribute (I certainly understand a tight budget), but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Get the word out about this campaign using social media.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for your contribution!

story:
Direction chorégraphique et mise en scène: Philippe Lessard Drolet / Interprétation et collaboration à la chorégraphie:Josiane Bernier, Fabien Piché /Assistance à la dramaturgie et à la mise en scène: Bruno Bouchard /Conception sonore:Simon Elmaleh / Lumières et programmation du système interactif: Philippe Lessard Drolet /Répétitrice: Marilou Castonguay


Le Projet

(ENTRE) est un spectacle en chantier alliant danse contemporaine et installation scénographique interactive. Sur scène, deux interprètes incarnent les différentes géométries de relations entre deux êtres, tissent un réseau de liens, de liaisons et d’attachements, et occupent un espace intime qui se transforme sans cesse, à l’image de leurs présences.

L'écriture chorégraphique se veut un terrain de jeux vivant, où les corps composent avec la trace lumineuse et sonore de leur présence. Un travail de duo qui, par ses mouvements et interactions, crée le contexte spatial et musical de sa partition.

Le dispositif scénographique développé pour le projet consiste en une installation de projecteurs d'éclairage suspendus en matrice au-dessus du centre de l'espace scénique. L'ensemble projette au sol une série de carrés lumineux qui reproduisent une image vidéo basse résolution. En captant la présence des danseurs par des caméras en direct placées dans l'espace, celui-ci devient la source même qui les éclaire. De la même manière, l'environnement sonore du spectacle se cronstruit en réaction aux mouvements et déplacements.

L'aide financière demandée servira à assumer les dépenses liées aux dernières phases de création du projet, qui sont indispensables, nécessaires.

Le spectacle sera présenté par la Rotonde et le Mois Multi à Méduse en février 2016.


La Compagnie

Théâtre Rude Ingénierie

TRI est une jeune compagnie de production multidisciplinaire de la ville de Québec qui se concentre sur la rencontre du son, de l'image, de l'objet, de l'ingénierie et du vivant. Les productions de TRI mélangent autant de techniques d'arts bruts que de nouvelles technologies, d'arts populaires et actuels. Passionnés par le bricolage, le «faire avec» et le pouvoir de l'objet transformé, ces artistes sont constamment à la recherche d'une nouvelle écriture composée à l'aide du langage que le projet lui-même inspire. Cette démarche «indisciplinée» souhaite que ce soit les projets eux-mêmes qui dictent les formes, les lieux et les conditions de création. TRI prône une utilisation de la discipline comme outil ou matériau plutôt que fin en soit, à la recherche de nouvelles corrélations entre les pratiques. Le groupe aime dire que qu’il sculpte l’espace dans le temps.

Depuis 2013, le trio a multiplié les collaborations dans les milieux du théâtre, de la danse, de la musique et des arts visuels. Il a notamment présenté La Petite Maison Musicale au FIMAV 2012, Dreamland à l'Usine C en 2015, en plus de cosigner la station Les Palais du parcours déambulatoire du Carrefour International de Théâtre au printemps dernier.


Les retombées du projet

La diffusion de (ENTRE) dans la saison de la Rotonde et dans la programmation du Mois Multi constitue, pour Théâtre Rude Ingénierie, une étape importante dans le développement et la visibilité de son parcours artistique. L'approche multidisciplinaire de la compagnie permet de développer des liens et des complicités avec des créateurs de différentes disciplines, et donne par le fait même la chance de rencontrer de nouveaux publics. En ce sens, (ENTRE) cadre parfaitement dans les objectifs artistiques que la compagnie met de l'avant.

En axant cette création sur la danse contemporaine comme langage dominant, et en y juxtaposant d’autres formes d’expressions (une construction performative, propre à TRI, le dispositif scénique abordé comme œuvre installative, le recourt aux technologies médiatiques actuelles, etc.), le collectif souhaite développer un objet scénique singulier, et inspirant. En ce sens, nous croyons que cette proposition contribue au dynamisme et à la vitalité du milieu de la danse à Québec.

Le soutien Indiegogo servira essentiellement à rémunérer les interprètes et payer les frais de studio. Ce financement est crucial et essentiel afin de mener le processus de création du spectacle à son terme, c’est à dire à sa diffusion publique programmée en février prochain.

spectacle en chantier alliant danse contemporaine et installation
scénographique interactive. Sur scène, deux interprètes incarnent les
différentes géométries de relations entre deux êtres, tissent un réseau de
liens, de liaisons et d’attachements, et occupent un espace intime qui se
transforme sans cesse, à l’image de leurs présences.
L'écriture
chorégraphique se veut un terrain de jeux vivant, où les corps composent avec
la trace lumineuse et sonore de leur présence. Un travail de duo qui, par ses
mouvements et interactions, crée le contexte spatial et musical de sa
partition.
Le dispositif
scénographique développé pour le projet consiste en une installation de
projecteurs d'éclairage suspendus en matrice au-dessus du centre de l'espace
scénique. L'ensemble projette au sol une série de carrés lumineux qui
reproduisent une image vidéo basse résolution. En captant la présence des
danseurs par des caméras en direct placées dans l'espace, celui-ci devient la
source même qui les éclaire. De la même manière, l'environnement sonore du
spectacle se cronstruit en réaction aux mouvements et déplacements.
L'aide financière demandée
servira à assumer les dépenses liées aux dernières phases de création du
projet, qui sont indispensables, nécessaires.
Le spectacle sera présenté par la Rotonde et le Mois
Multi à Méduse en février 2016.La Compagnie
Théâtre Rude Ingénierie
TRI est une jeune compagnie de
production multidisciplinaire de la ville de Québec qui se concentre sur la
rencontre du son, de l'image, de l'objet, de l'ingénierie et du vivant. Les
productions de TRI mélangent autant de techniques d'arts bruts que de nouvelles
technologies, d'arts populaires et actuels. Passionnés par le bricolage, le
«faire avec» et le pouvoir de l'objet transformé, ces artistes sont constamment
à la recherche d'une nouvelle écriture composée à l'aide du langage que le
projet lui-même inspire. Cette démarche «indisciplinée» souhaite que ce soit les
projets eux-mêmes qui dictent les formes, les lieux et les conditions de
création. TRI prône une utilisation de la discipline comme outil ou matériau
plutôt que fin en soit, à la recherche de nouvelles corrélations entre les
pratiques. Le groupe aime dire que qu’il sculpte l’espace dans le temps.
Depuis 2013, le trio a multiplié
les collaborations dans les milieux du théâtre, de la danse, de la musique et
des arts visuels. Il a notamment présenté La
Petite Maison Musicale au FIMAV 2012, Dreamland
à l'Usine C en 2015, en plus de cosigner la station Les Palais du parcours déambulatoire du Carrefour International de
Théâtre au printemps dernier.
Les retombées du projetLa diffusion de (ENTRE) dans la
saison de la Rotonde et dans la programmation du Mois Multi constitue, pour
Théâtre Rude Ingénierie, une étape importante dans le développement et la
visibilité de son parcours artistique. L'approche multidisciplinaire de la
compagnie permet de développer des liens et des complicités avec des créateurs
de différentes disciplines, et donne par le fait même la chance de rencontrer
de nouveaux publics. En ce sens, (ENTRE) cadre parfaitement dans les objectifs
artistiques que la compagnie met de l'avant.
En axant cette création sur la
danse contemporaine comme langage dominant, et en y juxtaposant d’autres formes
d’expressions (une construction performative, propre à TRI, le dispositif
scénique abordé comme œuvre installative, le recourt aux technologies
médiatiques actuelles, etc.), le collectif souhaite développer un objet scénique
singulier, et inspirant. En ce sens, nous croyons que cette proposition
contribue au dynamisme et à la vitalité du milieu de la danse à Québec.
Le soutien Indiegogo servira essentiellement à rémunérer les interprètes et payer les
frais de studio. Ce financement est crucial et essentiel afin de mener le
processus de création du spectacle à son terme, c’est à dire à sa diffusion
publique programmée en février prochain.

story:
Crowdfunded Art!

By contributing to a literary prize, you are helping a young writer create their art!

The #AppropriationPrize events highlighted two things: the lack of diversity in the ranks of senior Canadian editors and journalists, but also the democratizing power of social media. A crowdfunded literary prize won't just support new literary voices and nurture emerging indigenous writers, but is also the ultimate boon to young writers -- and to all of you who contribute. The more money we can raise, the better because it means we have more to give to emerging artists. But how many people give is also important.  Imagine knowing, as a writer just starting out, that your work is being supported by 1000 people. Our contributions, all together, are worth so much more than one big donation. Together we are a chorus of positive change, creating and building.

Point being: NO DONATION IS TOO SMALL! Remember the story of the hummingbird and the forest fire? Little hummingbird flew back and forth, sprinkling tiny droplets on the raging fire, while the other animals stood by and watched in wonder. "What are you doing Nenookaasi?" they asked her. "Surely you will perish and you cannot stop this fire?" 

"I am doing what I can," she replied.

(Why not check out Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas' beautiful book that includes this tale: Flight of the Hummingbird by Greystone Books? Learn more about his art here:  http://mny.ca/en/)

 

Indigenous Voices Matter

Seems obvious, doesn’t it? The more perspectives we can see/hear/read the richer our imagination, intellect and spirit.  Cherokee Nation academic and author Daniel Heath Justice offers seven reasons on his blog, Imagine Otherwise, why Indigenous literature matters:

  1. It can give perspective on the diversity and complexity of the Indigenous community, revealing one dimensional stereotypes about Indigenous people for what they are;
  2. It can be beautiful, showcasing the “full, rich depths of Indigenous humanity and creative spirit.” Beauty is a positive and healthy thing to experience and be changed by;
  3. It can empower by reflecting back an image of community that is affirming of humanity, dignity and strength;
  4. Reading nuanced stories of human experience builds empathy, which we so desperately need to nurture and build in the non-Indigenous community at this moment in our history;
  5. It leaves a legacy of stories for future generations;
  6. Writing, reading, discussing, considering Indigenous literature firms up continuity of Indigenous culture. “The People go on, and so do the stories.”
  7. Creative expression in all forms is transformative, and offers hope and possibility for a wholesome abiding in the world by the artist and their community.

Daniel Heath Justice, Chair of the First Nations and Indigenous Studies Program at UBC, has a forthcoming book, Why Indigenous Literatures Matter (Wilfred Laurier U Press). In the meantime you can read his blog post on this subject, which I have tried to summarize, here: http://imagineotherwise.ca/scholarship.php?Blog-Posts-6

 

Where Should I Start?

Don’t know where to begin? Here’s a great piece by scholar Alicia Elliott, Ten Indigenous Writers You Need to Read Right Now:

https://www.vice.com/en_ca/article/ten-indigenous-writers-you-need-to-read-right-now.

CBC has a more daunting list of 108, recommended by listeners:

http://www.cbc.ca/books/2017/05/60-books-by-indigenous-writers-to-read-as-recommended-by-you.html. Pour yourself a cup of tea and savour losing yourself in these lists…

Logistics

It's a delight to announce that we will partner with the Indigenous Literary Studies Association (ILSA) to administer the award. ILSA is a national organization of scholars, knowledge-keepers, artists, and community members. Their guiding purpose is to honour the history and promote the ongoing production of Indigenous literatures in all forms.  We will announce more details about the award on Saturday May 27, 2017 at Ashineu Aimun: An Indigenous Poetry Night  at the Imperial Pub, 54 Dundas St. E., Toronto, 8:00 p.m.

Learn more about ILSA: http://www.indigenousliterarystudies.org/govern...

Ashineu Aimun: https://humanities.utoronto.ca/event_details/id...

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out! The more the merrier. More money means more art! Share our info on social media and ask people to donate.

Thank you.

Blessings,

Robin Parker.

story:
THE PROJECT

     The N-Word will be a dense 56-page, softcover book, measuring 6 x 8 inches, fully illustrated with high-quality color reproductions throughout. The book is first and foremost a presentation of paintings created by artist Peter Williams in 2014 and 2015. The "N-Word" of the title refers to an African American superhero serving as Williams' avenging alter ego, who redirects the power of the racial epithet toward those engaged in systematic acts of oppression and hate.

     The book contains a four-page introductory essay by publisher and editor Ryan Standfest, examining Williams' work and placing it into both a historical and contemporary context. Running alongside the images, is a conversation between writer Bill Harris and Peter Williams, in which both discuss their upbringing and race in America. Writer Lynn Crawford contributes a five-page short story inspired directly by the paintings contained within this volume, which addresses issues of spectatorship and healing by way of action.

     Peter Williams is an important contemporary painter and The N-Word presents some of his most important recent work. It is a timely and pointed, deeply-felt response to the increasing instability along the racial and political fault lines that remain unhealed and continue to convulse in the United States. Williams' images need to be seen and considered. 

     The N-Word will be printed in a small edition of 200 copies according to the proposed modest funding goal. Should that goal be surpassed, then the print run will be increased accordingly. 

     The book is an extension of the mission of publisher Rotland Press, which has an established and successful record of seeking out and supporting work that uses satire and caustic wit to tackle pressing socio-political issues. 


WHAT WE NEED + WHAT YOU GET

Rotland Press is making use of crowdfunding as a means to publish this project when it is most needed, by those who feel strongly that it needs to be seen. This project is a labor of love and is designed and packaged accordingly. It is the hope of Rotland Press that there is an audience for this material, who will fund it into existence out of a similar sense of urgency and care.

The proposed funding will cover the following:

  • Printing costs for a 200 copy print run: $1,200.00.
  • Shipping of the books from the printer to the publisher: $300.00.
  • Packaging to ship all books out to customers: $100.
  • Printing of a 100-copy, 10-color, silkscreen print edition by Peter Williams, hand-signed and numbered by the artist, available as an exclusive perk: $900.
  • Printing of a limited "thank you" postcard with an unpublished new image by Peter Williams: $50.00.

Unique and exclusive perks include:

  • A handsomely printed "thank you" postcard for all contributions, presenting an unpublished new image by Peter Williams.
  • A 10-color silkscreen print by Peter Williams created exclusively for this project, handprinted in Detroit at ESP Custom Screenprinting in Eastern Market in an edition of 100. Signed, numbered and dated in pencil by Williams. 
  • A limited number of copies of "The N-Word" signed by Peter Williams, with an exclusive, tipped-in risograph bookplate.

The 10-color screenprint. Printed on 100-pound Durotone Newsprint White paper from the French Paper Company of Niles, Michigan.


Exclusive risograph bookplate. Signed and numbered in pencil by Peter Williams, tipped-into the inside front cover of all signed copies.

TIMELINE

The campaign for The N-Word will last only 30 days. At the end of this period, pending successful funding, the following production sequence will unfold:

  • The completed PDF of the book will be delivered to the printer.
  • Printing time is estimated to take three to five weeks.
  • The silkscreen edition will be printed at ESP while the book is being printed.
  • The postcard will also be printed during this time.
  • Copies of books and the print edition will need to be signed by Peter Williams (this requires shipping time to the artist, time for material to be signed, and shipping time back to the publisher).
  • Books, prints and postcards are estimated to ship during the month of September.
Updates regarding this process, will be posted regularly.


THE CHALLENGE

     Crowdfunding always relies on the openness and goodness of those who believe in the project they are committing to fund. Rotland Press is dedicated to funding The N-Word and getting it and all of the perks that accompany it to you, as soon as the funding is complete. Should there be any delay in the timeline as outlined above, all contributors will receive notification.

     The immediate challenge is to fund the publication of The N-Word. The secondary challenge is to increase the print run, and therefore the scope and audience reach of The N-Word. 


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

     If you are unable to contribute to contributing funds to The N-Word, then the most immediate and important contribution you can make is to spread the word about this project and to help generate interest in supporting it. You will have the gratitude of all involved.


ABOUT PETER WILLIAMS

     The paintings of Peter Williams have been described by artist and writer William Eckhardt Kohler as "in no particular order: hallucinogenic, acerbic, pained, beautiful, confessional, obsessive, critical, jarring, wild, weird and profoundly human. They are born from Williams' experiences of race, appetite, and physical vulnerability. The visual lexicon is a heady blend of psychedelic color, abstract pattern, and cartoon-manic imagery." Most recently Williams has had solo exhibitions with Foxy Productions and Novella Gallery in New York City and Paul Kotula Projects in Detroit and was included in the 2016 group show "Me, My, Mine: Comanding Subjectivity in Painting" at the DC Moore Gallery in Chelsea. Recipient of numerous grants, including a Joan Mitchell award in 2004, his work was included in the 2002 Whitney Biennial and is in the permanent collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts is work was included in the 2002 Whitney Biennial and is in the permanent collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts, the Walker Art Center, the Whitney Museum of American Art and the Mott-Warsh Collection, Flint.

     Peter Williams' work can be viewed at http://peterwilliamsart.co/

ABOUT LYNN CRAWFORD

     Art critic and fiction writer. 2010 Kresge Literary Arts Fellow and 2016 Rauschenberg Writing Fellow. Her criticism has appeared in Art in America, Tema Celeste, The Metro Times, Zing, Parkett, Modern Painters, American Ceramics, The Brooklyn Rail, and Infinite Mile. Her books include Solow, Blow, Simply Separate People, Fortification Resort, a collection of sestinas responding to the work of visual artists, and Simply Separate People, Two. She is a founding board member of Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit. Her most recent book is Shankus & Kitto, to be published in August 2016 by DittoDitto Detroit.

     More about Lynn Crawford at http://www.lynncrawford.net/


ABOUT BILL HARRIS

     Playwright, poet, critic, and novelist. Professor of English at Wayne State University in Detroit.  Formerly Production Coordinator for Jazzmobile, and the New Federal Theatre, both in New York. Author of Birth of a Notion; Or, The Half Ain’t Never Been Told, A Narrative Account with Entertaining Passages of the State of Minstrelsy & of America & the True Relation Thereof (Wayne State University Press). Published plays include: Stories About the Old Days, Riffs and Coda. Queen of Sheba, and BOO! A Musical Fantasy had their debuts at the St. Louis Black Repertory Company. Anthologies containing his work include The National Black Drama Anthology: New Plays for the Black Theatre, Voices of Color: 50 Scenes and Monologues by African American Playwrights, both edited by Woodie King, Jr., and African American Literature, edited by Al Young. Harris has had two books of poetry published: The Ringmaster’s Array and Yardbird Suite: Side One, which won the 1997 Naomi Long Madgett Poetry Award. His latest book Booker T. & Them:  A Blues (Wayne State University Press), is an examination in long poem form of the era of Booker T. Washington. He is currently working on three novels, one set in 1954, a second in 1854, and the third, the story of a young blind entertainer rising to fame during the 1940s and 50s. Harris has been honored as the recipient of the Kresge Arts in Detroit Eminent Artist of 2011 award.

     More about Bill Harris at http://www.billharris.info/

ABOUT ROTLAND PRESS


"Rotland Press seems to have its roots in The Realist and Grove Press c. 1960s more than in the Hippy UG press that followed or in the gentrified graphic novel presses that have come along since. Nihilists and other marginally socialized types will be as glad to discover their satirical publications as I've been." 
—Art Spiegelman, co-editor ofArcade and RAW, author of MAUS

     Founded in 2010 by editor-in-chief and publisher Ryan Standfest (www.ryanstandfest.com), Rotland Press is a small publishing house located in Detroit, Michigan, USA. It is a publisher of printed projects that promote subversive humor— be it black, dark, gallows, satirical or absurd. Rotland Press aims to occupy a place between the mainstream and the avant-garde, the philistine and the genteel, industriously manufacturing the finest in despairing entertainment.

    Visit Rotland Press at http://rotlandpress.com/

story:
The Place & The People

Area 51 is home to a group of artists from all different backgrounds and disciplines: painters, sculptors, wood workers, graffiti artists, photographers, performers and more.

After 5 years running an art gallery and shared studio space, I am lucky to have such a strong community of friends and artists; they have seen us through tough times and we are all able to benefit from the good times.

Our studios are available for rent as a means to supplement building and operation costs. Our front flex space is in need of an upgrade so it can be accessible for temporary rental for a variety of different mediums: photo shoots, meetings, workshops...and any income that the flex studio makes goes back to costs and improvements.

I am honoured to have the opportunity to work along side these talented emerging creatives, and utilize my experience in the professional art industry to ensure they not only have a space to produce their works, but a means to be exposed.

As the 23 year old me always said, "I want to make sure these creative creatures continue creating".

Our Needs...

We want what the art community so desperately need, a place to produce work. As we continue to upgrade our space, the more we can accommodate creative professionals to easily produce. With your help, we will ensure our facilities function efficiently so these creatives can continue developing in their art careers.

In order to function, there are some basics every studio requires which unfortunately we are in need of: Lighting, sound equipment, proper storage, website and supplies to maintain exhibit worthy walls.

The funds will go to building dividing walls, which require framing, drywall, tool rental, plaster, paint, scaffolding and electrical. Once we get the shell of the front space built, we must ensure the aesthetics are to standard, including noise, washrooms, ventilation, security and proper lighting. In order to continue promoting the space and the artists, we require a website to be designed, developed and updated.

Your donations allow us to build a foundation that will secure our future to maintain the space, straightening our grounds to protect us from any hiccups along the way, while establishing a communal space that will advance all creatives and their endeavors.

...& Your Gets

These creatives are extremely thankful. We have many of our in-house artists who are offering their works as incentives along with your donations.
The years working in the arts has also networked us with other amazing companies who have teamed up with us and donated products and services which expand our audience and what you get with unique perks! Ranging from jewelry, clothing, yoga sessions, drawing workshops and custom tattoos.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways you can help! Spreading the word not only benefits this campaign, but our efforts with the studio and our services. The more people in the know the better. We are also open to in-kind donations too! Gear, equipment, materials or supplies are more than welcomed. Just shoot us an email to area51toronto at gmail.com

Thank you so much for your support. Without you, there is no community.

story:
Shanghai’s iconic Wutong leaves turns yellow during the winter which looks like a golden dragon laying in the city. The city’s sanitation workers will cut branches from Wutong trees once a while. These branches will normally be shred and burned. We will collect discarded branches to make a dragon, which will become the effigy of Dragon Burn 2018. The work will be completed collectively by volunteers from the general public who play a significant role in the process. 

上海的冬天，道路两旁的梧桐叶变黄，整个街道从高处看上去就像一条巨龙蜿蜒盘旋在整个城市中。城市的环卫工人在梧桐叶凋零后便会开始修剪枝干，我们会从环卫工人处回收这些被修剪掉的枝干来做一条木龙，成为龙焰2018年的木雕，这项活动会有众多志愿者一同协助完成。

The Dragon will be 6M tall in a spiral shape, head to the sky waiting for the flames to come out of his tongue at the last night of the Burn! The body part will be connected by bundled branches that was discarded by the city, the Dragon will be lifted up by bamboo stick. 

龙高6米呈螺旋上升形状，龙头仰望天空，等待着最后一晚的火焰吐舌！身体部分将有捆绑好的梧桐枝干组成，整个龙身会被竹棍腾空抬起。

The Dragon will be light up by LED lights during the Burn event, at the last night we will remove the lights and start the burn from the Tail! 

整个龙身会被覆盖灯光，最后一晚将会移除灯光并从尾部开始燃烧！

The money you donated will be mainly used for below items您所捐献的资金将用于以下内容:

- Branches repurchase from the city 回收梧桐枝干

- Bamboo sticks purchased from local 当地采购竹棍

- Ropes for binding the Dragon body 捆绑所用的麻绳

- Nails, iron wire, fuel and other tools 钉子，铁丝，燃料及其他工具

- Transportation for moving the Dragon 运输木龙的费用

- Other miscellaneous expenses

story:
As tensions grow between Russia and America so does tourism and creative brands that allow the two to merge. 

By listening to whatever our country tells us about another country and openly accepting our own negative propaganda as fact limits our creative potential with the citizens of another country.

During the month of September I plan on effectively starting a merging brand of artists and creative collaborators between two of the worlds most powerful cities, Washington D.C. and Moscow. Already I have music events, photoshoots, museum exhibitions, live painting sessions, and much more lined up with artists throughout Moscow.

All I need from you is a pledge of $10 in exchange for 1 pin out of a batch of 80. The idea behind this is $10 per pin for 80 pins will provide me with $800 to cover only a portion of my trip to Moscow. (10 x 80 = 800). In total my trip will cost $2,200. $1,400 from me and $800 from you. The $800 will cover:

  1.  20 rolls of film ($200)

  2. Museum and Art Gallery fees (3 galleries/museums for $200)

  3. Music venue cover (5 shows for $100)

  4. Photoshoot supplies. Props, food, and rentals.  ($200)

  5. And finally $100 to put a smile on my face haha jk the last $100 will be a cushion for miscellaneous taxes spent on the last four items. 

The pin you will receive is posted below and is the insignia of a creative brand based in D.C. A dope local brand that I have worked with for the past 5 years. The same brand that took me on tour when I was 19 and the same brand that I have tatted on my right arm.

So please if you share any interest in breaking down the barriers between two great cities, supporting dope young brands from both cities, or just want to see your boy in Russia celebrating life and love then donate $10 and claim your pin!

story:
Where is Bronzeville? 

Bronzeville is an area of the South Side of Chicago. It became the American center for African American Art, business, entertainment and culture in general.  Bronzeville was the end destination of  the 20th Century Great Migration of African Americans from rural Southern states to cities in the North. African American Legends such as musicians Louis Armstrong, Muddy Waters, Sam Cooke, Nat King Cole, Mahailia Jackson, boxers Joe Louis, Jack Johnson writers Lorraine Hansberry, Richard Wright and the activist Ida B. Wells called Bronzeville home. 

100% OF THE PROCEEDS OF THIS FUND RAISING EFFORT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT THE PEOPLE OF BRONZEVILLE. THE MONEY RAISED IN THIS CAMPAIGN WILL BE MATCHED BY LOCAL POLITICIANS AND WILL PAY FOR SEVERAL PHOTO MURALS THAT WILL RE-CONNECT BRONZEVILLE TO ITS HISTORY, THE FIRST PHOTO MURAL OF NAT KING COLE IS UP ON THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF 43RD AND KING DRIVE, FACING NORTH.  A SECOND MURAL, OF LOUIS ARMSTRONG SITS AT 39TH AND KING DRIVE. WE NEED YOUR PLEDGE ASAP TO erect a large (20' x 27') photo mural of writer and Bronzeville Legend Lorraine Hansberry.  Make a year-end donation to Bronzeville Legends and invest in our efforts to create community.

What is the Bronzeville Legends Identity Initiative?

The three pillars of vibrant community development are Identity, Sustainability and Mobility. Identity represents a community’s historic and present day character. When we think of China town, we know exactly what we are getting, quality restaurants and an authentic experience of Chinese culture. When we think of Devon Avenue, we know it as place to experience Indian culture.

 Bronzeville is sitting on a gold mine, it’s rich history and famous past residents. Musician Louis Armstrong performed at clubs like the Savoy Ballroom (4733 S. King Drive), the Royal Gardens (459 E. 31st Street), and lived on 44th street. Author Richard Wright wrote his first book here. Heavyweight boxers Joe Louis and Jack Johnson called Bronzeville home as did Muddy Waters, Sam Cooke and many other African American legends.

The Impact

The Bronzeville Legends Identity Initiative is a creative placemaking campaign that uses large scale commercial quality public art installations to create a backdrop, an ambiance within which the community’s commercial and cultural activities can take place and which acts as a magnet for tourism and a catalyst for healthy outdoor activities like biking and walking. When you attend a museum exhibit you are encouraged to “exit through the gift shop” and leave some of your money behind. The idea is to transform Bronzeville into an outdoor museum that attracts visitors and to make its commercial corridors the gift shop. This increases retail sales per square foot and offer chances to sell Bronzeville as a cultural and entertainment destination, leading to jobs.  An investment in high impact, coordinated Public Art that conveys a single message of Black excellence that compliments all of the cultural activities that go on in Bronzeville and supports the new Artist galleries and work spaces, attracting those members of the "creative class" so important to the revival of any community. The works turn the neighborhood's vacant lots into a positive attribute because the open spaces create viewing opportunities.  The photo murals "activate' the space around them and support the many gardens springing up in the neighborhood.

What We Need & What You Get

Violence is a quest for Identity.

The violent young man seeks to learn about himself by clashing with others.  Belonging to a gang gives the young man an Identity; membership makes him a somebody. At this crucial time, not only is not enough being done to give these young men something to hold on to, public schools are being closed and the County jail is over-flowing. When a kid looks back in his past, there is nothing there to give him hope,no values but materialism. To free them from the cycle we must provide them with a substitute Identity, one that will enhance their self-esteem. These Art works partly replace that combative Identity with a new, healthier one by reconnecting our youth to a time when we were great. The Initiative improves pride in the neighborhood and teachrd the area's children about the values of black excellence, entrepreneurship and perseverance that enabled these neighborhood legends to achieve what they did.This helps address the neighborhood's current problems and improve safety perception.  For all of this to succeed, the support of the entire community and indeed, the diaspora is needed.

This IndieGoGo campaign is a way for everyone to show their respect for the culture and to say, "We know where we’ve been and so now know exactly where we are going."  This campaign is not an attempt to live in the past, but rather a retracing of our steps back to that fork in the road where we got lost, so that we may start off in the right direction. Show your support today by making a pledge. Your donation will help erect a large (20' x 27') photo mural of Bronzeville Legend Lorraine Hansberry, who wrote "Raisin In the Sun",  to be installed Spring, 2015 on the top wall of the Cain Barber College at 365 East 51st Street. Banners will be made and installed in the windows of local businesses. By reminding us of our past, the scale and power of these artworks get us excited about our future. Pledge today.

Risks & Challenges

Every project worth doing carries a certain amount of risk. However, the main risk with the Bronzeville Legends Initiative is not doing it. A community that has lost its collective memory ceases to function as a cohesive unit. Design standards that emphasize and preserve Bronzeville's unique Identity have been established and communicated to corporate entities who wish to do business in the community.  These standards will prevent large businesses from putting up bland, "cookie cutter" facades that are inconsistent with Bronzeville's image and requires them to make a contribution to the neighborhood's Identity.  Media companies that own billboards throughout Bronzeville are being asked to donate ad space for photo murals that sell the idea of community, not just product.  The Initiative seeks to get various community players working together from a common artistic stylebook in an effort to create a Bronzeville Renaissance.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • You can get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this project with your friends!

We thank you in advance, and wish you much love in this holiday season!

story: My dog Samantha swallowed a squeak toy and it got lodged in her intestines. She required surgery to remove the blockage and save her life. I am a professional pet photographer and recently did a shoot inspired by the famous Coolidge painting of dogs playing poker. I am selling a limited run of signed prints to pay the medical bills from her veterinary care.

story:
Kaleidoscope - UWE Animation's 2016 Degree Show.


When: June 3rd 2016

Where: UWE Bower Ashton Campus (4th Floor)

Why: Help towards venue hire, printing, material and catalogue costs


Every year UWE holds a campus wide Degree Show, allowing third year students to showcase their work from the past year. 


This usually includes a screening of our films, displays of posters, models, degree show catalogues and much more. However, being students, we're all very poor and need your help to fund the show.


We're actively fundraising too, but there's only so many bake sales that we can do around UWE - and competition is pretty fierce there too. Please help us reach our fundraising goal by donating so that we can buy catalogues, foam boards and most importantly - drinks for the show. 

As well as holding a show at UWE, we're thinking of organising several pop up shows around the UK to show our work to as many people as possible. If we raise enough, we'll be able to visit more areas, but this means increased costs for venue hire and transport. The more we receive, the more we can do.

You don't do this for free though - as a way of thanks we'll give you rewards for your generosity. Some of which are animated or personalised just for you. 

In any case, we'd love to see you at the UWE Degree Show on June 3rd - come and see the range of work, the mix of disciplines and styles and the culmination of 3 years at UWE.

story:
Proud new Doumbek Daddy!

Who We Are & What We Do:

We are the EXTRA-vagrant BRC drum-building collective known as Camp ThumpThump, and our OVER-THE-BIG-TOP aim is to create theater while simultaneously gifting the experience of drum building. Our project leader, the good Doctor Thelonious D. RUM, will build and usher over 100 drum shells (made with rhythmic snake oil) to the playa.



A few of the gifts at Caravansary!


 More of the Caravansary gifts! *Thank you to Erica Martin for some of the photography on this page. You can visit her at: www.ericaphotography.com


Participating burners might "win" a drum-building experience by playing our not-so-traditional carnival games on the Midway. The rest of us are his well-snake-oiled carny kinfolk, a traveling troupe of drum-building apprentices that guide burners through the workshop experience, a path that  leads the naive as well as the clever through a maze, marinated in the sauce of their own psyche. This unique skill set, a fantasy world grounded in the makersphere, is our gift to the playa. To make it happen, we need your help. As a collective we travel to you from far and wide: New York, Texas, Louisiana, Utah, Indiana, California, & more. We arrive with the skills to help you paint, stain, woodburn, tie-dye, build, & tighten your own customized drum.... but first you must play our carnival games to win the chance to do so!


Experience Dr. Thelonious on the Midway:

Our double-wide Midway booth will be split in two: Front of House (our games/facade), and Back of House (the workshop);

Currently stretched over these fine lands resides a medley of Carny Beings that are in this very moment conspiring to captivate you. With our peerless pedigrees, we are well equipped to taunt and excite you, especially with our bait of FINE PLAYA MADE DRUMS! AND THE RAKUMBEKS CREATED WITH ACTUAL PLAYA!

RHYTHMIC TREASURES within the authentic (wink) magic medicine show wagon await those fortunate few whose kismet and keen insight lean in their favor! Oddities found are gifted to all players; Everyone moves on with a valuable token representing their time within our baliwick of roving performers. So, while the pot of magic is still percolating, we're well aware of our ONLY limitation.... that being, "Besides the seed money from Burning Man Arts of $1000.00, who's gonna HELP pay for this show??!"



Monies Needed for our Whacky Medicine Show:


Drum Building Costs:
[3 drum types, 35 of each]
Ceramic Rakumbek = $941
Black Cherry/Bass Ashiko = $770
Black Cherry/Bass Djembe = $1062
Total: $2773
*does not include the lumber/supplies required to gift 20-30  of our                     "Oing-go Boing-go Bongos"

Transportation:
Trailer Rental NY-NV = $360
Fuel = $1158
Total: $1518

Facade & Game Supply:
Gypsy Wagon (Amish buggy chassis) = $250
Asst Supplies = $400
Facade and Booth Ambience = $250
Game Development /Supplies =$500
Wooden Nickels = $160

Total: $1560

Total [Minimum Required]: $5851

*Minimum Required to Fundraise less BM Honorarium: $4851
*For a more detailed itemized budget, please visit our website:
https://medicinalhealingexcursion.wordpress.com/carnival-of-mirrors-dr-thelonious-budget/

For the price of your morning coffee, you can contribute to our project and know that every cent will help us put a smile on every Burner's face that walks toward our installation. Although not every Burner will be able to build a drum, every burner has a chance to vie for one by playing our carnival games. We will have plenty of swag available for game winners who can trade up for something more valuable with each win! Our dream is big, our motives are sincere, and materials are expensive. Please join us in curing the world one drum at a time!
story_txt:
Proud new Doumbek Daddy!


Who We Are & What We Do: 
We are the EXTRA-vagrant BRC drum-building collective known as Camp ThumpThump, and our OVER-THE-BIG-TOP aim is to create theater while simultaneously gifting the experience of drum building. Our project leader, the good Doctor Thelonious D. RUM, will build and usher over 100 drum shells (made with rhythmic snake oil) to the playa. 




A few of the gifts at Caravansary!


 More of the Caravansary gifts! *Thank you to Erica Martin for some of the photography on this page. You can visit her at: www.ericaphotography.com

Participating burners might "win" a drum-building experience by playing our not-so-traditional carnival games on the Midway. The rest of us are his well-snake-oiled carny kinfolk, a traveling troupe of drum-building apprentices that guide burners through the workshop experience, a path that  leads the naive as well as the clever through a maze, marinated in the sauce of their own psyche. This unique skill set, a fantasy world grounded in the makersphere, is our gift to the playa. To make it happen, we need your help. As a collective we travel to you from far and wide: New York, Texas, Louisiana, Utah, Indiana, California, & more. We arrive with the skills to help you paint, stain, woodburn, tie-dye, build, & tighten your own customized drum.... but first you must play our carnival games to win the chance to do so!



 Experience Dr. Thelonious on the Midway: 
 Our double-wide Midway booth will be split in two: Front of House (our games/facade), and Back of House (the workshop);Currently stretched over these fine lands resides a medley of Carny Beings that are in this very moment conspiring to captivate you. story:
We are Lauren and Alyssa.

Us at the premiere of Alyssa's music video Ghost Town, Directed by Lauren!
Lauren is a filmmaker, photographer, actress and producer and Alyssa is a independent musician. Together we are driving cross country to play music and make films and your contributions would support both Alyssa's music tour and Lauren's first solo film project!

Our route! 

What We Need & What You Get

For three weeks, we're traveling from Moscow, ID all the way back to our homes in Brooklyn. In that time we're gonna need gas, food and lodging. Also, Lauren needs to buy additional equipment to make her short film (and that ain't cheap). If you contribute some dollars you can get some pretty cool schwag...including post cards from us from the road, a personalized social media hello from us, a download of Alyssa's album, a truck stop gift we'll buy especially for you AND MORE! Go check out our perks section! GO!

This amazing (and in Alyssa's case...truthful) truck stop gift hat could be yours!

The Impact

Lauren and Alyssa have been working in the arts, both together and seperately, for many, many, (many) years now and are about to embark on an incredible, art-filled journey... And even the tiniest of donations can help two independent artists continue to follow their dreams of playing music and creating a film .

Check out Ghost Town, Alyssa's music video directed by Lauren!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute (we get it...times are tough) PLEASE send this link around and get the word out. Also check out the cities we're visiting (see gigs below) and if you know anyone in those places, send them our way for a show, a high five or a beer!

story:
Hello Everyone! 


When I started this project, over 7 years ago now, I had no idea how much work would have to be done before I could even see the finish line.  The paintings themselves were only fully completed late last year and the writing process, now well over half way done, has been another major engagement.  (Recently surviving a full hard drive crash)  I have been researching these women for the entire 7 years, reading biographies, tracking down articles online and digging up any piece of valuable information that I could apply to telling their stories.  

The book itself will be large format, 10 portrait paintings and 10 biographies to accompany them with an introduction about myself and some personal insight in regards to how I came across these incredible women.  Included will be, Tina modotti, Camille Claudel, Sophie Scholl, Melina Mercouri, Farough Farrokhzad, Phoolan Devi and Xiang Jingyu.  Never heard of em?  Thats the point, I wanted to portray women who have been swept under the rug yet have incredibly interesting and important stories to tell.   These are not dry, academic biographies but rather stories told with historical context and emphasis on the effect each woman had on our world as we know it today.  My goal is to present these women as a mirror or window for us to look into and draw inspiration from as reminder that we can all  follow what our true passions are and use our heart as a compass without fear.

This campaign is part one of a two part crowd-funding effort to bring the book to life.  In this first part I am asking you to help me get the book edited and get the scans of the paintings so I can have high quality images to use as the plates in the book.  The second part, which will be launched later this year, will offer the finished book for pre-sale, prints of the paintings and the original paintings themselves as incentives to bring the book to press. 

In order to obtain high quality scans I need to bring the paintings to a large format scanning facility where each scan can cost up to 200$.  Hopefully I can get a discount on volume, but this process will be essential to ensure that the images retain the texture and richness of the original portraits.  These scans will also be used in creating prints of the paintings later.  

                                

                                    "Tina Reciting"    Soy ink on archival paper 

I will also be using the funds that I raise to create submission packages to be mailed off to various publishing houses where I may find an editor to work with.  If not, then I will be hiring and editor and publishing the book myself during the second part of the campaign.  Either way the hard cover book will be available during the second part of the campaign.  

I know that I am asking a lot of peoples attention spans in an age where books are becoming an antique of sorts and most information out there is formatted in 2-5 minute packages.  But I'm betting on peoples desire for a physical copy of a well made book and I'm sure that there is still a desire for a project like this.  I'm hoping that i can find the audience who will embrace and share the stories that I have dedicated so much work in bringing to life.  If you are unable to contribute financially in some way please share this campaign with someone who might be interested or simply post it to your social media pages.  That is almost as important as the financial support so please share the link. 

                              

                                "Tina Revolutionary"   Only 4 prints available!!!  

The sheer amount of time and energy put into this project can never be recovered but I have truly found a depth of appreciation for the lives represnted here and it has made me a better person in the process.  It is my hope that if you are reading this that you see the value in having a book like this in circulation and that you will  consider being a part of its birth.  There is no doubt that equality between men and women is part of our evolution as human beings and that when that equality is reached we will have a more peaceful and prosperous world!  Thank you from the bottom of my heart for even considering being involved, this is just the beginning!   

                       


   -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------                    A small but meaningful percentage of the proceeds of this project will go to the education of girls in Afghanistan.  I am doing the research myself to make sure the money goes to the people themselves and gets used properly.  As i get closer to the end of this project I will give more detailed info on where exactly the money is going, thank you.                                

                                                

          Tyler Schwarz is a Canadian born artist currently living in Los Angeles.
                                 See more of his work at www.art-tyler.com

story:
What is The Meeting Point?

The Meeting Point will be a temporary structure created from a large 11' x 6-6.5' knitted fabric supported by a wooden frame creating a curved section of wall.  The Meeting Point was inspired by the concept that walls can retain stories and memories.  This project aims to create a shared space in and around which people can spend time reflecting or sharing ideas through conversation or the use of notebooks provided in the space.  People will be invited to post their drawings or writings from these notebooks on the walls of the structure.  I hope the unexpected nature of the materials being used to create the space will interest and draw people in.
This piece will be presented as a part of the Build Peace 2015 art program, Together Separate,  "...an artistic showcase of individual and collective work that engages with the global issue of contested boundaries, borders, and spaces, which is directly reflected in the host city of Nicosia"   

Where and When is The Meeting Point?

This interactive installation space will be presented at the Build Peace : Peace through Technology conference April 25th and 26th in Nicosia, Cyprus, the world's last divided capital city.  Through people interacting with the space and posting stuff on the walls, I hope to create a site and time specific record of experiences of the installation, the conference, and the city around us.  Due to the prohibitive costs of shipping a large wooden structure, I will be traveling to the conference a few days ahead of time to build the structure on site. 
More information about the conference can be found on their website:  http://howtobuildpeace.org/

Who is The Meeting Point?

The Meeting Point was conceptualized and is being built by me, Talia!  I hope to have assistance building the wooden structure when I reach Nicosia, but all of the labor behind creating the knitted wall and a floor covering will be done by myself.  


How Will The Meeting Point Use Your Money?

All work going into creating this installation is volunteer work.  I am not being reimbursed for the hours of labor or for time that I am taking off work to travel to create the piece on site.  The biggest remaining financial obstacle is purchasing my plane tickets to get there and back!  Airfare will be anywhere from $900-$1500 depending on when I can buy my tickets and which airline's scheduled flights work for the timeline of this project. I will also have to cover food and transportation costs in Nicosia.  The Build Peace conference can supply me with some funding to cover material costs and is going to try to set me up with housing among the local art community.  If I have some extra room in my budget I would like to add more details to the installation such as cushions for people to sit on.  I would also love to explore bringing this installation to other conferences and events, so any remaining funding would go towards further developing and expanding this project for future occasions.


In Conclusion

I am excited and honored to have this opportunity to bring my art work to an international event.  I am determined to make this project happen whether or not I meet my fundraising goals in this campaign and I am looking into other forms of fundraising.  I am passionate about the idea of creating intentional and interactive space to foster community even on the transient level of a conference.  Being able to take this project to Cyprus and then continue to develop it beyond the Together Separate show would be incredible!  Even if you are not able to contribute financially, thank you for taking the time to listen to my ideas and please share this project with others!

story:
My name is Amber Doe and I am an artist. My latest project is called “I want you: portraits of my mother.” I have been selected to create and exhibit "I want you.." in Buenos Aires, Argentina for the international art fair Arte BA taking place this May 2015.


What is "I want you: portraits of my mother:”

A series of seven images and one video, where I am disguised as my mother. There are too few interesting and complicated images of American Black Female Identity in the world. This work is adding to the collective visual conversation.


Why Buenos Aires?

"I want you: portraits of my mother" was also selected for creation and exhibition in Southern Spain, but I did not have the same resources, mentorship and exhibition opportunities in place.


Your help

Your help literally means the world to me.  Because of your support in my last campaign Doe in Finland I was able to do work for a solid twelve months and was exhibited in Hämeenkyrö, Finland,  Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, The Hague, Netherlands, El Bruc, Spain and fingers crossed Buenos Aires, Argentina! My work is personal and intimate, but I am concerned with open expression and opportunity, giving a voice to marginalized and underrepresented communities. It makes the world a less lonely and more beautiful place when there are unique perspectives and independent expression.


How I will spend the money:

Flights from Tucson, AZ to Buenos Aires, Argentina are expensive! I will use the money for travel, camera equipment, printing and framing costs for exhibition, and my room and board while working in Argentina.

story:
Hello All! We are PepperScar Productions! A indie Award winning film company, owned by Randy Lee Beasley. We are

Currently in post production of one of our newest films, Whom I Fear: Part II. That is were you come in! Sadly, PepperScar is not racking in the dough as of yet. But, we are known to donate to other film companies projects all of the time! We are trying to raise as much as we can, but not get greedy with it. We have a major scene that needs to be refilmed, and with that..we Need rental (or purchase) expenses, for location, and for the filming equipment. Not to mention, we are currently at a loss of using our "camera". the final scene we need to film is ready to go...except for the means to film it,

And of course...light it, and help with any further post production expenses (there are more than you think).This is more of a, Randy Lee Beasley needs your help,

Than PepperScar. But hey, he owns PepperScar. So, it is all in the same. We have many rewards and perks for you to choose from! Our last indiegogo was a huge success and raised over $2,000!! (welcome to Woodbary). So, let's get this going! Whom I Fear Part: II is the sequel to PepperScar Productions very first indie film! And this film needs to be done right! We can not do it without you!
